name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Wednesday, 27 May 2020.

name: Presidente. –
text: On behalf of Parliament and personally, I would like to express my deepest condolences to George Floyd's family and friends. His death on 25 May provoked, as you know, many protests both in the United States and also in Europe, showing everyone that respect for democratic values and human rights is a fundamental, daily, demanding and necessary task.  We can rest only when Martin Luther King's dream comes true and people will never be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. This Parliament has always strongly condemned all forms of violence and discrimination and is committed to respect for the rule of law. We will begin our plenary today – and then we will have a debate on this – with this important invitation: I would ask you to observe a minute's silence in memory of George Floyd and all the victims of violence, racism and discrimination. Thank you. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that room Spaak 3 C050 is fully connected to the Hemicycle, in order to allow Members who have no place in the Chamber to take part in our work. Members whose names are on the list of speakers are invited to take their places in the Hemicycle, where they will find, in the place assigned to them, a card with their first and last names. Members who are not on the list of speakers will be led by ushers to other posts.  I inform you that a attendance register is linked in both rooms. I would also remind you that the use of masks covering the mouth and nose is mandatory. Speakers who prefer to speak in the debate without a mask will be allowed to do so for the duration of the speech alone.  I would also like to call on my fellow Members to include the voting card when they take their seat, so as to make it easier for microphones to function and to identify them. I welcome The President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen. Thank you for being here with us.

name: Manon Aubry (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, allow me to intervene at this opening to refer to the resolution of the extreme right tabled on the debate that will animate us on the death of Georges Floyd, who is using this death to accuse our political group and France insoumise of encouraging and perpetrating acts of violence throughout Europe. We know that hatred and slander are the hallmarks of the National Gathering, but I hope to be able to count here on the support and condemnation by every republican force of this undignified defamation. This abject manoeuvre actually masks the chilling acts of white supremacists and racists who have been rooted in the ideology of the far right and the National Rally since its founding. We are proud, on the contrary, here to be the heirs of communist resistance fighters who gave their lives against Nazism, while your political formation was founded by a former SS so that this ideology survived the war. Violence is your business fund, on the far right: that of the police violence you cover, that of the fascist groups you hatch. Your violence reminds us of the bitter certainty that drives us: where there is no justice, there is no peace. We will therefore continue to march against racism and against you, with justice and peace as the horizon.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I take the floor on the basis of Articles 157 and 171 of parliament's Rules of Procedure. Mr President, I strongly object to the way the speaking time is allocated. For such important debates as the future of Europe, such as the Brexit deal, such as transport, the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists is given four minutes.  In four minutes, Mr President, if I have to allocate them, i have to give all my colleagues a 17-second speech. This is a pro forma debate. You are first among equals and your task is to ensure that every Single European Representative has the opportunity to speak out, to defend his opinion, because that is the job of the representatives – to speak. I know there are those who don't want to hear from some of my colleagues. I know there are those who don't accept some of their colleagues, but they should have the freedom to say it. To the left of the Communists I will tell them to stop abusing and seek political dividends from police violence or vandalism and robberies.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would remind you that I must ensure, together with the cooperation of the group chairmen, that the right to speak is exercised.

name: Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the people in Europe who have shown their solidarity. As far as I am concerned, I would like to inform you and my colleagues that I have been the victim of police violence by the Belgian police. I consider this to be a discriminatory act with a racist tendency.  Yesterday, as I left the Gare du Nord, I saw nine police officers harassing two young black men. I had my phone in hand, I took a picture of the scene with my phone, which is legal. The police went to me, they ripped my phone out of my hands. Four of the nine armed policemen brutally pushed me against the wall, violently took my purse, pinned me to the wall, legs apart, and a policeman wanted to feel me and search me. They treated me humiliatingly.  When I told the policeman that I was a Member of the European Parliament, he did not believe me, even though he had my two passports, my European Parliament pass and my German passport. He then asked me for the residence card of Belgium. I gave it to him. I took my badge in my bag and I had the badge around me. I filed a complaint today because we cannot allow this police violence to pass. This experience, at a time when the whole world has seen the unfortunate consequences of police brutality, is traumatic for me, but I am here, although I have spent the whole night here in Parliament to write, and I did not have the courage to go out until 6 a.m. I was here yesterday, we can check it out with our badges. So we need to take concrete action for many people who are not here and who have not been able to escape police violence.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you very much for your comment. Of course we are close to you at the moment. I invite you to come to my office to tell me in detail what has happened and to be able to ask the Belgian authorities for clarification. I think they're going to have to explain. Thank you.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as President of the Greens-ALE Group, to which Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana belongs, but simply also as a citizen of the Belgian State, I would like to express my indignation at the events against our colleague. Ms. Fofana did not commit any wrongdoing. If she was molested by a squad of police officers, it was simply because she took pictures of these police officers molesting two young people. This, not to the displeasure of the supporters of the police state, is legal in Belgium and must remain so. And I cannot help but think that the colour of our colleague's skin is no stranger to the very fact that she was arrested and the brutality and disrespect she suffered. We all know how difficult and demanding policemanity is, but it is precisely because the police are one of the arms by which the state uses and exercises its monopoly on legitimate violence that all those who wear it must at all times exercise restraint and discernment. It is at this price that the respect of all will be earned. It is therefore right that our societies stand up en masse against police violence, which is growing in scale and intensity, especially since it strikes people of colour or those who rise up against the established order. Whatever the status of the victim, as Pierrette said very well, facts like yesterday's are intolerable. Therefore, Mr President, I ask you, on behalf of all of us, to protest vigorously with the Belgian authorities and to demand that all the light be shed on these events and that appropriate sanctions be taken.

name: Clare Daly
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, yes, I would like to support the request to postpone the vote on the ratification of the Euro-Mediterranean Aviation Agreement with the State of Israel. This ratification has no actual practical implications as the agreement has been provisionally applied since 2013, but to adopt it now in the context of the announcement by the new Israeli Government of their imminent plans to annex one third of the occupied Palestinian West Bank, in flagrant breach of international law, is of substantial symbolic and political importance.  To ratify this agreement now would send an inconsistent message from the European Parliament. It would be perceived as an upgrade in bilateral relations with the State of Israel, a positive for them and a complete shift in the EU’s long-standing policy of linking any upgrade in the relationship with Israel to progress on conflict resolution. Clearly this latest move from Israel is only going to accelerate the conflict and the hardship on the Palestinian people. We should not normalise Israel’s violation of international law by ratifying this agreement now, and I’m asking colleagues to please support the postponement of this decision.

text: – Mr President, I was requested by the Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) to read out the following text concerning the urgent procedure: On 8 May, the Commission adopted a proposal modifying the Directive on Administrative Cooperation by deferring by three plus three months the deadlines imposed on financial institutions and tax advisers to comply with their obligations under the Directive. The ECON coordinators have therefore agreed to follow the urgent procedure under Rule 163 for this file.

name: Manon Aubry (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, under pressure from the banking lobby, the Commission is asking us to vote in an emergency procedure on the postponement of tax transparency measures that we sorely need to combat tax evasion. This contempt of Parliament, which is called upon to speak in haste and without going to committee on such an important issue is, I believe, and must be said firmly, inadmissible. Our group will of course vote against this emergency procedure and appeal to all groups today. This detestable way of doing things is symptomatic of the European Commission's current focus on the fight against tax evasion. The health crisis has a good back, because it is really just a pretext to delay again and again the implementation of the tools that would finally allow progress. In the Commission's view, therefore, it must be inferred that there is an urgent need to wait. Urgent to wait and do nothing to combat tax evasion. Yet Member States must now, immediately, spend billions of euros to save their economies, to save jobs, to save businesses, and now is the time to recover the hundreds of billions of euros lost to tax evasion across Europe than ever before. The powers of money will always find good reasons to push any regulation away from the Greek calendars. The urgency today is not to facilitate their work. It is we, ladies and gentlemen, who make European law, not the European lobbies. What is urgent, finally, is to start resisting lobbies and acting in the interests of the european peoples.

name: Thomas Waitz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There is no doubt that it is time to provide support to our farms in Europe – in this crisis and in the event of their loss of revenue. In itself, however, there is the crisis reserve provided for in our common agricultural policy. However, both the Council and, I believe, my own Member State, Austria, have decided against disbursing the crisis reserve. I suspect this is because large farms would have received significantly less in proportion here than smaller ones. But I can only guess what the background is. What remains is that we are now using the money here from the second pillar, that we are using the money that is in itself earmarked for climate protection, for environmental protection and for supporting regional communities. We in the Opinion Group, including the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, believe that this is too short-sighted.  However, since the Commission has made it clear that, if we MEPs in this House table amendments, this request or proposal will be withdrawn, which would have meant that our farmers will not receive any help from the European Union, I would urge my group not to vote against it, despite serious reservations about this urgent procedure.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on anti-racism protests following the death of George Floyd (2020/2685(RSP)). I would remind honourable Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure for this debate, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted. I would like to give the floor to Minister Brnjac, on behalf of the Council, for her presence.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for inviting the Presidency to share its views on the crucial topic of racism. The brutal killing of George Floyd was shocking and it has provoked a tide of emotions and protest, not only in the United States but around the world.  I would like to start by using this forum to express, on behalf of the Croatian Presidency and of the Council, my deepest condolences to the family and friends of George Floyd. Let me say loud and clear that we stand in solidarity with victims of racial discrimination across the world. Black lives do matter and systematic racism and discrimination have no place in our society.  The events that triggered the recent protests raised, first and foremost, the issue of police treatment of African-American people and, more broadly, their place in society. Because of each country’s history and social and political context this situation cannot be transposed to Europe one to one. Equality, human dignity, respect for human rights, together with tolerance, gender equality and the prohibition of discrimination are founding values of the European Union. Among the tools we have to fight racism, the main one is the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, which protects citizens against any discrimination on the grounds of race, colour, ethnic origin and religion or belief. The Racial Equality Directive, as the first new-generation equal treatment instrument extending legal protection against discrimination beyond the grounds of gender, is the key instrument at EU level. Not only did it pave the way for extending protection to new grounds and fields, it changed the European human rights infrastructure forever by requiring all Member States to designate national equality bodies to promote equal treatment. The Presidency is strongly committed to fighting racism. Therefore, it gives me great pleasure to announce the marking of the 20th anniversary of the adoption of this crucial legislative instrument, organised by the Croatian Presidency and in cooperation with the European Network or Equality Bodies, the Commission and the Council on 29 June, the exact date of the adoption of the directive by the Council.  The EU has so far developed a robust legal framework, including specific legislation on combating intolerance and hatred, such as the 2008 Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia. In June 2016, the Council invited Member States to ensure the effective transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision and other relevant hate-crime laws at national level. In addition, it asked all Member States to develop effective methods to report and ensure proper recording of hate crimes. In conclusions adopted in October 2017, the Council also welcomed the measures coordinated by the Commission’s High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. All these countermeasures need to be accompanied by anti-racist education and youth work and, more precisely, the need to develop democratic resilience, tolerance and conflict-resolution skills in the learning process. To sum up, we have the tools, legislation, knowledge, education, counter-narratives, but also condemnation of any form of racially motivated violence, hate speech and discrimination. At the same time, however, we in Europe must be vigilant in the face of a worrying increase in the number of manifestations of hate speech and racism affecting minorities. The Fundamental Rights Agency report, ‘Being Black in the EU’, released in November 2018, revealed the unacceptable challenges black people still face in our countries. The inclusion of black people is hampered by several obstacles: discrimination against them during their job search, mismatch between individuals’ educational level and their current jobs and access to housing. We are therefore compelled to take such matters extremely seriously. It is our obligation to lead an uncompromising fight against racism in our Union.  The European Union is deeply committed to fighting all forms of discrimination within its borders as well as in the world at large. In March 2019, the Council adopted EU human rights guidelines on non—discrimination in external action. This provides guidance to enhance the effectiveness of EU human rights policy in combating discrimination on any grounds, including race, and to increase the visibility of awareness of EU values and action in combating discrimination in its external action. Abuse of power has to be denounced and combated everywhere. Societies which pride themselves on representing the rule of law, democratic principles, fundamental freedoms and human rights should set an example in this respect. All societies must remain vigilant against the excessive use of force and ensure that incidents such as the killing of Mr Floyd are addressed swiftly, effectively and in full respect of the rule of law and human rights. We trust in the ability of the American people to come together to heal as a nation and to address these important issues. Racism is not just a problem in the United States, as I said, and as the protests in many European countries and across the world have shown. The responsibility for combating racism rests with all of us: politicians, teachers, civil servants, students, parents, policemen, citizens. With all of us.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, I do not know what it is to be black. I do not know what it is to be black, or a member of any minority, be it ethnic, religious or sexual, in the places I’ve lived. Je n’ai jamais fait l’expérience d’être traitée différemment pour la seule raison de mon apparence. Je ne sais pas ce que c’est que d’être traitée avec soupçon jour après jour dans la rue ou en faisant mes courses, à la recherche d’un emploi ou d’un nouveau logement, comme notre collègue nous l'a tout juste raconté. C'est incroyable! La plupart d’entre nous dans cette salle ne le savent pas, mais nous savons une chose: beaucoup de gens, eux, le savent et ils nous disent à pleine gorge que nous tolérons le racisme depuis beaucoup trop longtemps. Cela doit cesser. Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, les gens qui manifestent dans nos rues, dans nos pays, des deux côtés de l’Atlantique et dans le monde entier élèvent leur voix, désireux de se faire entendre. Il est grand temps de faire plus qu’écouter, plus que condamner, il est temps de parler du racisme ouvertement et honnêtement et voilà pourquoi je tiens à vous remercier d’avoir inscrit ce point à l’ordre du jour de la session plénière et de l’avoir mis à la première place de votre session. Honourable Members, as a society, we need to confront reality. We relentlessly need to fight racism and discrimination: visible discrimination, of course, but also more subtle racism and discrimination – our unconscious biases. All sorts of racism and discrimination! In the justice system and law enforcement; in our labour market and the housing market; in education and healthcare; in politics and migration. We should join forces at all levels: European, national, regional, local, public and private, business and civil society, and each of us individually, as citizens, to build a Europe that is more equal and more humane, more fair. And let me be very clear: in our Union there is no place for racism or any kind of discrimination. This is for sure. (Applause) And honourable Members, together, we need to answer difficult questions: why do racism and discrimination endure in our societies? Why are there political parties supporting xenophobia and racism that win elections? Why are members of ethnic and religious minorities underrepresented in political, social and academic institutions – and overrepresented in poverty, illness and law-enforcement statistics? What can we do in the fields of education, employment, healthcare, housing and more, to build an open, fairer and more conscious society? What can we do so that our institutions better represent the diversity of our European societies? This is not the work of a sectoral policy, of a single person, or of a single Commissioner. This is why I am here, as President of the European Commission. I want to get to the bottom of these questions. Next week, we will have a structured debate on racism in the College and let us look around here in this very Chamber. The diversity of our society is not represented and I will be the first to admit things are not better in the College of Commissioners or among the European Commission staff. And this is why I say we need to talk about racism and we need to act. It is always possible to change direction if there is a will to do so. Let me take one small example of a small step in the right direction that I witnessed when I was Defence Minister in my home country. At the time, in the German armed forces, a recruiting system had been in place for decades that always favoured the same. We had some excellent candidates who would bring valuable assets to our armed forces – sometimes rare assets, like speaking Arabic or Farsi – and yet, somehow, those assets were not valued. Not at all. And in a mission abroad, such skills could save comrades’ lives. But at the time, the attitude was: ‘Ah, but the system does not allow for this and we have never done this before.’ But then, analysis and reflection started and finally led the German armed forces to change the recruiting system and it was for the better of the German armed forces, it was for the better for society! It has now become a fairer system for those soldiers, so we can change if there is the political will behind it. There is a way to do it. We need to talk about racism with an open mind. The good news is: we do not start from scratch. In the European Union, discrimination is prohibited at the highest possible legal level: I mean our Treaty, our Charter of Fundamental Rights, both on grounds of race and ethnic origin. We also have European laws against racism, ethnic discrimination and hate speech: our Racial Equality Directive; our Framework Decision on combating forms of expressions of racism and xenophobia, to name just a few. We have cooperation tools involving experts from all Member States, a High-Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance, and a European Network of Equality Bodies. Here again, to name just a few. And we have European funds. But we need to try harder. I am glad to live in a society that condemns racism. But we should not stop there. If we encounter it, we must sound the alarm and act immediately. And we must be aware that vigilance and awareness begin on a very small scale, with each and every one of us. Awareness includes examining ourselves. Awareness includes speaking up in cases of discrimination. Awareness includes questioning privileges we may take for granted, which are anything but.  The motto of our European Union is: ‘United in diversity’. Our task is to live up to these words, and to fulfil their meaning, and this is why I am looking forward to listening to you for a better Europe. United in diversity. Unie dans la diversité. In Vielfalt geeint.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, stand up, rebel, refuse with all his might with the spirit, the heart and the bowels of any form of racism. That is my feeling, but it is also, in my view, our duty as Members in this Chamber. That is why it was so important to have a common text to speak in one loud and clear voice about what is essential. Our rejection and absolute condemnation of racism, our solidarity with all those who suffer and suffer discrimination, a strong message from the European Parliament. The violent death of George Floyd has rekindled the worldwide need to affirm the rejection of racism and the rejection of the abuse of police force. This movement of all colors and bringing together so many young people gives hope for the future. But I would also like to express my admiration for all those other police officers who do their job in an exemplary way and for whom being a police officer is not only a profession but a true vocation. As for our history, we will surely not rewrite it and if we can be proud of many aspects, we cannot as human beings, no, we cannot not also be ashamed. This shame is evident when we think of the concentration camps of the Second World War. It must be just as obvious when it comes to slave-filled boats. Proud, I believe, we can be proud of the values that underpin our European Union, the rules we set for ourselves today and for a better future. However, the daily life must correspond to it, that we give ourselves all the means to implement a policy that will give everyone, without discrimination, the same opportunities and eradicate racism.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, "I can't breathe." George Floyd's words during a long agony of more than eight minutes and 46 seconds are not only the cry of an instant, but the injustice and reality of our time. Why does police violence suffocate black people more than white people? Why does the COVID-19 health and socioeconomic crisis suffocate blacks more than whites? Why does climate change suffocate blacks more than whites?  Rosa Parks ended up in jail for refusing to give up her seat to a target and not stay in the back of the bus.  Martin Luther King paid with death for a life dedicated to ending racial discrimination in the United States. But the inequality and pain caused by discrimination have not prevented decades later their dreams from remaining alive: the cry for equality and social justice of the millions of people who, in recent weeks, on every street in the world, have given us hope back. A hope that calls for compromise. And, as representatives of European citizenship, we have an obligation to eradicate structural racism still dormant in our cities and in our peoples.  It is unacceptable that the Anti-Discrimination Directive has been blocked in the Council since 2008. I see Commissioner Helena Dalí here. I hope to have a good accomplice with her to get this issue unlocked, because we need legislative instruments to be able to end racism, also in Europe, at a time when political parties in Europe are re-being declared racist.  We know that people who do not know its history are doomed to repeat it. A citizenry subjected to discrimination because of their skin color, sex, religion, is doomed to failure. We can only achieve the progress of our societies if we first guarantee that all human beings will be free and equal. And, because the voices of millions of citizens have reminded us that black lives matter, from the European Union we must speak loudly and clearly: "Remove the white knees from black necks forever." At last, the same.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Black lives, all lives matter. The death of George Floyd was terrifying. This brutal crime has proved that, in our societies, there is still a real lack of respect for human life. But we have to be honest, racism is not an exclusively American problem, it is also a European problem. What is happening in the United States with Georges Floyd, the aggressiveness of his death and the lack of respect for human life that this reflects should allow us to look more closely in our European court. With different socio-historical roots, racism and discrimination exist in both the west and east of our Union.  All too often, fear of the other is accompanied by deep, structural, institutional discrimination, socio-economic inequalities that end up harming our society as a whole. And unfortunately some politicians also play with this fear to maintain this feeling and use it for electoral purposes. A society in which one must be afraid if one is different from others is not a society that allows human development.  The Europe I want is a Europe that makes diversity an asset and a force for evolution. It is not enough to legislate respect for diversity, non-discrimination, but above all it must be cultivated, not imposed by force, but cultivated with common sense. I believe that first of all we must start with ourselves and, on behalf of my political group, I would like to propose that the three European institutions work together on this issue. Parliament, the Commission and the Council must sit down at the same table and ask whether our institutions inside sufficiently reflect the diversity of our Union.  I therefore ask the Council, as well as you, Madam President, to support the initiative of a task force on this subject. Because we must contribute to the building of an inclusive society, starting with ourselves. And when we set an example, we can also ask others to respect these principles. Racism and discrimination are a shameful part of our common history and unfortunately also of our present. It is our duty and our responsibility to ensure that racism and discrimination are not part of our future.

name: Susanna Ceccardi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the death of a man as a result of violence deserves justice. And so, rightly, the whole world, expressed its condolences around the death of George Floyd. But for the international press and the mainstream, perhaps some lives are worth less than others. This is the case of David Dorn, who I would like to mention, the 77-year-old African-American, retired police officer, who died on June 2, live on Facebook, while trying to defend a friend's store after the assault of violent protesters in St. Louis. He was black and innocent, too. For his death, however, no march, no protest, no indignation.  Demonstrations across America have become increasingly violent and have also flooded across Europe. The fury against the police has been joined by the iconoclastic fury against the statues and symbols of the past. Christopher Columbus, the Confederate leaders, Indro Montanelli, conquerors of the past, even the film "Gone with the Wind" have been accused of racism. Taking down statues will not save the world from the fight against racism. In addition to racism, there is a widespread scourge that is spreading throughout the world and we must combat it: it is the ignorance and stupidity of those who want to erase our history.

name: Alice Kuhnke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, a few days after the killing of George Floyd I was putting my youngest daughter to bed. She chatted away and then went silent and asked me: ‘will they kill me too?’ Colonialism has defined American and European societies for centuries. It has created deeply rooted prejudices and inequalities that still prevail and de facto kill people. Of course, structural racism in the EU is different from the US. We don’t have the same horrific history of slavery and lynching, but we do have documented atrocities in our colonial history, which still resonates today through discrimination and police brutality. In addition, we have a recent history of systematic persecution and mass murders of minorities, of Jews, of LGBTI persons and of Roma people, to name a few. No one is free unless all are free. We need to send a strong signal to the US, but also to sweep in front of our own door.  This Parliament and your Commission will define how the EU steps up to create a sustainable society that leaves no one behind. There can be no room for racism and discrimination. A first step would be to unblock the anti-discrimination directive that has been stuck in Council since 2008. Madam President, I call on you and the incoming German Presidency to take this historic opportunity for action. Tonight, I want to put my daughter to bed, and reassure her – ‘you will be safe’. Because in the EU we refuse to be silenced by hate, by fear, by ignorance. I ask, on behalf of my daughter, if not now, when? (Applause)

name: Hermann Tertsch
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, how much European pride is being heard here. We Europeans are so good. That's bad. What a good opportunity to do a great campaign, a great anti-American operation, which we love so much. I'm going to read you something written and said by a European. By a current European, a European who has allies in this House and who has a member of his party in this House. It is: "It is beasts, scavenger beasts, snakes, hyenas, beasts in human form that distill hatred, disturbed hatred, nauseating, like dentures with verdin, against all that represents the language, the Catalan language". This is said by Torra. Torra is the president of the Generality. Torra is the chairman of Mr. Puigdemont's party, which is here in this House. Torra is an ally of the president of the Sanchez government within what is the current legislature. Allied with the Communists, allied with the Socialists. A racist who is ruling part of Spain against the Spaniards. That's what happens in Europe, you don't have to go to America. In America we have had a very tragic chapter. On 25 May he died, by criminal action by a policeman, a black man; a black man who had fled the police, who had a lot of backgrounds, who had been in jail... That died, and all of a sudden he's uneded a wave of racism, racism against the American system. A wave of hatred of what the American nation is, used politically against the United States and its president, against which a terrifying fake news operation has been made. And now, another manipulation.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, it is the honour of our European Parliament to open this plenary session with this debate and, on behalf of our whole group, I thank you for that. A tragic incident has become a major political event. The chilling eight minutes of George Floyd's assassination have set hundreds of thousands of people around the world in motion to curb structural racism and police violence. And our outrage this afternoon speaks of how much these acts offend the values we share, and that is why we stand with this movement and the victims of racism and police violence so that a concrete response is given to the demands for respect and equality. In the face of this event, we must also look lucidly at our history and we must see that this event refers to centuries of black domination in the United States and unequal conditions in Europe. Let us keep in mind that our European history has always oscillated like a pendulum between barbarism and civilization, that it is in Europe, despite the reason, despite the Enlightenment, that the worst theories of prioritization of races were born to justify conquests, to justify slavery, to justify colonization and to justify the Holocaust. It is therefore, if we want to root out evil, an entire mental continent that we must continue to deconstruct, and it is also a whole system of economic violence that must be combated because, as we observe, social inequalities continue to intersect racial inequalities. In this work that we must do, Mr President, symbols, like memory, are important, and that is why we must proclaim from this European Parliament, as our resolution calls for, that slavery is a crime against humanity, and together, to act as an act of civilization.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the brutal murder of George Floyd has caused a wave of indignation, anger and protest throughout the world. What happened to George Floyd is unfortunately not an isolated incident and we cannot remain indifferent to the violence of racism.  We must tackle this phenomenon frankly, without hypocrisy, and we must combat all forms of racism, the most obvious and violent, but also the less obvious and therefore the most insidious. And the reference goes to that racism that hides behind compassion or that is hidden in the charitable approach or in also flaunting a moral superiority, betrayed then by a utilitarian conception of those who have black skin. Attitudes all of which offend human dignity.  In the fight against this phenomenon, we still have many battles to win, from cultural battles against all forms of prejudice against social groups to political prejudice, in order to guarantee everyone full enjoyment of rights in the fields of work, education, health, justice and political and social participation. This is the response to all forms of unequal treatment expected of the European institutions and the Member States.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, listening to us all, we are all anti-racists. I'm glad. Racists are always the others. But George Floyd's face is a mirror that reflects the one who looks at him; and the concentration camps where millions of Jews were exterminated 75 years ago are in Europe. Racism is not cured only by laws; racism is not cured by propaganda; racism is not cured by tearing down statues; racism is not cured by insulting cops; racism is not cured by closing its eyes; racism is not cured by racism.  Only when every church, every mosque, every synagogue, is my church, my mosque and my synagogue, will we have cured racism. Racism is cured with education and culture. Racism is humanity's oldest pandemic. We have been suffering from this pandemic for centuries and the day has not yet come when we have decided to quarantine those infected with racism, invest whatever it takes to design a vaccine.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for A person's skin color, country of birth and religion are never a threat. The threat is spelled racism, fear and ignorance. The murder of George Floyd is not an isolated incident in the United States. We also have cases on our continent. The "Black lives matter" demonstrations spread like wildfire in solidarity with all blacks who are subjected to structural racism in the United States on a daily basis. However, the demonstrations also stem from frustration at the structural racism and discrimination that black people, migrants and other groups are also subjected to in our Union.  We should know, however, that structural racism is not always expressed through obscure racial theories. Rather, it is visible in the everyday. In the conversation with community institutions, in the conversation with colleagues, at the schools. Our citizens deserve better. Our EU motto 'united in diversity' cannot simply mean national diversity, it must include other foundations as well. It must include all the people of our Union. It's time not just to talk anti-racism. It is time to act anti-racist by voting in favour of the resolution here in Parliament, but also for the Council to adopt the proposals and for the Commission to implement them.

name: Samira Rafaela (Renew).
text: – Madam President, George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Rayshard Brooks, Mitch Henriquez, Adama Traoré: many have fallen victim and many will follow if we do not act. I stand with everyone who is protesting against police violence, systematic injustices, discrimination and institutional racism. People demand action from our own institutions and our own Member States.  Haven’t we learned from history? We hear that we need to embrace progress, but if my ancestors would see society now, would they see real equality and true respect for human dignity? ‘United in diversity’ is what we say in the EU, so let’s walk the talk. We need a fundamental change in our institutions so that they represent all of Europe’s citizens. A new generation of Europeans wants a seat at the table. They will show up, they will be loud, and they will break through. Black lives matter. (Applause)

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, the instrumentalisation of the death of a man, tragic as it may be, to impose the false idea of systemic racism in Europe is immoral and scandalous. To debate the tragic death of George Floyd in this chamber is to import to our continent subjects, struggles and concepts that are foreign to him. Racial segregation is the opposite of the spirit of our continent and France in particular. Rather than demolishing statues and debaptizing the names of the streets, as has been done a few hundred metres from this Parliament, I prefer to celebrate the history of my country. Rather than constantly condemning our ancestors, I prefer to recall that European civilization was the first in the world to abolish slavery when it was practiced everywhere. Rather than accusing, as in France, the police of racism, I prefer to support them in the face of the multiple and increasingly violent barbaric attacks against them. Rather than classifying people by race, I prefer to recognize only citizenship. The variable geometry indignation that mourns the death of a man because he is black, but never moves about anti-white racism, is unfair and scandalous. It is all racism that must be condemned.

name: Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, for my part, as a black woman in Europe, I have not only become aware of the racist reality here, I have experienced the racist reality of Europe for the last 40 years. What is happening in the world today is the result of colonialist structures of oppression that have been in place for hundreds of years. These are not individuals, they are systemic and institutionalized racism that targets blacks and all ethnic minorities.  I don't want to hear about police training just, I want to see consequences for police violence. I want justice for all those who lost their lives, those who lost loved ones and all those who were traumatized by the police. It is not just black Europeans but all blacks and all their descendants, people of color, including those who continue to drown in the Mediterranean because of a racist immigration policy. I want to be clear: all Black lives matter, whether they are European citizens or not, Black trans lives matter, Black women lives matter, our lives matter. As a teacher, I have seen how children's souls have been destroyed by latent racism or open racism, by this word, the word "hate," which enters the child's soul and ultimately leads to failure. It is time to renew the dialogue so as not to leave anyone stranded and, as Martin Luther King said, we must learn to live together as brothers, otherwise we will all die like idiots together.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the European Commission, all lives matter. To deny this and to claim that the life of only one race matters — that, dear leftists, is racism. To claim that one race is to blame for everything - it's also racism. To claim that only one race is important, again, guess what, and that's racism. Choose, dear colleagues, which thesis you are defending. You either have to respect all lives, or you're essentially defending racist ones. And what's more, when you use one death and one tragedy to amass political capital — that, dear, is hypocrisy. And this has long been the technique of communists, leftists and anarchists. And I remind you all of you who wear these T-shirts that when you wave the flag with sickle and hammer — the red flag — you have to think about how many lives communism and Bolshevism have lost in the whole world they so praise.  When you justify vandalism - it's also, dear, racism and hypocrisy. And one more important thing I want to tell you. When my ancestors fought against Turkish slavery in Bulgaria, they fought honestly with a weapon in hand, and did not steal shops and did not steal shoes and clothes.  The insization of guilt because of origin is unfair, dishonest and wrong, dear. Inging blame to a race is an extremely mean political act. You're also trying to make someone feel guilty about their background. No, that's not going to happen. I am not ashamed of my origins and my nation. On the contrary, I am proud of the ancient and great nation to which I belong.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Madam President, George Floyd died of arrest by three police officers in Minnesota and three weeks later statues of Winston Churchill, Charles de Gaulle were degraded and here we are, I hear you here accusing the whole of Europe of racism. But what happened to us? We do not fight injustice with another injustice. George Floyd is not being done justice by indicted all the police and gendarmes in Europe. Justice begins by refusing any amalgamation. Every year, police officers and gendarmes give their lives for our safety and for our peace and they are not entitled to a single word here. Doesn't their lives matter? Racism is not combated by fuelling the powder keg of resentment with dangerous fiction. How can we say that everywhere in our countries, Europe has structural racism policies in all areas? I will not allow the immense effort of citizens across Europe who contribute to the most generous education, social and migration policies in the world to be insulted - and this is not a theoretical question, because by entering this spiral of resentment, you are adding to the long-suffering reserves of violence that those who dream of fracturing our societies have long accumulated. Racism will not be fought by resuscitating racial divisions. The history of Europe is made of greatness, it is made up of weaknesses too, like the whole history of the world, but our civilization has formed for 24 centuries the idea of the universal. Have we forgotten this by voting today on a resolution that separates black lives from others? An authentic European Parliament should have only one fight: all life counts.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this month we have seen thousands of people taking to the streets demanding justice for the killing of George Floyd. A police officer pressed his knee into Mr Floyd’s neck for a breath-taking eight minutes as he lay pinned on the ground in handcuffs, and Mr Floyd’s killing is not an exception. He’s one out of many unarmed black men who has died at the hands of law-enforcement officers. People are rightfully demanding justice for Mr Floyd but also for all the other innocent lives that have been taken before. The call for justice against institutional racism is not new, but the movement is stronger and broader than ever. Young, old, black, white: everyone is demanding systemic change. The call for racial justice quickly moved to Europe too. This highlights that racism is not exclusively an American problem. Also in Europe, racial discrimination against people of colour runs deep in our institutions and societies. Black lives matter, and that means we have work to do as well. And lastly, our healing cannot succeed without acknowledgment. We need to recognise the injustices of our dark colonial past and how it still influences much of today’s society, and especially the lives of black and brown people. The protests fill me with hope and together we have the momentum to change.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: – Madam President, can you imagine what it does to a mother’s heart when your daughter asks you every day, ‘Mama, I don’t want to have my colour. I want to be white. Can you make me white?’ Can you imagine? Well I can, because it happens to me. I have a beautiful black husband and two beautiful coloured children, so this debate is a very important one. Let the death of George Floyd be a game-changer. Let us fight against racism, online hate speech, discrimination, all together and harder than we did in the past.  Europe is the most progressive continent on human rights, on values, but Ms von der Leyen, over the last days, I was a little bit disappointed. Today you made a very strong statement, but these last days the Commission and the Council were too silent. That’s why we speak out loud today, why we vote a strong resolution, to come out and speak and not speak but to act, so that every child of every colour can grow up safe in Europe. Black lives matter.  (Applause)

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Structural racism in Europe, that seems a little strange to me. We see illegal immigrants demonstrating in European cities for a permanent right to stay. This does not necessarily seem like structural racism. We see street battles between Maghrebs and Chechens in Dijon without the police intervening. Again, this does not seem like systematic state oppression. In many German, Belgian, Dutch or French cities, the police hardly dare to enter certain migrant districts. Again, this does not seem like structural racism. And although it is claimed everywhere that this racism exists, hundreds of thousands of Africans still want to go to Europe. But there is a very simple remedy if you really believe that Europe is dominated by structural racism: stop the Global Compact on Migration for at least ten years until you have ensured that this alleged structural racism has disappeared from the European institutions.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, we are outraged by the death of George Floyd on 25 May in Minneapolis and this is normal. It is part of a list, a very long list of deaths of black people at the hands of the American police for decades and for which justice has mostly not been done. Yes, on many levels there is structural racism in the American system, but systemic racism also exists in our European democracies, our societies. European citizens suffer daily in their access to housing, education and employment because of the colour of their skin, their origin, their supposed origin, the origin of their parents. There is not enough diversity in our institutions, almost not, as we see in this Parliament. There is not enough diversity in our jurisdictions. But above all, some of our fellow citizens suffer every day, suffer every day during arrests by the police. They suffer from police violence at times, repeated checks, and our governments continue to ignore the systematic aspect of these incidents. There have been deaths in France, Germany, Belgium and elsewhere, and there will be more if we refuse to face this problem and dare to ask the question of these daily arrests.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Nassim Nicholas Taleb, a Lebanese—American writer, describes in his books the asymmetries in our daily lives. He recalls that violent revolutions with good intentions in order to change dictatorship have sadly resulted in today’s cases of active slave markets, such as in Libya, and the persecution of innocent minorities like the Yazidis and Christians in the Middle East. All minorities who did not have a police or state force supporting their rights had to pay the price for changing systems that resulted in uncertainty. We have seen similar cases after wars and revolutions when totalitarian ideology replaced the menace of the other and persecuted those who did not fit in and obey, sadly, in my part of the world. Persecution led to the slaughter and suffering of thousands of people. Sadly, the brutal killing of George Floyd spoilt the American dream that we had and we witnessed this with our own eyes via modern technologies. This woke us up and we understood that similar cases need a quota for every group, religion and member of society in order for everybody to feel equal and not like second-class citizens. For many years, we have tried to explain this to our partners outside Europe. We need to export the European way of thinking and show that the EU has the best model as a peace project in the last 70 years. So let us really export the European model to the whole world and try to be honest with ourselves because that is the only one that has worked so far.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I want to join a clear condemnation of the excessive use of force on George Floyd that resulted in a tragic outcome. He, unfortunately, is not the only victim of the systematic, deeply-rooted, institutional racism that has not disappeared for a century and half since the abolition of slavery and 50 years since the civil rights movement. Condemning racism in America is not complete if we do not look at everything we, as the European Union, do wrong. The Non-Discrimination Directive has been blocked in the Council for 12 years. There is a proposal for a further reduction of the Justice, Rights and Values Fund, and school curriculums are often selective and overlook the less glorious part of the past. In the context of foreign policy and transatlantic relations, the European Union should remain committed to improving its partnership with the United States, which will be based on the rule of law, human rights and common understanding of democracy. It’s time to clearly condemn all those within our society who are actively working on additional divisions for political opportunism and together stand up for a Europe united in diversity but also equality for all.

name: Monica Semedo (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I want to share with you an essay I wrote when I was eight years old. ‘I am Monica Semedo. I have beautiful black skin. My family came from Cape Verde to Luxembourg. We almost had to go back to our island because we should be expelled from the country. In the beginning, I was at the Saint-François Institute. Now, our mother found a beautiful large apartment. I am happy with everyone.’ My teacher laughed when I said, ‘We’re all just Luxembourgers!’. She added, ‘We are all just human beings!’  However, colour is not invisible. I have experienced racism. I’ve been surrounded by 40 neo-Nazis shouting at me. I frequently get stopped at airports. Once I was even separated from my friends for hours. I hear prejudiced remarks about black people, and then: ‘But you’re an exception!’ And I say ‘No, I’m not!’ This is why we must support this resolution and call on the Council to unblock the anti-discrimination directive. The time for silence is over. (Applause)

name: Tom Vandendriessche (ID).
text: – Mr President, all lives matter, every human life matters. What until recently was a normal statement has now become taboo. The elite of journalists, politicians and professors are trying to project an American problem of police violence onto Europe and abuse it for their own left-wing political agenda.  But that's not true at all. We have no problem of police violence against black supremacists, quite the contrary! Cops are just being attacked excessively by immigrants here. We have no problem of structural racism, quite the contrary! Nowhere in the world is there a place where people get so many opportunities. We are not privileged because of our white skin color, quite the contrary. Our society is the result of the hard work and genius of our ancestors. It is this society that they want to destroy: the left acts out of self-loathing and wants to erase our history and our culture. We're never going to apologize for who we are. We are never going to allow people to kneel because of their skin color, because this is purely anti-white racism. We are part of a unique civilization and we can rightly and rightly be proud of it.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, before we continue with the speakers’ list, I need to make an announcement, which is to open the first voting session. We will vote on the files as indicated on the agenda adopted today at the opening. The voting session will open from now, at 16.30, until 17.45. The same voting method will be used as during the May I part-session. For the two immunity reports, voting will be by secret ballot. Members will be able to cast their vote in the usual way, but the ballot paper that they receive for signature will not display the way they voted, only the fact that they have voted. All of the votes will be held by roll-call. Explanations of vote may be submitted in writing. Exceptionally, only explanations of vote containing a maximum of 400 words will be accepted. I now declare the first voting session open, which runs until 17.45, and the results will be announced at 20.15. I do apologise for that brief interruption to this important debate.

name: President. –
text: We now continue with the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the Anti-racism protests following the death of George Floyd (2020/2685(RSP)).

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The image of the racist murder of George Floyd doesn't let me go - and shouldn't let us all go. Racism is a global problem, a current one. We too have forms of racism, social inequality: poverty, discrimination, violence, the housing market, the workplace, education systems, unequal wages, behaviour towards refugees, foreigners and minorities. We have our hands full if we take our Charter of Fundamental Rights seriously in Europe and in the world, see it as a mandate to act: human dignity, respect, the prohibition of discrimination, liberal democracy, the rule of law, the protection of minorities. COVID-19 reinforces social inequality in the longer term, so the building plan, the recovery plan, must also be a fight against social inequality in Europe, because that is the only way we can strengthen democracy and, with it, the fight against racism and social hardship.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Madam President, I share what many previous speakers have said of their disgust with racism and discrimination that have lasted for too long, with indicators which continue to be extremely worrying, such as the rise in the number of deaths during arrest or the number of investigations for insults or discrimination. So I focus on three topics. Firstly, the flagship text, the Anti-Discrimination Directive, the Anti-Discrimination Directive, which has been stalled for eleven years because the Council does not want to evolve on the pretext that fighting all discrimination would be too expensive. This must stop either with Member States that better measure the seriousness of the issues or with a new legislative proposal. Secondly, the text of our resolution lacks, from my point of view, a reference to the indispensable actors that are NGOs fighting racism and discrimination. I believe that by supporting them better, we could avoid certain communitarian excesses. Finally, the text addresses the issue of ethnic statistics. I believe that we must be very careful, from this point of view, first of all for a constitutional concern in some Member States and also because these statistics are photographs at a T moment which cannot at any time replace real economic and social proposals to reduce inequality.

name: Irène Tolleret (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that we are having this debate today. In this assembly, all too often, neo-fascist or neo-Nazi parties, though incredibly minority, take advantage of any debate to pour out their hate rhetoric from the other. Today's debate is therefore very important to remind our fellow victims of racism in Europe: we MEPs are here for them! We are here to counter this divisive discourse. We are here to speak louder than the mini-Trumps, the half-Bolsonaros, the ventriloquists of Le Pen or the Salvini at the foot. Vote after vote, debate after debate, resolution after resolution, we will not give up a comma, not a word, to racialist and xenophobic ideologies. The European project was built on reconciliation with the other, Europe is the best shield against the extreme racist right. At the heart of our identity is the pride and strength of our diversity. No to racism, united in diversity, we are stronger, we are more beautiful.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this very important debate. I think it was very obvious from what the President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said in her opening speech: no place for racism in our Union. The Commission condemns all instances of racist or xenophobic hatred and violence. But let me also be clear that we condemn violence in general, wherever it comes from, and that the police needs to do its demanding job but always within clear limits of the law. Racial or ethnic profiling and selective approaches should not be tolerated. And, by the way, our Fundamental Rights Agency already published, I think two years ago, very useful guidelines which would serve as a training for the police and for the armed forces to avoid this kind of treatment. Yes: black lives matter because all lives matter. Everyone, black, white or any other race or nationality, deserves the same chance to be able to participate and pursue happiness in our social environment. We all should be able to say to our children and grandchildren: ‘do not worry, nobody will kill you because of the colour of your skin’. But this debate is also about where we are in Europe with racism and xenophobia, and we have a lot of data, for instance, from the already mentioned Fundamental Rights Agency in its latest report which brings clear evidence that people with minority backgrounds continue to experience harassment, violence and ethnic and racial discrimination in different areas of life in the EU. Indeed, As Members said several times here, we have strong legislation but the legislation cannot do the whole job. We have legislation at the highest possible level, as President von der Leyen mentioned, the Charter of Fundamental Rights. We have 20 years since the adoption of the Racial Equality Directive and over 10 years after the adoption of the framework decision on racism and xenophobia. We have strong legislation and the situation is still worrying, remains worrying. We indeed need to promote and to get adopted the Equal Treatment Directive, which was mentioned here many times. It’s a shame, I would say, that this directive waits 12 years for adoption and I fully rely on my colleague, Helena Dalli, who was here a while ago, that she will be very determined to convince the Member States to take a unanimous decision, because this this directive requires unanimity. The legislation itself is so important, its implementation and proper enforcement, but we need much more, because what’s our problem? It’s deep-rooted prejudice and thinking grounded in stereotypes. We need awareness-raising, we need education, we need culture and we need equality bodies, which were strengthened by our legislation in the last mandate and which should do the good job. We need trust from the people belonging to minorities to report on the cases of harassment and violence against them. They do not trust, they do not report and next week we will also update our strategy on implementation of the Victims’ Rights Directive to encourage victims to report. But we should do much more not to have the victims. It’s late to respond only with criminal justice. We have problems in all the Member States. I would say this is a pan-European problem but with country-specific symptoms. We only have 15 Member States at this moment which have a strategy against racism. We have to talk seriously about that; it has to be changed. We also had to work much more with the digital world because we saw a lot of increase of hatred online. We have quite efficient instruments against hate speech and we have the platforms cooperating, but we need to do much more in this direction. This year, as you know, as per the work programme of the Commission, we want to uphold our European Charter of Fundamental Rights by adopting the strategy on charter implementation. We will also update the strategies on Roma inclusion and LGBTI equality later this year. And, if you noticed, also in the proposal for the EU New Generation budget, there is a very clear line that it must have social dimension and nobody should be lagging behind, and everybody should get the chance to avail themselves of EU funding. We will have the European Social Fund, which is also hopefully well equipped to help minorities. We cannot trivialise the matter. This is not about which political colours we are wearing, but about very basic human rights, the right to be treated equally, regardless of colour of skin, our religion or sexual orientation. We politicians should be put more under pressure. We politicians and opinion leaders who have the influence on what society thinks and how the people approach matters related to minorities, we have to refrain from spreading racially charged hatred for political gains and invest in long-term education and culture and do many more long-term measures. As Ursula von der Leyen said, I can also confirm I don’t have a clue how it feels to be black. I have never experienced any kind of discrimination. That’s why, whenever I go to the Member States and I speak, for instance, to young Roma people, I always ask those who managed to study at secondary school, who managed to study at university. My question is: ‘how did you manage that’, because I know that their starting line is so difficult, much more difficult than the starting line of my children or the children of many of us here.  And they always tell me there were three moments: ‘at some moment I realised I do not want to live the life of my parents. I want to do something more. I want to get out of the trap of, usually, poverty’, poverty was the problem. The second very important thing and condition: ‘I needed to find a helping hand’. Those who managed always found a helping hand. In their local community it was the mayor, it was the NGO, it was the teacher or director of the school. They could not manage without the help. So, zero tolerance for discrimination and zero tolerance for racism cannot be enough. We have to take proactive actions and support people to get out of trouble.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, this has been a useful and emotional debate. I would like to thank you for this opportunity to participate in it. I believe that our institutions are largely on the same line with regard to these important issues. Respect for human dignity and human rights, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law are the very foundations of the European Union. The Council is committed to upholding these values in the EU’s external relations, including with our like-minded partners such as the United States. Let me assure you once again that the Presidency, and the Council as a whole, rejects any form of racism and racial discrimination and supports your fight to make sure our values endure. We have a solid legal framework in place which needs to be complemented by effective implementation, enforcement and targeted measures such as education, public debate and counter-narratives. I can assure you that the Council will continue to follow this debate very closely and that I listened closely to your views today. We must hear the voice of young people peacefully demanding a better and more just world.

name: Илхан Кючюк (Renew)
text: in writing. – 57 years after Martin Luther King's significant "I Have a Dream" speech delivered from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, in which he called for world peace and respect for the rights of people of all races, religions and countries, we see that the racial problem in the United States has not been remedied, despite the efforts made. But America is not alone and no exception in this battle. Unfortunately, hate speech, extreme nationalism and racism are increasingly common in our societies. Including in Europe, the one that claims to be a centager of freedom, equality and democracy. A number of reasons can be cited, but it is a fact that the judicial authorities often exhibit apathy towards the problem, especially when extreme nationalism is empowered, as is the case with my country Bulgaria. This sense of impunity must end, otherwise we will not eradicate the language of hatred and racism, but we will silently observe what is happening.

name: Gheorghe-Vlad Nistor (PPE)
text: in writing. – The resolution we are debating today condemns the killing of the black American citizen, George Floyd, supports peaceful anti-racist protests and strongly reaffirms the anti-discriminatory values that animate the European Union and the Member States. An institutional framework to discuss these contemporary challenges is absolutely necessary so that such events do not happen again; numerous protests have degenerated into violence and vandalism, approaches that cannot bring about the positive changes that we all want.  Continuing the educational processes by which positive values can be conferred on younger generations, the recognition and discussion of negative episodes in recent history around the world and the sincere and sustained efforts of the European institutions to eradicate the harmful effects of these events are the ways forward.  The violent and destructive tendencies of some protesters must be disavowed, which either do not understand that the only way we can correct these historical injustices is to respect democratic laws and processes, or are motivated by extremist political agendas. These reactions, placed outside the legal framework, facilitate slippage towards much more unequal, intolerant and polarized societies. I support the healing process of these deep wounds in our societies through balanced measures, adopted and implemented following serious debates, not under the pressure of the moment.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In the U.S., waves of protest have echoed a bit everywhere. They come to confirm that even in the most powerful capitalist power there is resistance and struggle! While all the uncertainties and difficulties in building an alternative to the rail dominance of the republican and democratic party persist, it is increasingly evident that, if the above can still, the field of those under it no longer wants to widen.  In an attitude of condemnation of racism and police violence and the demand for justice in the face of the vile murder of George Floyd, the demonstrators (of all colours, backgrounds and ethnicities, of all ages, but above all young people) are condemning a deeply unfair and inhumane social order, exposing the lie and rot of "American democracy" to the world and putting into question the capitalist exploitation system itself.  These demonstrations also took place throughout Europe, partly in solidarity with what happened in the US and condemning racism, but also pointing the finger at the discriminatory and exploitative nature of the capitalist system in the 'Old Continent' and, in particular, that of the European Union.  We will continue to denounce and repudiate any expressions of racism and fight them firmly.

name: Guido Reil (ID)
text: Writing. It goes without saying that all forms of racism must be condemned. And, of course, the death of George Floyd is to be regretted. Every life is worth protecting. But what is happening in the United States and has spilled over into Europe misses the real problem. In the United States, more than 40 percent of all blacks belong to the middle and upper classes. They are not victims of society. Fortunately, the days when the US was a racist country are over. Black people, like whites, have their way to the top of society. Condoleezza Rice, Colin Powell and, of course, Barack Obama are just a few examples. That is why this resolution sends the wrong signal. The claim that racism exists everywhere is not only false, but also corrosive. It perpetuates an imaginated immaturity and relieves people of their duty to build their own lives and to live independently. The left, supported by the other socialist parties, abuses and exploits the death of Floyd to pursue its own political purposes. It defines black people as victims who serve them as willing ecrats. At the same time, it is trying to prevent any debate about the harmful consequences of mass immigration with increasingly undemocratic laws. This development is detrimental to Germany and the EU.

name: Sylwia Spurek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " What has happened in the USA, what Orbán is doing in Hungary, what the President of the Republic of Poland says, has the same source – prejudice, hatred, lack of modern, equal education. We cannot stand idly by when, in the United States, African-Americans are treated more brutally and are more likely to die at the hands of the police, and racism is still not effectively combated. We cannot stand idly by when people are deprived of their right to decide their identity in Hungary. We cannot stand idly by when the President in Poland calls people an ideology and the human rights movement compares to Bolshevism. Equality is a fundamental value of the European Union. The human rights system is part of our DNA. Either we will learn to defend this value, or the European Union that we dream of will cease to exist. Perhaps it is high time to ask whether education, in particular civic, anti-discrimination, pro-democracy education, should not simply be the exclusive competence of the European Union. Because how else do we want to protect people from discrimination, exclusion, violence, if we have no influence on what European citizens and citizens learn at school, how european police, prosecutors, judges are trained? It is high time for European education!

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. We must also start fighting structural racism and hatred of minorities in the EU. In the EU, too, police violence and racism are an everyday experience of black people and other minorities. The EU is called upon to present decisive measures to combat structural racism and police violence. Verbal and physical attacks on minorities are attacks on all of us and we must resist. Racism and hatred of minorities must never again become acceptable. Looking away is not an option!

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. On May 25, 2020, 46-year-old George Floyd was brutally murdered. The policeman, who knelt on his neck for more than eight minutes and took the air out of him, was arrested only after massive public pressure. Floyd's only "crime" was to have a black skin color in the United States. George Floyd is just one of many names, in the US a disproportionate number of Americans with dark skin die each year from police violence. But we in Europe, too, live with two pandemics: the COVID-19 crisis and the perpetual pandemic of racism. This deeply interferes with the reality of life for many citizens and our actions. And we politicians must also be aware: in today's world, each of us must take responsibility and actively work to be anti-racist. Because silence and inaction only support racist structures and "habits" that are still present today. Politics must not be held out of responsibility! As long as there is racist nationalist policies that stand up to minorities, migrants and refugees, this contributes to a structure of suffering. #Blacklivesmatter is more than a hashtag, it's activism for a more livable, fairer reality for our fellow citizens with dark skin color. It is not just words that are needed, but measures such as mandatory anti-racism education for all those responsible. #blacklivesmatter. Today. Tomorrow. Every day.

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID)
text: Writing. George Floyd's death was an avoidable injustice. He would have deserved a fair trial, as is customary in a state governed by the rule of law. His death, however, does not justify outbreaks of violence or the tearing down of statues. It is not acceptable that history should now be rewritten or that Western society should be cheered on by a collective guilt, for example for historical events such as the colonial era. The same applies to the fact that a noisy minority wants to impose their ideology on a silent and indiscriminate majority. Every decent democrat must oppose this! The claim that Western society is a hotbed of structural racism is pure nonsense. This is being used by the left-wing extremists as a pretext to destroy our culture and to nip in the bud our resistance to their anti-democratic aspirations. Just to establish their utopia of a multicultural state without borders. Those who do not support them are denounced as racists. We must preserve our culture and the roots of our identity. ANTIFA is a terrorist organisation which aims to destroy democracy, the rule of law and its values, such as freedom of expression. It is therefore mandatory to protect society. And that is what AfD and ID stand for – in contrast to all the other factions.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council meeting of 19 June 2020 (2020/2656(RSP)), and – the report by Kati Piri and Christophe Hansen, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on International Trade, on the European Parliament recommendation for negotiations on a new partnership with the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (2020/2023(INI)) (A9-0117/2020).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the coronavirus pandemic continues to create extraordinary challenges for our societies. As we emerge from the height of the health crisis, we now face a different, yet pressing, task: creating the conditions for a successful economic and social recovery. We need to support the sectors and regions most affected by the pandemic to kick-start the economy and lay the ground for a sustainable recovery across Europe. Yet we also need to ensure that other vital priorities for our Union, such as the green and digital transition, are met and matched by the right resources. That is why the EU recovery plan, presented by the Commission at the end of May, is so important, and why it will be the main focus of our efforts in the weeks ahead. We will shortly be called on to agree not only on the instruments of the recovery, but on the entire Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the coming years, and this is no small task. The Council and the European Council are fully mobilised behind this common effort. Members of the European Council will hold an orientation debate on the EU recovery package on Friday through video conference. The President of the European Council wants to give leaders an opportunity to discuss the various aspects of the overall packages and prepare the subsequent summit, which should, if possible, be a physical meeting.
