While the President of the European Council launched the political consultations at the highest level, following the Commission’s proposal, we also immediately started work in the Council. The Croatian Presidency has organised a series of meetings, both at technical and political levels, in order for the delegates to closely examine and present their views on the building blocks of the package. This technical and political work on the proposals is needed to pave the way for the leaders’ discussion. These discussions in the Council have helped clarify many issues and were held in a positive atmosphere. Delegations are willing to look at both the MFF and the recovery plan as a package, taking into account the effects of this crisis. Continuous cooperation with the European Parliament will remain crucial if we want the package to enter into force already in January 2021. The ambition is for the European Council to provide its political guidance to the Council before the summer break, which would allow us to promptly seek the European Parliament’s consent. Let us be honest: this is a very ambitious approach. Positions are still apart on a number of issues, but together we have to make sure and do our utmost so that the MFF and the Recovery Instrument swiftly bring tangible positive effects for our citizens and businesses. While the EU recovery package will be the main focus of the leaders’ discussions on Friday, they will also touch upon other issues. In particular, let me note that President Michel will update the leaders on the state of play of the EU—UK negotiations on the future partnership. Unfortunately, so far we have not have not achieved as much as we had hoped for. That is the case in all four crucial areas: the level playing field, fisheries, governance and internal security, as well as foreign policy and external security, to which you rightly devote a section in your recommendation. Since the UK Government has confirmed that they will not consider an extension of the transition period, what is ahead of us is about four months of further negotiation, taking into account the time necessary for a proper ratification process. The fact that we are left with so little time is not the choice of the Council, nor of the Parliament, but we have to respect it. The mandate and political declaration that are guiding our negotiator, as well as your resolution on the subject, are anchored into the situation created by the United Kingdom. The UK has a choice: either to preserve enough alignment with the Union and retain substantial access to the single market, or choose its own path – not only in terms of sovereignty, but also in regulatory terms, which would reduce the scope and the depth of the partnership that can be concluded. We believe that the negotiating mandate, adopted by the Council last February and largely echoed by your resolution, provides for enough flexibility to find an agreement in the little time left. This is also why we support the decision of the negotiators to intensify the pace of negotiations over the summer so that, by October, we can see a draft partnership emerging. Before I conclude, let me finally stress that, as also pointed out in your draft recommendation, we have causes for concern in the current implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement. Needless to say, progress in the partnership negotiations has to go hand in hand with progress in the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, the negotiations with the United Kingdom always promised to be difficult, and they have not disappointed. On Monday, President Sassoli, President Michel, and I discussed the way forward with Prime Minister Johnson. The Prime Minister confirmed that he does not want to extend the transition period beyond the end of this year. We, on our side, have always been ready to grant an extension, but it takes two to tango. This means that we are now half-way through these negotiations with five months left to go, but we are definitely not half-way through the work to reach an agreement, with little time ahead of us. We will do all in our power to reach an agreement; we will be constructive, as we’ve always been, and we are ready to be creative to find common ground where there seems to be none. What we are not ready to do is to put into question our principles and the integrity of our Union because it is our duty to protect the interests of the European citizens. Michel Barnier has done an outstanding job over the last month and has explained many times why the four outstanding issues are so crucial. First of all, the level playing field. The fundamental issue at stake here is fair competition. We are ready and willing to compete with British firms. They are excellent and our firms are excellent too; but it cannot be a downward competition. Just think of labour standards or environmental protection. It should be a shared interest for the European Union and the UK to never slide backwards and always advance together towards higher standards. Second, on fisheries: no one is questioning the UK’s sovereignty in its own waters, without any question. But we ask for predictability and we ask for guarantees for fishermen and fisherwomen who have been sailing in those waters for decades. It is very clear that there cannot be a comprehensive trade agreement without fisheries, without a level playing field or without strong governance mechanisms. Governance may sound like an issue for bureaucrats but it is not. It is central for our businesses and our private citizens, both in the UK and in the European Union. It is crucial to ensure that what has been agreed is actually done. Finally, on police and judicial cooperation: we want our citizens’ liberties, fundamental rights and data to be safeguarded in all circumstances and this is why we expect a role for the European Court of Justice where it matters. These are objectives, not only in our discussions with the UK but in any relationship with any partner because these are principles at the heart of the European Union. Fair competition, rising social standards, the protection of our citizens and the rule of law, this is who we are and it is not going to change. Honourable members, I am particularly glad for the unity that all institutions have shown and for this Parliament’s full support throughout this process. This will be even be more important than the next phase of the talks. No one can say with certainty where these negotiations will be at the end of the year, but I know for sure that we will have done everything to reach an agreement and to have a good start with the UK as a third-country neighbour. Meine sehr geehrten Damen und Herren Abgeordneten! Unsere britischen Freunde sind leider entschlossen, einen Schritt zurückzugehen. Sie wollen die Europäische Union und den Gemeinsamen Markt verlassen. Wir werden weiter daran arbeiten, die wirtschaftlichen Folgen für unsere Union abzufedern, und gleichzeitig fordert uns die Gesundheits- und Wirtschaftskrise in einer noch nie dagewesenen Form heraus. Die Europäische Kommission ist in die Verantwortung gegangen. Mit Next Generation EU haben wir einen ambitionierten, einen mutigen Vorschlag präsentiert. Next Generation EU ist ausgewogen, es hilft jenen, die viele Kranke und Tote zu beklagen haben, aber es hilft ebenso den Staaten, die indirekt schwer betroffen sind, weil Lieferketten gerissen sind, weil Fabriken stillstehen, weil die Arbeitslosigkeit steigt. Next Generation EU ist aber weit mehr als ein Rettungspaket. Es ist ein Beschleuniger für Wissenschaft, innovative Forschung und Investitionen in Zukunftstechnologien. Wenn wir es richtigmachen, wird Next Generation EU nicht nur zur Erholung unseres Binnenmarkts führen, sondern seine Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und seine Innovationskraft voranbringen. Was uns wichtig ist, ist, dass wir damit die längst überfällige Modernisierung beschleunigen. Wir wollen nicht in den Zustand vor der Krise, sondern wir wollen nach vorne gehen in einer modernen Wirtschaft, in einer innovationsfähigen Wirtschaft, die uns nach der Krise stärker macht, als wir vorher waren. Next Generation EU ist auch ein Vertrag zwischen den Generationen. Ja, es stimmt, wir müssen jetzt gewaltige Investitionen tätigen, um uns aus der Krise zu wuchten, aber wir bauen mit dem Geld ein besseres, ein nachhaltigeres und ein digitaleres Europa. Europa geht voran. Andere Regionen in der Welt verfolgen ganz genau, was gerade hier passiert, und auch deswegen haben wir Next Generation EU so ausgerichtet, dass es Europas Position in der unmittelbaren Nachbarschaft ebenso stärkt wie auf der großen Bühne. Wir haben jetzt die Chance und die Verpflichtung, ein Europa zu bauen, das besser in der Lage ist, den globalen Stürmen zu trotzen und künftigen Generationen eine sichere Heimat zu sein. Meine Damen und Herren, ich hatte schon mehrfach die Gelegenheit, Ihnen den MFR und Next Generation EU zu erläutern. Das werden wir auch am Freitag im Europäischen Rat tun. Next Generation EU wurde in seinen Grundzügen positiv aufgenommen, auch die Reaktion der Märkte darauf war sehr positiv, und mir ist klar, dass es gleichzeitig sehr wichtig ist, dass wir diese Aufgabe angesichts ihrer Größe und Komplexität ausführlich erklären und ausführlich diskutieren, auch hier in diesem Haus. Mir ist insbesondere wichtig: die Rolle des Europäischen Parlaments, das richtige Verhältnis zwischen nationalen Reformanstrengungen in den Mitgliedstaaten und unseren europäischen Prioritäten – insbesondere dem European Green Deal, der Digitalisierung und der Resilienz – und drittens die Bedeutung neuer Eigenmittel für die Union in einem fundierten Rückzahlungsplan. Es ist meine feste Absicht, mit Ihnen dazu im intensiven Gespräch zu sein. Wir müssen alle an einem Strang ziehen, wir können uns keinen Verzug leisten. Lassen Sie uns das gemeinsam anpacken für Europa!

name: Kati Piri
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, 204 days: that is the time we have left to reach a deal on our future relationship with the United Kingdom. We are now halfway through the transition period, we have held four rounds of negotiations, and it seems we have reached a stalemate. What is needed now is an injection of new energy and dynamism: a paradigm shift in these talks. And although the joint declaration of last Monday didn’t give us many clues, in this House we all hope that the high-level meeting did just that: create a new dynamism. For this Parliament, a comprehensive agreement means guarantees on fair competition with clear social, environmental and labour protection, and this is what Prime Minister Johnson and the EU signed up to only months ago in the political declaration. None of this should be in any way controversial. With zero tariffs, zero quotas, comes – logically – zero dumping. An ambitious and comprehensive future partnership is in the best interest of both the UK and the EU citizens. We, of course, welcome the latest enthusiasm and euphoria of Prime Minister Johnson and his drive to finalise a deal within six weeks – but the Prime Minister did not explain how. We very much look forward to hearing the details on that. Over the past few months, the European Parliament has shown its commitment and has taken its responsibility in reaching this deal. With the UK Coordination Group, two lead committees and 17 opinion-giving committees, we have developed a unique and unprecedented procedure for the report, prepared by Christophe Hansen and myself, that reflects how serious we take our role as the European Parliament. Our President this week took part in the high-level meeting to also present our position, and I’m proud to say that Parliament stands united on a strong text with a clear political message. And that message is simple: yes, we want a deal, but we will not simply consent to just any deal. Our consent is conditional on the UK Government’s adherence to its own commitments. The UK must respect the political declaration and ensure the full implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement. Let me be very clear: the UK’s expectation to keep the benefits and rights of a Member State, without agreeing to any obligations, is not realistic. It’s only logical that, if you want to have access to the market of 450 million citizens, this will come with conditions. The UK Government made a conscious decision to leave the Single Market. We respect this, but so should the United Kingdom, and without a level playing field and fisheries, there cannot be a trade agreement. I do not see a divide between the people of the United Kingdom and those of the European Union. The division I see is between those that have a vision and seek a comprehensive deal, and a UK Government that backtracks on its commitment and continues to put ideology over the interests of its own people. The way forward is clear: we stand united in our demand for an ambitious and comprehensive future partnership with clear conditions and red lines, as formulated. The European Union is united and continues to stand ready to negotiate in good faith: constructively, as an honest broker. Our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, has our full support, and we hope that finally the time has come for Mr Johnson and the UK Government to join us and deliver. We are ready.

name: Christophe Hansen
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, almost exactly four years ago, on 23 June 2016, the Brexit referendum took place in the United Kingdom. Since then, we have been treated to four years of drama, witnessing the UK’s painful coming-to-grips with the reality of unwinding decades of membership of the largest single market in the world and, in my humble opinion, the best cooperation project – even with its imperfections – that mankind has so far created. The Global Britain that Brexiteers dangled before the British people is no longer a viable project – if it even ever was – in a newly polarised world, where the institutions that underpin the multilateral order are being hollowed out and where protectionism is growing in the wake of the coronavirus. While the political Brexit happened last January, the economic Brexit still looms large at the end of this year, following the UK’s ideological decision not to extend the transition period. Our message for the ongoing negotiations is crystal clear: the European Parliament stands behind our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier. The UK claims to seek an agreement rooted only in precedent, yet their proposals in areas such as financial services or professional qualifications go well beyond what the EU has ever conceded in any other FTA. The UK refuses to engage with the EU on topics such as public procurement – notwithstanding commitments taken in the Political Declaration – and refuses to speak about SMEs, yet they do so with other negotiating partners, the latest example being the UK’s objectives for negotiations with Australia, published today, and including government procurement and SME chapters. What a surprise! Any agreement without robust guarantees for a level playing field or without an agreement on fisheries simply will not fly. And let’s be clear: a level playing field does not mean a copy/paste of our rules and regulations, but rather that we take our common point of departure as a point of no regression, following which we jointly managefuture divergence to guarantee equivalence, not necessarily identical rules for all players. We stand firmly behind the Commission’s approach to press for a comprehensive agreement. We reject the UK’s piecemeal, sectoral approach as it is well known that salami tactics lead to a cluttered spaghetti-bowl agreement. The implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement remains key and the European Court of Justice must remain the sole referee of EU law. Indeed, the EU is no less sovereign in its decision-making and decision-taking than the UK is.  Finally, allow me to thank my co-rapporteur, Kati Piri, for the excellent collaboration we have had in this exercise. I would also like to thank the 17 committees which gave an opinion for their valuable input. I sincerely hope that there will only be one last Brexit resolution: to consent to a balanced agreement no later than November this year. Personally, I remain confident that the legendary British pragmatism will prevail over ideology in the interest of all UK and EU citizens. The unilateral, staged introduction of border controls for EU goods coming into the UK, announced last Friday, to give corona-hit businesses time to adapt seems to indicate that. So let’s use this new momentum very wisely.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, compromise seems to mean that half a loaf is better than the entire loaf. It seems nowadays that that’s the position of the UK, whereas before, half a loaf was definitely not better than the entire loaf. Prime Minister Johnson said yesterday, in a press conference, that he wanted a more dynamic nature to these negotiations. He wanted more ‘oomph’. Well, that’s just a metaphor for the UK’s lack of cooperation in the last four rounds, the lack of transparency and also for its lack of commitment to the political declarations that were signed. Prime Minister Johnson: he who rides a tiger is afraid to dismount! Decisions have consequences, and the European Parliament is committed to protecting the best interests of its citizens.  The UK’s participation cannot be a Swedish buffet. We cannot allow cherry-picking. We cannot allow a piecemeal approach. Such decisions have consequences. But no one will take away the UK’s role in the unification of this continent. We all look around and know the fact that this Parliament is sadder without its British colleagues on the benches and we also know that four years ago Jo Cox was slain at the hands of a murderer, and Jo Cox said to us, ‘that which unites us is more important than that which divides us’.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, after several months, negotiations between the United Kingdom and the European Union continue without significant progress on the most sensitive issues, re-emerging the scenario of a non-agreement.  In those circumstances, it is neither acceptable nor responsible for the United Kingdom refusing any extension of the transitional period and, at the same time, not having a constructive attitude in the negotiations and insisting that it does not even fulfil the commitments it has made in the political declaration and the exit agreement, in particular as to the establishment of border controls in Northern Ireland. So if Boris Johnson's government really wants a deal, its negotiating attitude has to change. The European Parliament fully supports Michel Barnier's team in seeking a good agreement and also makes clear what it does not want: the bad agreement that does not safeguard the single market or our environmental, social and labour standards.  The threat of a bad deal and the threat of a non-deal are dangerous games that have everything to go wrong.

name: Kris Peeters
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Mr President, time is ticking, but the question arises as to whether there really is an affectio societatis - the will to negotiate sustainably and achieve a result. Both European companies and workers expect an agreement. Especially now that an economic hurricane like COVID-19 is passing through Europe and business.  Failure is not an option! For my country alone, forty-two thousand jobs are at stake and for the EU that is 1.2 million in the event of a hard Brexit. The draft report before us today can and must facilitate an agreement. This text reflects the principles for a new partnership. Firstly, I would like to stress that the withdrawal agreement must first be implemented clearly and in its entirety. SMEs need to be assured. Secondly, I would like to stress that a new partnership agreement must respect European internal market rules. Thirdly, compliance with the agreement must be permanent. Ladies and gentlemen, we have only a few months to go. But I sincerely hope that the necessary agreement between the EU and the UK will be concluded with a great deal of affection.

name: Johan Danielsson
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you to Mr Barnier, who is here today, for all his work. It is absolutely crucial that we remain calm and together continue to negotiate according to the mandates that we have previously agreed on. I have been responsible in the Committee on Transport for this issue. It is quite clear that it is important that we get an agreement in place that guarantees continued good relations between the EU and the UK.  Every year there are over 4 million lorry journeys by freight to and from the UK. More than 54 million passengers travel between the EU and the UK every year. So it is absolutely essential to maintain these freight and passenger transport. At the same time, however, the United Kingdom has chosen to leave the Union, and then it cannot retain the same rights without any obligations whatsoever.  What we need to ensure is an agreement that ensures continued good relations but also ensures that Britain cannot undermine our good working conditions, our environmental standards and otherwise underbid compete with the European Union.

name: Pascal Arimont
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, Mr Monsieur Barnier, Cher Michel! Let us not deceive ourselves: Brexit is and will remain a huge historical mistake – it will only know losers. As is so often the case in history, it will become apparent that separation and secession can only bring loss. Only cross-border cooperation can bring real added value to the people of Europe. The last 70 years have shown us this impressively. But now even a disorderly Brexit is in the house. This has even become very likely. In this case, I would like to see our small and medium-sized enterprises protected, because they and their employees can do absolutely nothing for this situation. These small businesses, like the big players, can't respond quickly and flexibly to changing trade relationships. So we need quick tools for small and medium-sized enterprises in the event of a hard Brexit that no one wants. In December, in the Committee on Regional Development, we proposed and supported the use of the Solidarity Fund in this case. I therefore urge the Member States to allow our small and medium-sized enterprises to use the Solidarity Fund and to support them if a hard Brexit becomes a real reality.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Mr President, the proposed resolution contains the text that all the parliamentary groups have supported in the Committee on Fisheries to reiterate this fundamental principle which Michel Barnier strongly holds in the negotiations: there can be no agreement with the United Kingdom which does not include a long-term, balanced, sustainable agreement on the issue of fisheries , allowing access to water and resources in a reciprocal manner between the partners that are now the European Union and the United Kingdom. This is a major economic and social issue as tens of thousands of jobs are at stake. This is an issue for our territories, which live off this activity, these exceptional know-how, and which could be weakened by an exit without agreement. Finally, it is an ecological issue because the common fisheries policy has enabled us, for years, to implement with the British a fishery that respects biodiversity. We must maintain these common rules, it is in this spirit that we wish to continue to work and I would like to thank the entire negotiating team and all the parliamentarians, our colleagues, for having incorporated this position into this important text.

name: Loránt Vincze
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, the United Kingdom should become the EU’s strongest ally and partner. This is as yet more of an ambition than a reality, but we all can agree: today we look to the future. Our proximity, the values we share and the common challenges we face make mobility, security, justice and home affairs cooperation as vital as trade. The safety and security of European citizens is essential for us; so is the protection of their personal data. The message of Parliament is clear: we cannot compromise on our values, the continued adherence of the UK to the European Convention on Human Rights and on the role of the European Court of Justice.  The fight against terrorism, cybercrime, and cross-border criminality is one of the success stories in EU-UK relations. This should be continued. But let us not forget: by its own decision the UK will continue as a third country in this cooperation. We must hope that on the other side of the Channel the sense of reality will overcome and we will be able to obtain the closest partnership possible for our citizens’ benefit.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, it is good to see my good friend Mr Barnier again. I must say that for the last few months we – together with you, I think, Mr Barnier – have been disappointed with the lack of progress in the negotiations. We have been disappointed with the UK’s continued and final refusal to extend the transition period to avoid the risk of a cliff edge in January and to ensure full and effective implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement on which future relations will be built, but we respect this choice. Monday’s political momentum and the decision to intensify talks in July is good news in this context. So now there is a physical space, and I personally believe also political space to finalise the process, but I also want to emphasise that what is at stake is the quality of our future relationship. The benefits of a single market cannot be reconstructed within even the most generous free trade agreement. Equivalence and voluntary regulatory cooperation on financial services cannot be put into a free trade agreement.  Let me finish by saying that London will continue as an important global financial centre. But at the same time it would greatly benefit from growing financial and capital markets in the European Union. So the best choice for completing the negotiations is to follow the path of a long-term cooperative strategy.

name: Gheorghe Falcă
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, colleagues, for me, Brexit was a mistake. Instead, the agreement may correct it by mistake. For four years, we have shown that we are part of the solution in this relationship and we are waiting to see solutions from the UK as well. For four years, we have been trying to find the compromise zone, but for four years, we have been guaranteeing to the citizens of the European Union in the UK that we will be there for them, and with this resolution we are saying, once again, that our values will be defended, and that all that means the rights of citizens, both of the Europeans in the UK and of the UK in Europe, will be guaranteed by us. Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Good luck with what the next four months mean.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is now more than four and a half months ago since the United Kingdom decided to leave our European Union.  From the very beginning, we in Parliament’s UK Coordination Group followed the negotiations for a new partnership thoroughly and sought to ensure a strong political consensus. We have closely been in touch with our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, whom I would like to thank personally for the excellent cooperation. I also would like to thank Maroš Šefčovič, and we will all be seeing each other again in about half an hour’s time for the next meeting of the UK Coordination Group. This report incorporates the opinions of no less than 17 committees. This is unprecedented, and it delivers a clear and strong message of unity. That’s why I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Kati Piri and Christophe Hansen, for their tireless work, but also the Chairs and the rapporteurs of all the opinion-giving committees. Yes, indeed, the high-level conference decided that new momentum is required for the negotiations. The EU is ready to intensify the talks in July to create the most conducive solutions for concluding an agreement soon. This should be in the interest of both sides.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, most Members have referred to the Brexit negotiations and I therefore think there has been a clear message. In this regard, I would like to join in appreciating the great work that Mr Barnier is doing and — as many of you have said - obviously we must be behind him in these negotiations, because we are aware that you are at a fundamental moment.  But I would also like to refer to the European Council. Ladies and gentlemen, time is pressing. On the street, people are clear about it. And this Parliament, too. I hope that the few reluctant governments in the Council will also understand this and reach an agreement in July, at the latest. We cannot go on holiday without activating the recovery plan and agree on the budget so that it can start implementing as soon as January. The amount proposed by the Commission, EUR 750 billion, is the minimum. Same as the amount of $500 billion for subsidies. All international agencies warn us that it is not time to spare efforts but to invest to revive the economy. Even our fellow conservatives and liberals who in 2008 advocated austerity now recognize that it would be a big mistake. All right, because rectifying is wise, and now it's time to row them all in the same direction. We can build on this momentum to transform our economies and adapt them to the new digital context and environmental emergency and ensure a fairer society, with stronger public policies. The route is clear: invest in ecological and digital transition to modernize our economies. Governments in the Council now need to have vision and courage, because where there is no vision the people suffer. This Parliament has the vision, and we are not going to give in. Because we can't afford it and because citizenship wouldn't allow it. That is why we are not going to accept a bad agreement in the Council. And also because we have to continue to insist on Parliament's role in these decisions. I am referring to key issues such as the management of the European Next Generation EU Recovery Instrument. No crisis can be an excuse to undermine democracy. On the contrary, more democracy and more accountability are required to resolve it. And so the only conditionality that must be imposed on the recovery plan is respect for the rule of law. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to know how to combine our objectives and principles with the reality of the facts. We cannot go from naive in this increasingly complex world in which former partners seem to have lost faith in multilateralism and cooperation. Firmness, principles and vision. It is more important than ever that we defend a strong Union, capable of marking the course.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for the first time, I believe that this week there will be a European Council whose conclusions we already know. There will be no agreement on the so-called Recovery Plan and there will probably be a clash between the Member States that we have already seen and anticipated in recent days. This is once again proof of the inefficiency and inadequacy of the European institutions in responding to the crisis. Let us de-develop the Commission's proposal, which is already a highly inadequate proposal. We are talking about EUR 400 billion in subsidies as well, and three quarters of this money will not arrive until 2023, that is, 3 years after this crisis has broken out, when companies have already broken their job. I believe that, once again, this is proof of how the decision-making process within the European Union is not suitable for responding to citizens and businesses and, moreover, this effort, this money would be given in exchange for new European taxes, taxes that will be levied on businesses, about seventy thousand companies within the European Union, and therefore not just multinationals. , and they will weigh on consumption, because of course companies will turn them back on consumption.  Let me conclude with a statement, with one consideration: I would not like this plan, as in 2012 was the ESA plan, to be a plan to convert industries in some countries with money from other countries. It was with the ESA with the banks of France and Germany, and this is likely to be the case with German and other industry.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, let’s be honest. No one really expects anything to happen at this European Council with regard to the recovery plan. We all think there will be some haggling and insisting on own positions, and afterwards everyone will go to the national press and say how well they have defended the national interest. Even the President of the European Council gave up on any outcome even before the summit had started. It’s quite shameful really that, when our Heads of State and Government come together, no one expects anything much to happen. Wouldn’t it be great though if, for once, the expectations of Europeans were over—fulfilled, if just once we didn’t wait until things were too late and until the mood was already really bad. We have an unforeseen crisis in the EU, and we all know that we need to act urgently in order to mitigate the economic impact. The EU as a whole needs to have, and provide, funds for this. The funds need to be targeted into the economy that we want to have tomorrow, not the one that puts profit over planet and people. A major effort is needed, but the benefits are great, especially if we link the investments to the challenges that we anyway have to face, namely the climate crisis, biodiversity loss, social inequality and digitalisation. Imagine if, for once, governments could ditch the drama and go for bold and for courageous. It would be worthwhile because, in the end, it is in the national interest of every single Member State to have a strong European Union for their citizens and for their economy. Our union is not a zero-sum game. It is the boat in which we are all sitting together. We fail together or we win together. So let’s make sure that we make a win for the future of the European Union.

name: Derk Jan Eppink
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the fight over the recovery fund is like a poker game in the dark casino. The EU likes to rely on European values. But what we are seeing is a mixture of corruption and blackmail. Countries of southern Europe are bought, countries in Central and Eastern Europe are bribed and countries in northern Europe are extorted!  So it is not about COVID-19, but about distributing a lot of money from Brussels. This means more power for the Commission, a higher EU budget and new European taxes. That is the purpose of the recovery fund. There is a long ratification process and somewhere along the way there is someone with the hammer. I imagine the British are happy that they don't have to go through this. I am therefore astoned by the European Parliament's resolution on Brexit. It reads like a list of demands, as an ultimatum, to a country that pulled "Europe" out of the mud twice last century. If it wasn't for the British, we wouldn't be here! Where we would have been, everyone has to fill in. The resolution exudes revanchism. The British should be punished for leaving the EU. But that was based on a democratic statement, ladies and gentlemen. The EU sees itself as a benchmark for the world, as a great moral power. But the EU is often a pedek among the big boys. Without strategic insight.  The Balkans are warmly welcomed at the entrance. The British get a cold shower at the exit. Ladies and gentlemen, resolutions without insight produce politics without a view!

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the meantime, there is a feeling that, after every meeting that takes place between the United Kingdom and the European Union, the contradictions are becoming bigger rather than smaller, and that a good agreement is becoming increasingly distant. This is by no means a criticism of michel Barnier's excellent work, which I greatly appreciate, but an analysis of the current situation, which, because of the British position – I would like to stress the British position – only allows the conclusion that we will see either a bad deal or a hard economic Brexit at the end of the year. I would like to say here, on behalf of the Left, that an agreement that opens the door to social dumping, environmental dumping, tax dumping or which contributes the security of private data to the fair is completely unacceptable to us. However, the Johnson government wants such an agreement. That is not an option for us, and I hope that this is not a real option for anyone in this House. That is why it is now time to consider an emergency plan to protect the regions and sectors particularly affected by Brexit, in order to provide the hundreds of thousands of workers and businesses with the necessary protection. And on the Council, people are still waiting for a clear signal of solidarity and unity. Next Generation EU is so far more of a bet on the future than actually a generational contract. The clearest signal would be to abandon and abandon the Stability and Growth Pact once and for all, which in the future will only lead to further cuts in public services and social security or to further privatisations. On the other hand, we need public investment, tax loopholes must be closed, tax justice must be achieved. The ECB should be able to directly support public finances, and super-rich speculators and companies should play their fair share of reconstruction by introducing a comprehensive financial transaction tax, a strong digital tax, and a wealth levy. That would be a signal of solidarity that Europe is waiting for.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, while the situation seems to be stabilizing on the health crisis, the economic challenges remain major. For me, we now have two options: either we negotiate at national level to end the crisis, and then each Member State defends its interests, or we accept that the only solution is to build together. That is the logic of the stimulus package and the multi-year budget that we support. Because, yes, we have to be clear, we are not asking for the dusting of funds, we will have to target where the funds should be allocated. It will also be a matter of conditioning for reform, so that this European solidarity is the engine of a genuine joint recovery. However, I do not hide my concern from you. We are about to borrow 750 billion euros on the financial markets without knowing exactly how we are going to repay that money. Indeed, to envisage an increase in national contributions or a reduction in the funds allocated to future European policies would undermine the whole European project. Therefore, for us, only the rapid implementation of real own resources would strengthen the credibility of this recovery plan, but also ensure the sustainability of the European project. I do not hide from you that the proposal on the European multi-year budget is far less ambitious than we expected and the very existence of a recovery plan is not enough to compensate for the weakness of this proposal because even if it is a package, the objectives are still different. While the recovery plan will allow us to get back in the saddle, the new European budget will define our ability to cross the finish line.  Therefore, only an ambitious budget would provide a structural response to the many challenges we face and would determine our ability to assume both economic and strategic independence. It would finance major European projects such as the battery project or the hydrogen project. It would allow such projects to come into being.  Today, however, I am concerned because some programmes which aim to finance such essential projects as research, digital, the single market or defence remain too lowly funded. The same is true for social projects or for projects that concern young people, for example. So I will end by pointing out that my group will not support a European budget that continues to provide funding to European governments which, every day, turn their backs on our values and undermine democracy and the rule of law. This must stop and quickly.

name: Tiziana Beghin (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Recovery Fund is an instrument never seen before. With over EUR 750 billion, it is the very expression of a new era of solidarity in Europe, and for this we must thank the impetus of the Italian Government and the contribution of other states, such as Spain, French and Germany.  The forthcoming European Councils, if they have the courage to approve it, will make the history of the Union. We know that some governments will oppose it, but any resistance or compromise to the downside is unacceptable, because it takes up valuable time. As our Prime Minister Conte said today in the Houses, Italy is ready, and we hope that Europe will also be ready and approve the "Next Generation EU" as soon as possible. European citizens and businesses deserve these resources to be available now, we owe it to all those for whom every day can make a difference.  Ladies and gentlemen, solidarity has once again flowed through the veins of Europe. Now we just have to make sure it reaches his heart.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European People's Party has led and promoted in this Parliament and in the Commission the recovery plan with the greatest European aid to combat COVID-19, and we have done so with unity, solidarity and responsibility. Now it's your council's turn to live up to it. Time is pressing. It is at stake that many of those who have lowered their business shutters can lift them back up. To this end, the Governments of the Member States must act quickly and with responsibility.  European solidarity must be accompanied by ambitious national reforms, to make our economy more modern, competitive and sustainable; to make our national health systems more resilient; and to protect all families. To defend spaniards, to be patriotic is to digitize and re-industrialize Spain; is to know how to negotiate a CAP that makes the countryside an opportunity; is to revive the tourism sector. In short: create jobs, which is the best social policy. This is the real Europe, which defends the People's Party, the Spain we want.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the next European Council, the Heads of State or Government will finally have to give their opinion on the reconstruction plan presented by the European Commission. We expect them to reach a decision as soon as possible, but not just any decision, a decision that is equal to the crisis we are experiencing. As you know, our political group immediately welcomed the 'Next Generation EU'. For us, the Commission's plan is the minimum trade union or, if you like, a good starting point, and it has elements that deserve attention.  I will cite two for brevity. The first is the EUR 750 billion, a large part of which is not lost, in order to restart our small and medium-sized enterprises, to help our workers, to give a perspective to the people who have lost their jobs. Secondly, the possibility of common European debt, guaranteed by the Union's own resources, which are not, as some would have us believe, new taxes for the citizens, but the possibility of making those who have not paid taxes so far pay the cost of the crisis as much as they should have paid, or paid them where they wanted – I am thinking of the multinationals – or to finally combat environmental dumping on our products. People are asking for help at every latitude. This emergency has affected everywhere in Europe, but it has struck differently. However, do not think of the so-called frugal states that this is a good reason to leave the countries most affected and therefore the most fragile to their fate. Here we all save together. Value chains are integrated, our economies too interdependent and, if even the smallest state in Europe collapses, the whole of the internal market collapses, and the productive realities of countries that today feel invulnerable will also suffer. It is not just solidarity and mutual convenience. Therefore, in view of what we have been through in these difficult months of lockdown and the road ahead for a recovery that is slower than we think, I would like to reiterate from this House an appeal to the Council not to weaken or slow down the launch of this recovery plan. Only by acting in good time and with adequate resources will we be able to get back on our toes. Parliament is ready.

name: Nathalie Loiseau (Renew).
text: Madam President, four months is the time we have left to reach a partnership agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union; It's short. It is short, but it is possible. I am sure that, like the European peoples we represent here, the British people want us to keep strong and mutually beneficial ties, that they want the planet to be preserved tomorrow and today, the rights of workers to be protected, the health and food security of all to be the focus of attention. I have no doubt that the British people are committed to the protection of their personal data, I know, because they keep saying it, that British companies as well as European companies hope to be able to continue their industrial cooperation and their exchanges, because that is in everyone's interest. What we are going to vote on tomorrow is a strong political signal. The signal that we are defending the interests of all Europeans, who elected us and who rely on us: our farmers, our fishermen, our businesses, our citizens. A strong signal of unity from the representatives of the European peoples on what forms the basis of a just and balanced agreement, the one that we will have to ratify, since on this side of the Channel, it is our Parliament that will have the final say. No one wants to add the negative consequences of a lack of agreement to that of the COVID-19 pandemic, no one is responsible for the epidemic we are experiencing, but we have a common responsibility to avoid adding the crisis to the crisis. We have little time, but we have a path, one that has been drawn up by the political declaration that Europeans and the British have negotiated together, signed together and which, alone, can prevent us from wasting precious time. We will vote tomorrow and tomorrow will be June 18, the anniversary of General de Gaulle's call from London when we were united to fight together. I ask our British friends, let us live up to this common destiny, this community of values that has made us great, let us be ambitious together.

name: Laura Huhtasaari (ID).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Great Britain: they just saved around EUR 80 billion because they were late on the corona package. So nobody in Britain would even dare admit voting against Brexit. The European Commission’s proposal for a recovery fund is another step towards a centralised debt union. This proposal is illegal, according to Article 125. The Commission also wants EU own sources of taxation passed by the Member States. In the EU a large part of its economic problems would be reduced if the monetary union, the euro, were dismantled. According to a study, Finnish exports would be 40% higher in their own currency. I want my money back.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I am saddened when I see that the negotiations are stalling. The EU and the UK have all the prerequisites to strike a bargain on the second-best trade and partnership agreement in the world. Never before has there been a situation where negotiating partners’ premises and interests are so aligned and so close to one another. The agreement on the new relationship between the EU and the UK must acknowledge our common history, geographical proximity and the other connections we have between the Brits and the EU. Anything but a comprehensive and indivisible agreement that provides robust level-playing-field guarantees, both to the UK and the EU, would be a historical failure. What must be achieved is the second-best trade and partnership agreement in the world: an agreement so good that the only better deal is EU membership itself.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The Commission's proposal for the MFF and the Reconstruction Fund, as a joint support package for investment in Member States, provides a good basis for negotiations at the Council. Secondly, however, efficient and effective negotiations are necessary, because the economic and social reality in all Member States, despite their mobilisation of huge public aid, will nevertheless deteriorate, and in the second quarter in some countries we can expect up to a 20% fall in GDP. Thirdly, the financial strengthening of cohesion policy and the CAP proposed by the Commission should be applauded, as these are the two most effective EU policies, and the CAP and farmers have ensured food security for 500 million EU consumers during the pandemic. Fourthly and finally, the effectiveness of the use of such huge EU funds will be determined by the flexibility of their use, as well as by their ability to address the real economic problems of the countries, and not only on digital or climate issues.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, time is running out: five months. The relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union cannot be a mere free trade agreement. There are opportunities for a balance between rights and obligations in which we have to be clear that the priority is the protection of citizens and strategic activities. Johnson tries to make commitments, and he's doing it by threatening not to agree. It's important that there is. Millions of citizens expect it: they live, work in the UK, their rights and their activities will depend on these future relationships. Learning Brexit and the reconstruction plan we make together must be a way to become a project for which citizens are willing to bet decisively. There are positive aspects to this Parliament's recommendations: environmental standards, avoiding dumping, protecting the primary sector or the citizenship rights that we have managed to expressly include; but we also see inadequacies. We cannot move forward on a European project if we are not an international independent actor. In these recommendations we run the risk of ending up subordinate to Johnson's international policy, that is, Trump's agenda. It's time to bet on a way of being and being in the world. That way, we'll have a future, too.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: – Madam President, let’s be pragmatic and sensible. The British Nation is a much-loved and respected member of the European Family, and it will always be for generations to come. They no longer are a member of the EU. That is why we have to come to an agreement with our close neighbour and old friend. After four rounds of unsuccessful negotiations, we must conclude that the strategy has not worked so far. Circumstances have changed. We are looking at a huge economic crisis – the COVID-19 crisis. We cannot afford a no-deal in the current situation. A divorce is painful for all parties involved. There is a price to pay on both sides. We have to think about the next generation. This is not a moral issue, but a situation in need of a sensible approach. When circumstances change, strategies have to change as well. Let’s not aim for the ultimate deal but for the best one possible at this moment. Think about the generations to come in Britain and in the EU. Let’s be pragmatic, and let’s be sensible.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – Madam President, here we go again. Six months away from another Brexit cliff edge and, again, we have to conclude that no substantial progress has been made at all. Somehow ‘get Brexit done’ became ‘get nothing done’, and actually we have moved backwards, with Boris Johnson seeming to have forgotten about the political declaration that he himself agreed and signed last year; forgotten about the joint declaration that provides a basis, a foundation, for an ambitious partnership between the UK and the EU, founded on a level playing field. We said it many times: Brexit is a lose-lose situation. It’s bad for both the UK and the EU, but at least with a properly organised exit, we can mitigate some of those negative effects a little. Citizens and companies have a right to certainty, clarity and reassurance about their future. I’m afraid to say that it seems like we’re running out of time and options. So maybe we need to get creative. Maybe, Michel Barnier, you could invite Marcus Rashford to the next negotiating round. He at least seems like someone who gets something done in the UK these days.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In the debate on a trade agreement with the United Kingdom, it is often said that let us make an agreement like CETA, the agreement with Canada! Boris Johnson has said that again.  This is the typical perception, the misperception that a thing always means the same thing. In the negotiations with Canada, there were two partners who were far apart, who moved towards each other and reached agreement in certain areas. That was a great success. We have a common situation with the United Kingdom, a common market, and now we want to diverge, and if we go in the direction of the Canada agreement, that is a bad deal. And we do not need a bad deal, we need a good deal in the interests of economic relations and in the interests of jobs and citizens. That is why I can only encourage the Council, which will meet on 19 June, not to agree to a bad deal, but to work to ensure that we really get a good deal. A bad deal means that economic growth is gone. Even the British have said that 4.6% will leave if we have a CETA deal, and boris Johnson should not be followed.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, a people has chosen, a country has left the European Union. It is now a reality, and Boris Johnson has just said it again, he wants to reach an agreement without delay. The choice of the British demonstrated that when the people want, the people can. He testified to his extraordinary ability to take responsibility for his choices beyond pressure and manipulation. This is also true for Boris Johnson. Refusing to say so, he lied to the prophets of doom predicting London's ten wounds on his country, should Brexit be confirmed. Better yet, it is the European Union today that is concerned about competition in all areas of Britain, finally free of its shackles. While it is certain that a fair deal is necessary, it is also understandable that Boris Johnson will use his hands-free, as he says, to tackle the evils that his country is going through, the same as ours. When it comes to immigration, for example, more ideological muzzles, only foreigners guaranteed a job paid more than 30,000 pounds (35,000 euros) a year will be able to knock on the door of the country to work. Not all problems, of course, will be solved with a magical Brexit. France is not Great Britain either, but the direction is the right one, that of a country neither submissive, but, friend of Europe, favouring its own without isolating itself from others, identity preserved and not programmed dilution, the choice of cooperation against that of suggestion, the choice of Europe of nations against that proposed by the EU of cold and contemptuous technocrats so well embodied.

name: Sergey Lagodinsky (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, they ask us why we are doing this; they ask us why we stand united and invest so much time in negotiating something that the British government has rejected and ignored again and again. The answer is: we are doing it for our common European future. Maybe not next year, maybe the year after that, maybe later, but this future will come. We are doing it for our common values and interests – values that don’t depend on the signature as a member of the EU: liberal democracy, climate policy, women’s and minority rights, human rights. These are values that we share with each other, regardless of membership of the EU. We are doing it for Europeans on both sides of the Channel, for those who share families, jobs, love stories, biographies. We are doing this for their rights. We are doing this for you, our British friends: British citizens who believe in the wisdom of the EU much more than you believe in the wisdom of your Brexiteer government. Because if they go low, we aim high, and we aim high with this resolution. We won’t ever see Britain as a third country and we will never see British citizens as citizens of a third country. To paraphrase a famous Brit: a Brexit with a deal is the worst form of future for Great Britain, except for all other forms of Brexit. This resolution is our last attempt to prevent the worst. The ball is in your court, Mr Johnson.

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, very difficult negotiations are beginning on a financial response which, however significant, is likely to remain far below expectations, burdened with conditionality, all to be discovered and, above all, belated. Crumbs in 2020, little more than crumbs in 2021. By the time the bulk of the funding comes, too many businesses in too many sectors, from the service sector to tourism and industry, will have already closed down and too many people will be out of work. Flexibility on State aid increases imbalances in the internal market and only the ECB's purchases, as long as they last, really seem to respond to the crisis. Then some countries will decide to activate the ESA, but perhaps that is the aim. Meanwhile, instead of worrying about this, continue with the perverse ideology of the Green Deal, imposing new burdens on businesses and citizens on new lifestyles. You have rediscovered the word solidarity, we are pleased about it, but you have forgotten the word responsibility.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today is perhaps the last chance to influence the outcome of the negotiations. I very much welcome the clear words that we have been able to find together on social protection, environmental protection, citizens' rights and also the situation on the island of Ireland. I would like to make it quite clear, also to the negotiator: thank you for your work!  There will be no reduction in the level playing fields, i.e. the level playing conditions and standards, with the left. This also applies to trade issues. Perhaps, however, I also have to ask ourselves – thanks also to the rapporteurs for their work – why we have not learned together from the Corona crisis and the climate crisis and brought a new way of thinking into the whole negotiations. The section on trade relations does not protect health services from market forces, but follows traditional neoliberal paths. The proposals for cooperation do not give priority to disarmament and the fight against poverty, and the concrete needs of the people, citizens' rights and citizens' rights remain unresolved.  In other words, it is difficult for us to vote in favour of this result, so to speak, without conditions, and I therefore believe and hope that our group's amendments will still be approved tomorrow.

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Madam President, Scotland wanted to remain in the Union, but their voice has been silenced in the negotiations, and now they’re out with the rest of the UK. Across history, we have seen European borders changing by invasions and displacements of people, but when coercion is the base of stability, these only bridge the demise of Europe. The only thing that Europe has not tried is the only thing that we can offer to our citizens and to the world: a better kind of freedom, based on democracy and consent. For us to be credible for Scots to return, Europe needs to address urgently the issue of internal enlargement. Otherwise, the Union will be doomed, like all European empires, for the same reason: for repressing the positive power of diversity. Self—determination of peoples is not a right that we don’t know how to deal with; rather, it is the moral compass that will save us from our blind spots and illusions. To my very dear friends in Scotland, I say: we are eager to welcome you back in the EU.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – (start of the speech with the microphone off) Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Council, since so many colleagues have talked about Brexit and the negotiations for partnership with the United Kingdom, let me talk about the other very important point of this Council, which is precisely the issue of the recovery plan. It is essential that we, as Parliament, give full support to the Commission in this plan because it provides for, for the first time, the issue of European bonds, because it provides for a recovery based on subsidies and loans, because it provides for giving priority to those who are the european Union's major objectives for this decade, such as digitisation and, of course, the green deal. We must also regret what has happened with the multiannual financial framework where there are still very serious reductions. I would therefore like to appeal here to the Council, the European Council and the Member States, to the frugals, to those who displease them and to all those who have put some reticence to this plan of the European Commission. This is the following: if your concern is future generations, then be on the side of the Commission's plan, the plan put forward by President von der Leyen. This is what future generations expect of all of you.

name: Javier Moreno Sánchez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, three messages in one minute. Parliament and the Commission have already complied with the submission of ambitious proposals. It is now up to the Council to reach an agreement to rebuild Europe and to get the funds to citizens, businesses, the regions that need them most as soon as possible. The time has also come to introduce new Union own resources to re-reimburse the debt. Second message, to the European People's Party and its leader Manfred Weber: don't worry, the Spanish government will present an ambitious recovery plan that leaves no one behind. The Socialists will not accept the plans of the past. We don't want any disguised conditionality or austerity. And finally, you and your allies would ask you not to make a mistake. This House is not an annex to the Congress of Deputies. Do not use this House as a trench to attack and overthrow the government of Pedro Sánchez. Defend Spanish citizens and not the 'frugales strategy'. Learn to be patriotic too when you're in opposition, please.

name: Jessica Stegrud (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Then we'll be right here again. Once again, it is time for Swedish taxpayers to save economically mismanaged states and a monetary union we who voted against. You are talking about solidarity, about community and about helping, about a future for future generations. But solidarity cannot be based on one tearing and the other wasting. Had you assumed your responsibilities, you would now have called for major reforms. Instead, you take the opportunity, in the shadow of the corona, to make the growing debt burden common and to move even more power to the EU. The rescue package will not help, it will not solve structural errors, will not increase competitiveness or create long-term growth. Nor will it promote fragile cohesion. It shifts the problems to the future and shifts the burden onto our children and grandchildren.  This is not solidarity, it is irresponsibility. You call it 'next generation Europe'. I call it 'we don't care about next generation EU'.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, looking at Brexit, we find that it seems to have reached the stage of a confrontation. In reality, we need a fair agreement between the two parties. The fact that no progress has been made lately shows us that intervention at the level of the Heads of State and Government is needed. It is good, I think, for Mrs Merkel, the President of France and Boris Johnson to have a discussion to unlock.  It is clear that the European Union cannot be asked to abandon the criteria of the single market, nor can the British be asked to accept exactly the reasons why they left the European Union. I therefore warn that the risk of a lack of agreement is that each Member State will make separate agreements with the United Kingdom.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this European Council is faced with two major challenges.  First challenge: to find a political agreement that will enable a European response to the crisis and has a good proposal on the table. The European Parliament was demanding: it asked for the revision of the multiannual budget proposal, a recovery fund to be added to the European Union budget, mutualisation of responsibilities, eurobonds, more subsidies than loans, increasing and diversifying own resources as a source of funding for the European Union budget.  He asked for a European response. These principles are an integral part of the Commission's proposal.  Second challenge: to find a political agreement on the future of the European Union budget and has a bad proposal for the second period of the framework. The decision on one and the other is urgent. The European Parliament has been demanding and will not fail to be. We also hope that the Council will be up to it.

name: Tomas Tobé (PPE).
text: – . Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul What Europe needs now is to come together and agree on a multi-annual budget and a recovery package. The Swedish Moderates want to strengthen European cooperation, but believe that it must be done responsibly. If we are to now raise a historically high loan-to-note joint, we cannot send the bill to future generations. That's why we want to make demands for a much tougher repayment plan. It is not reasonable for the repayment to begin in 2028 and continue for another 30 years.  We need to stick to the call for a rule of law so that we use European funds properly. Finally, no matter where the compromise goes: it is not subsidies or loans or, for that matter, higher taxes that strengthen our competitiveness, but it is reform. Europe needs reforms. Then Europe will also become stronger.

name: Петър Витанов (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is clear that the negotiations held so far do not bring the necessary progress. The British side takes the maximalist approach that allows it to take full advantage of the single market without being bound by any obligations. And we regret to note that the free movement of persons will not be continued and will be suspended after the transition period.  Concerns about the rights of European Union citizens are becoming even greater because I observe that in the course of the negotiations Britain is adopting national legislation that is in the direction of limiting these rights. Moreover, the replacement legislation is moving faster than the negotiations themselves.  I believe that, at increased risk of no agreement, the European Union must push for a future partnership with ambitious provisions on the movement of people based on full reciprocity and non-discrimination and guarantee all the rights of citizens of the European Union.

name: Radosław Sikorski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as deputy Chair of the EU-UK Friendship Group, I would of course like for there to be a deal, but I’m beginning to despair. Our red line and our politics is that we want to preserve the integrity of the single market. The British prime minister has communicated to us that Britain cannot accept a deal which puts Britain under the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice or that binds the House of Commons in any way in future in determining Britain’s commercial arrangements. That seems to me to make a deal impossible, because the nature of a treaty, any treaty, is that you will do in future what the treaty says, and not as you please. And, therefore, our red lines don’t seem to touch at any point.  Therefore, I would urge you to stop demanding the impossible from our negotiators and start preparing for what is regrettable but seems to be inevitable, which is a very hard Brexit indeed.

name: José Manuel García-Margallo y Marfil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, principle of equal opportunities, fair competition; this basic principle has been clamorably unknown by the tax agreement between the United Kingdom and Spain, which seems to allow the continuation of a tax regime that taxes profits obtained within the Rock, but not those obtained outside, and which taxes gambling on a symbolic tax. From these privileges there are consequences that speak for themselves: thirty thousand offshore companies in Gibraltar and 60% of the online game controlled by Gibraltar. Gibraltar now has the third per capita income in the world, while the adjacent Campo de Gibraltar has an income that is six times lower, a greater difference than that between the United States and Mexico. We have denounced this regime here on as many occasions as we have had, because it is contrary to the Monti tax code and is contrary to the State aid code. The Spanish Government will be able to ignore this situation, but the European Union cannot tolerate it, and that must make it clear in the forthcoming negotiations. It would be good if in these negotiations we were all forced to comply with international decolonisation legality, as a union of law that we are.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, taking the opportunity to present the European Council and the European Commission and by being in the European Parliament, this powerful force of the peoples of Europe, I would like, with all the strength of my soul, to denounce an issue which is purely European and which will become a tragic issue for the European Union, which are the threats , Turkey's blackmail and expansionist aggressive policies against two Member States of the European Union, Greece and Cyprus. Turkey's violations in Cyprus, the violations in Greece, the illegal Turkish-Libyan Memorandum, are not cases concerning Cyprus but concern the whole of the European Union. The tolerance of the European Union, which continues to finance this illegal blackmail country affecting two Member States of the European Union to this day, has dethroned Turkey. It is not understood, while illegally located in the Cypriot EEZ and violating Greece's airspace and maritime borders, that this funding should continue. I appeal to the European Union and to the powerful Member States of the European Union to defend the European Union's maritime borders in the same way that they defend the European Union's borders against illegal immigrants and, if necessary, to send even their navy to defend the European Union's maritime borders located in Cyprus and Greece.

name: Jörgen Warborn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We need as close a relationship with the UK as possible. They remain our partner, our allies and our friend. Our geographical proximity and deep trade relations make it impossible to celebrate New Year 2021 without an agreement in place. Boris Johnson now wants Britain to be the best in Europe at business. They will be sharp competitors to the EU on the fight for jobs and investment.  This must get Europe to tag and set even higher targets for our jobs and our growth. Like Britain, we need to put our full focus on cutting red tape and creating better conditions for our European export companies and small businesses. It is unfortunate that the already time-limited negotiations are now coinciding with the Covid-19 pandemic. I have to say that it would, of course, be a good thing to extend the negotiating period, but I welcome the fact that new constructive approaches are now being made in the run-up to this summer's negotiations. The EU and the UK need each other. Let us work together for a better business environment.

name: Peter van Dalen (PPE).
text: Mr President, a good trade agreement is important for both parties. But what do we see? The UK has started backtracking. They are going to renegotia ned already agreed.  I think that is a real detract from the political statement that Mr Johnson also signed. So the question is: does the British Government want an agreement? British business wants it. The Confederation of British Industry, the overarching British business community, knows very well that our single market is essential. They realise that in the case of a no deal on both sides of the Channel, there will be many losers. And the already rapidly shrinking British economy cannot possibly have that. I want an agreement with fair agreements on fisheries, access for our fishermen to the whole north sea, good agreements on the joint management of fish stocks. And if these fisheries agreements do not come in, then no trade agreement!

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Šefčovič, the low expectations cultivated in the run-up to the European Council undermine the climate of optimism and confidence that our citizens and economies need. In my country Greece, after losing 25% of Gross Domestic Product during the economic crisis, we are now facing a deep recession if the European Union does not act immediately. That is why it is necessary for the European Council to seize the opportunity and send the markets a clear message of confidence, to show that the European Union is ready to guarantee the future of its generation. The Recovery Fund, in conjunction with the Community budget, can support high-quality primary production, electricity from renewable sources combined with jobs in the circular economy, digitisation of the public sector and its interconnection with small and medium-sized enterprises that are now fighting to reopen. Ladies and gentlemen, the money from grants and loans must be given so that our economies can be transformed. Jobs must be created for our generation and for the next generation.

name: Kati Piri
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I want to thank my colleagues for their contribution to this debate and for their continued support. Allow me also to say a special thanks to my colleague, co—rapporteur Christophe Hansen, and all the shadow rapporteurs who worked on this file. And of course, not to be forgotten, my gratitude also goes to Michel Barnier and his team for their full engagement with this House. We wish you patience and a good dose of humour in the coming weeks ahead. As you have all clearly underlined, what we need with this deal are not short-term answers but a long-term vision, given the unprecedented challenges we are confronted with. If the UK Government does not immediately and radically change its approach to these negotiations, there is no way to reach any sort of comprehensive partnership before the end of the transition period. To be honest, under the current circumstances, I believe we must also prepare ourselves for a no—deal scenario. Last week’s data from the UK Office for National Statistics and the Organisation for Economic Co—operation and Development show clearly the economic impact of the coronavirus crisis. It is time to turn the narrative to make the pandemic the reason for success and not the excuse for failure. That would be a disaster for citizens on both sides of the Channel. We need a deal, and we can have a deal that is good for all of us. A no-deal is neither rational nor responsible. The next weeks are the moment of truth in many regards. The time has come for responsibility and courage. Citizens and the business community need certainty. They need predictability. The EU is ready to play its role and to fulfil their needs and their legitimate aspirations.

name: Christophe Hansen
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you, and I say to colleagues: thank you for all the contributions in this very long debate today. I wish I could respond to each and every one of your remarks, but given the time restrictions, I want to come back to the essentials, namely the many remarks I heard on the ‘level playing field’. My father, who doesn’t speak English, always asks me: ‘when I hear you speaking about Brexit on the radio, why do you always insist on this level playing field? What does that even mean?’ So I told him, because we are both big cycling fans: ‘imagine the Tour de France, all cyclists competing with a common race bike, except for Chris Froome with his Sky Team riding with E-bikes. Do you believe this would allow for a fair competition?’ The answer was of course, ‘no, this is not what we want’. We want fair competition and fair play is what every good sportsman should aim for in a competition. This Parliament wants the closest possible cooperation with the United Kingdom. This is in everyone’s best interest. We will remain constructive and will be ready to discuss the fair and balanced compromises that will hopefully emerge in the coming weeks here in Brussels and in London. Of course, it takes two to tango, as the Commission President earlier said. And, you have to be aware, this Parliament will be ready for this last dance.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, dear esteemed colleague who negotiates for the EU, Michel Barnier, first a couple of remarks on the issue which was raised by Ms García Pérez, Ms Keller and Mr Cioloş, and this is of course the videoconference of the European Council this Friday and our proposal on MFF and Next Generation EU.  First and foremost, I would like to thank you for your support because it’s very important for our discussions with the European Member States, and also with the public, and I really would like to reassure you that we are not losing any minute from the time between now and what I hope will be a very important historic, unprecedented and ambitious deal on both the MFF and Next Generation EU in July.
