We are not losing any minute because we are talking to the governments at different levels, we are engaging with the citizens, and I personally approached all representatives of the national parliaments on Tuesday in the format of COSAC when I was explaining to them the construction architecture of the proposal and the importance of national parliaments and the European Parliament’s approval ratification in the end.  Of course, for us solidarity is a must, and I believe that this European Council videoconference will allow us to narrow the differences which are still there on the table, and to prepare the ground well, what I believe will be a decisive move forward, an agreement in July. On the second topic which was raised by the rest of the honourable Members, I would just like to inform you about how we are going to implement the Withdrawal Agreement. As you know, I am representing the European Union in this joint committee with Michael Gove, who is representing the British Government. And here we are talking about the agreement which was approved, signed and ratified by this Parliament and by the UK Parliament, and once there was a clear statement by Michael Gove that there will not be any extension of the transitional period, I did the same. And what I heard from our rapporteurs, Ms Piri and Mr Hansen, but also from Mr McAllister was that we need to accelerate our work and to make sure that the Withdrawal Agreement is properly implemented.  I’m very glad to report that the discussion of the joint committee was in a very positive atmosphere and that we could state that there is good progress in the area of the financial provisions, on the Protocol on Gibraltar, on the Protocol on the sovereign base areas of the UK in Cyprus and also on citizens’ rights where I know how important this issue is for the European Parliament and for our citizens and I believe we will be able to resolve our differences definitely before the end of the year. What is the most challenging issue is of course the application of the Protocol on Ireland and Northern Ireland, and here I was very clear and I made it very clear also to the UK delegations that what we need is some more operation, because we understand the aspiration, which has already presented to us. But for us, it’s very important to have very concrete responses on how the UK is going to implement the VAT regime, excise and customs obligations, which are clearly stated in the Withdrawal Agreement. I’m glad that the response I got from Michael Gove was that we will work very hard over the summer, that we will have another specialised committee session on the Irish Protocol in July, and we will come back overall what I believe will be progress in early September. So there is a lot of work, but I believe that when it comes to the Withdrawal Agreement, both sides are realising that the proper implementation is the key to trust-building, to confidence-building which we need for the good future relationship between European Union and the United Kingdom.  And how will this future relationship look? If you allow, Madam President, I will pass the floor to Michel Barnier because he’s negotiating day and night with our UK colleagues and he will be able to give you the best picture.

name: Michel Barnier
text: head of the task force for relations with the United Kingdom. Madam President, good evening to each and every one of you and thank you to Maroo for the good cooperation between us. I would like to say a few words at his side on the issue of this very complex, extraordinary Brexit negotiation. First of all, thank your Parliament, Madam President, the 17 committees that have committed themselves and their rapporteurs. As David McAllister said, this is the first time, and I think it is time, and so I would like to thank Kati Piri and Christophe Hansen very warmly for the rather complicated synthesis work they have done and congratulate them on it.  We need the vigilance, the determination of the European Parliament in this period. It is this determination that your President David Sassoli expressed on Monday at the high-level conference organised with the Chair of the Committee, Ursula von der Leyen, Charles Michel, the President of the European Council, yourself, and Boris Johnson. And then, I think it was Nathalie Loiseau who said it, you will have the last word, once again, when we have, I hope, reached an agreement with the United Kingdom.  As we have just pointed out, we have taken note of the negative position of the British Government to possibly extend, as we did, as we still have the possibility until 30 June, this transition period, which is in fact the period of negotiation. And so this puts us in the middle of the ford: there are four months of negotiations behind us, there are only four months of negotiations before us, Kati Piri said 204 days earlier.  So it's difficult. This remains possible, the time is very short and I share the sense of urgency expressed by Boris Johnson and that is why we have decided, with my counterpart, David Frost and his negotiating team, which is, like ours, very professional, to intensify in July, August and September, these negotiations, to have more concentrated discussions. , more focused, with the objective and the obligation for us, but you know that this is my rule, to have the same transparency with your Parliament, your coordination group, your committees and also with the 27 Member States on whose behalf we are negotiating. What are the next steps? One thing is clear, as the three presidents of the three institutions pointed out when they met Boris Johnson on Monday, what matters to us even before the process is a step forward on the merits.  It is up to the UK to choose what it wants and whether it wants a deal. As you said very well, Madam Minister Nikolina Brnjac, just now at the beginning of this session, it is the choice of the United Kingdom to want or not to want an agreement because the terms of an agreement are already known. We have approved them with Boris Johnson and every comma, every word has been negotiated bitterly in the political declaration to commit us to an ambitious and lasting partnership to which your Parliament is also attached.  Not only is there an unprecedented trade partnership, zero tariffs, zero quota on all goods - a first in the Union's commercial history - but with an agreement on fisheries, Mr Bellamy has pointed out, and with an agreement on the level playing field, which will deal with state aid, tax issues, but also social and environmental rights. As Christophe Hansen said at the time, an agreement on fair play, economic and social, and this agreement will also cover energy, transport, security and defence issues, and on the basis of this unprecedented offer, we also want the conditions for access to our market to be fair.  This political statement, these principles, we have made them our own in our mandate and our draft agreement published on March 18, and it is not open to negotiation. After four years of negotiations, we can see, ladies and gentlemen, what the strategy of the British Government is. First, he refused any discussion on important topics, defence, security, development. I interpreted this as the idea of focusing all the negotiation on economic issues alone and therefore on the defence of its economic interests.  And then, in this strategy, the United Kingdom seeks to negotiate, in certain areas, a status very close to membership of the single market, quasi-member of the single market of the customs union and Schengen without having any of the constraints or disciplines. This is what we call cherry picking, on rules of origin, on mutual recognition, financial services, professional qualifications, data flows or electricity exchanges. We will not accept not cherry picking.  The second part of the UK strategy is to reject all clear and strong commitments on level playing field in order to be able to keep the freedom to deviate from the current EU rules and to compete with the EU, some even say that this is the raison d'être of Brexit and we can see this strategy on data.  I know Parliament's very strong position on this issue, on financial services, on state aid, where the United Kingdom has so far given no indication of the future national framework for state aid, I also see it on food standards and, in this context, the United Kingdom has even wished to reopen the issue of geographical indications, which are clearly protected in the withdrawal agreement referred to by Maro-S.A.  All this is not compatible with the foundations of a lasting, ambitious agreement with a great country that will, in any event, remain our friend, our ally and our partner. And yet I remain convinced, ladies and gentlemen, that an agreement is possible for the long term, as Danuta Hubner has said. We have wanted this from the beginning and we want to give this negotiation every chance, as evidenced by this intensified process.  But, ladies and gentlemen, as you have set the direction for me in your resolution, we will not agree at all costs, that is what Bernd Lange said earlier. We will never sacrifice , I repeat the words of our President Ursula von der Leyen - the long-term economic and political interest of EU consumers and businesses for the benefit of the United Kingdom.  At the same time, we want to see tangible progress on the implementation of the withdrawal agreement referred to by Maro-S-F-ovic, both the guarantee of citizens' rights and, Madam President, this issue so important for peace in Ireland that is the proper application of the protocol. Finally, if our priority remains and will remain to reach an agreement, we also have the responsibility, as Mr Arimont and Mr Schiderwan said earlier, to prepare collectively for all possible scenarios, at the end of the year, in the event of an agreement or in case of disagreement. In any case, we have to prepare and we will prepare. I wanted to thank you for your confidence, the confidence you have in the European Commission's negotiating team, which is, never forget, your negotiating team. In the coming weeks, which are going to be decisive, we will have to demonstrate certain qualities. Ms. Piri asked me to be humorous; I recognize that I have some room for improvement, but it is important at my age to keep room for progress. The calmness to which Mr. Danielsson invited me, our patience; the calm and patience on my side are inexhaustible. Our firmness, which is clear and clear on the basis of principles to defend our consumers and our businesses. And finally our unity, which Parliament will give new evidence of today, of which I thank you.

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much, and I hope your reserves do not run out, Mr Barnier, so good luck with the negotiations.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I’ll first say a few words regarding negotiations on a new partnership with the UK, to which many of you devoted your comments. With the adoption of your recommendation, our negotiator should be in a better position to engage in the very intense phase of negotiating that is coming, as it is clear for both our institutions that progress in the partnership negotiations had to go hand in hand with progress in the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement. This means that we will have to remain vigilant as regards, first and foremost, the preservation of citizens’ rights, be it during the transition period or under whatever future relationship with the United Kingdom. But our vigilance will have to be no less thorough when considering the intended economic partnership, where strong, safeguarded and robust governance will be called for to protect the integrity of the EU single market and the competitive position of EU firms. We will therefore count on your cooperation in this respect as well. In negotiation with the UK on our future relationship and partnership, our common efforts and commonality of purpose will provide the support required by our negotiator and help ensure an outcome to the benefit of the Union and its citizens. Coming back to the MFF and recovery, the President of the European Council wants to pave the way for a deal by providing the leaders with an opportunity to discuss the MFF and the recovery package. Therefore, the Friday meeting will be an orientation debate, during which the leaders will have the opportunity to explain how they see the Commission’s new proposals and whether the overall package meets their expectations. This debate will inform the work of the President of the European Council and help him bring together the necessary elements to prepare the final stretch of negotiations and build a successful compromise. I take from this debate that we will share a sense of urgency and of ambition. We are actually aware that there is still a lot of work to be done to reconcile different interests and points of view in order to build a compromise. Ultimately, our goal is to agree as soon as possible on what is an unprecedented financial package to face an unprecedented crisis. In the remaining days of our Presidency, we will continue to be fully committed to doing our utmost to facilitate all the steps leading to such an agreement, and to do so in a way that is mindful of Parliament’s views. For it has been clear since the onset of the pandemic that we can only overcome this crisis if we act jointly in solidarity.

name: President. –
text: The joint debate is closed. We have already voted on the amendments of the report by Ms Piri and Mr Hansen. The final vote takes place tomorrow morning. Before I suspend the sitting, I would like to thank the interpreters very sincerely, because the debates were longer than we had anticipated. So my sincere thanks to our interpreters. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Gunnar Beck (ID)
text: Writing. – The EU's demands in trade negotiations with the UK are tough and inappropriate. Inappropriate are the refusal to grant London a trade agreement along the lines of the EU-Canada agreement, and the EU's demand that the ECJ retain the final say on the interpretation of an EU-UK trade agreement. Above all, this demand that The United Kingdom, as a sovereign state again, submits itself not to an independent arbitral tribunal, but to the highest court of its contracting party, the EU, runs counter to both the practice of international law and the practice of the EU itself. In almost all other EU trade agreements, disputes are settled through independent arbitral tribunals. In addition, the claim to power and the impartiality of the ECJ is controversial even within the EU. In the opinion of the Federal Constitutional Court, the ECJ may monitor compliance with the EU Treaties, but the final say on whether the EU is still within the limits set by its treaty is the prerogative of the national constitutional courts. So far, London has refused to respond to the excessive EU demands. If trade negotiations fail, it will harm not only British but also European exporters, consumers, and workers. After the Brexit vote and Britain's exit, it is time for the EU to finally end its punitive expedition against the former EU member.

name: Enikő Győri (PPE)
text: Writing. – The european Union's next multiannual financial framework and recovery basis should offer a solution acceptable to all Member States; the proposal should not leave anyone behind. Thus, the budget must be fair and balanced, and the money must be distributed fairly. The use of money in the budget must be flexible, as there is no general crisis management solution that can be applied to everyone. We need money for different things in some countries, different priorities in the south of Europe, others in the north and others in Central Europe. The restoration of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe should build on a strengthened cohesion policy, which has already been demonstrated; added value in Europe and its contractual objectives are as topical as before the crisis: to compensate for differences in development, thereby strengthening the Competitiveness of the Union. Hungary has made significant reforms in recent years and has succeeded in catching up thanks to its efforts. However, the proposed allocation criteria for recovery instrument resources are based on pre-pandemic statistics and therefore do not reflect the real economic impact of the crisis. In addition, countries with good growth and low unemployment are penalised. The current proposal shows a moral problem: rich countries would receive more money than poorer countries. This cannot remain so; Member States pursuing disciplined economic policies and successful defence should not be penalised for withering resources. Poorer countries should not be disadvantaged by richer Member States.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – At this week’s European Council, participants should be laying the foundations for a mutually—acceptable agreement on the upcoming multiannual financial framework and the recovery package as presented by the Commission on 27 May. It is essential that the recovery package achieve its target to help relaunch the European economy. Meanwhile, the long—term goals of the Union, especially those focused on cohesion between its territories, must be upheld. We face an unprecedented crisis in the amplitude and depth of the peril it entails for the European economic system. That should be recognised in deeds, not just in words. To deal with the crisis satisfactorily, the criteria of the recent past hardly apply. Unless some way is found for effective European action that really addresses, head on, the dangers of the ongoing recession where they are being experienced, the negative social and economic impacts will multiply. With all its flaws, the plans presented by the von der Leyen Commission go a good way towards meeting this vital challenge. Its thrust has to be endorsed. Arguments about, among others, whether loans or grants should be deployed; how recovery projects should be selected and conditioned, etc. should be subordinated to this overall priority.

name: Christine Schneider (PPE)
text: Writing. I hope that the negotiators will be able to intensify the negotiations now, so that a "no deal Brexit" can ultimately be avoided. Comparable environmental and social standards are just as urgently needed to ensure fair competition, as are agreements on fisheries policy or police and judicial cooperation.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. We want a fair distribution system. The objective of the Treaty must be pursued, so that EU funding serves cohesion and the catch-up of the poor. It is unfair for the poor and disciplined farmers to fund the rich and undisciplined. Hungary learned from his own example that future generations should not be indebted. This is also prohibited by the Basic Law. The Hungarian Parliament abolished the extraordinary legal order yesterday. The constitutional mandate of the government and the cooperation of the Hungarian people made it possible to act quickly and effectively. Hungary avoided the fate of Belgium, which is the same size as us, where, unfortunately, the number of victims is 20 times. Yesterday's decision proved that the press, MEP Maxová and his associates lied when they attacked Hungary. There is nothing more menial than attacking those on the front lines for lives in times of danger to all. If they couldn't help us, they'd have done better not to interfere with the fight against the virus. They should be ashamed of themselves for the rest of their lives. Everyone despises those who drill the bottom of a common lifeboat in trouble.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – We are talking again about a partnership agreement with Great Britain after Brexit. We should step up our actions to ensure the security of our countries and citizens. Let us pay attention to a few things. Further negotiations should be based on a political declaration, which is now a reference to the negotiations and defines the parameters of a flexible partnership. Interinstitutional cooperation must ensure the safety of our citizens living in the UK. It is essential that both parties to the future agreement maintain current EU standards on consumer protection and citizens' rights in line with EU legal achievements. The agreement should ensure the protection of citizens of both countries through the obligations of entrepreneurs recruiting workers from outside the UK, in particular from Central and Eastern Europe, many of whom live in the British Isles. We must also do everything we can to ensure that the principles of free movement of persons between the EU and the UK are applied after the transition period. The UK's notification of a derogation from this rule is very worrying. The future partnership should include provisions on the movement of persons based on full reciprocity and the principle of non-discrimination between Member States, and the UK's access to the Internal Market of the Union should be proportionate to the commitments made to facilitate the mobility of persons, taking into account the principle of reciprocity in bilateral relations. The agreement must protect EU and UK citizens, including their family members. They should receive all necessary information on their rights and procedures to be followed in order to continue to reside and work in the country of stay or to travel freely to it.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – The recovery of the European economy is in the interests of every Member State. In a historic crisis, it is justified that we use all the means made possible by the EU to revitalise our common internal market. However, there is still much room for improvement in the package. Personally, I think it is important that the Fund should provide member states with more loans than proposed and only a small amount of direct payments.  In order not to obscure the responsibilities of the Member States, the commitment to good economic management must be included in the criteria for allocating funds. At the same time as we agree on expenditure, a clear decision must also be made on the plan to repay the loan. Increasing the EU's own resources is a worth a proposal, and I welcome, for example, the idea of a tax on non-recyclable plastic. However, taxation requires a unanimous decision by the Member States, which has so far not been achieved. It is now important for member states to find a common position on future own resources and taxes on them. If the repayment of the loan remains open, it could lead to cuts in the EU budget over the next few periods, reducing funding for all EU programmes.  The most crucial thing for recovery is to channel the funds so that they support industrial renewal, digitalisation and sustainable growth. It is advisable to channel as much of the package as possible through existing EU programmes. This is important not only for efficiency, but also for ensuring transparency and parliamentary control.  It is good that the Commission's latest proposal partly increases funds to achieve climate neutrality. At the same time, however, I am disappointed that the proposal cuts from the CEF programme, which funds cross-border transport, energy and digital infrastructure. In order for our economy to remain competitive, we need investment in modern connectivity.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – Following the robust and widely agreed positions in the European Parliament, the European Commission has presented a strong, broad-spectrum new generation recovery fund with a solidarity model. It is essential that the Council swiftly and without unacceptable distortions this proposal, which has been understood by the vast majority of European citizens as proof of the Union's life and capacity to respond to their needs. Such unsprained approval is a condition for the fund to receive the consent of the European Parliament.  The exceptional way in which it was possible to overcome barriers and limitations in the design of the different programmes and response mechanisms has to be transmitted to the implementation procedures, so that the resources begin to reach as soon as possible to those who need them most.  The recommendations for the BREXIT negotiating process are appropriate and must be scrupulously complied with. The exit agreement must be respected, as well as the commitments made in the political declaration. Regulatory alignment must also be ensured and the interests of the European fisheries sector and the rights of Citizens of the Union must also be defended.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the Conference on the Future of Europe (2020/2657 (RSP). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in this debate and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to once again discuss with you the conference on the future of Europe; a reflection that today seems more important than ever in view of the unprecedented challenges our Union is facing. The situation has no doubt radically changed since we last had a chance to discuss the issue in this plenary back in January. The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic has, in the meantime, left deep marks on our societies and economies, leaving no one and nothing unaffected, including the plans we had for the conference.  For obvious reasons over the last few weeks and months, we had to focus our attention on the most pressing priorities for our citizens; foremost the health emergency and its economic and social consequences. If anything, however, the crisis has shown us how important it is to reflect together on the future of our Union. The Presidency therefore remains strongly committed to reaching a consensus in the Council as soon as possible, with the aim of finding an agreement with Parliament and the Commission on the timing and manner of launching the conference and on its overall concept. However, I want to strongly underline that we are doing our best to find swift agreement in the Council on this important issue. That work is still ongoing and has intensified over the last week at COREPER, ministerial and other high political levels. On 9 May, in his address to mark Europe Day, the Croatian Prime Minister, Mr Plenković, stressed the paramount value of the future of Europe open debates with our citizens and other stakeholders for shaping the vision of our common European future. He invited all EU Member States to reach a consensus as soon as possible, as well as the agreement with Parliament and the Commission.  On 26 May, the Presidency also included a discussion on the conference on the agenda of the informal videoconference of Ministers of European Affairs.  As it emerged from these exchanges, the design of the conference will of course need to take into account the recent developments. The Presidency is therefore working on the revised text of the Council’s position in order to also reflect the COVID-19 reality.  We take note of Parliament’s new resolution on the conference on which you will vote in this plenary which similarly seeks to reflect the new reality. At the same time, we believe that the nature of the conference should not fundamentally change in the light of the pandemic. The conference should contribute to the development of our policies in the medium and long term, so that we can better tackle current and future challenges while taking into account as many views of different stakeholders as possible.  While the lessons of the COVID-19 crisis should be included in our reflection, we also consider that the crisis has further highlighted the importance of the already identified priorities of the 2019-2024 strategic agenda. These priorities range from strengthening our single market to successfully delivering the green and digital transition, and delivering concrete results for the benefit and well-being of our citizens. Most importantly, we remain convinced that the upcoming conference should be an inclusive process involving our three institutions in full respect of the interinstitutional balance and of our respective roles. Likewise, Member States should be involved equally, including their national parliaments, and shared ownership remains important.  Finally, let me reiterate that to deliver on our priorities, as well as defining a vision of Europe in 10 to 20 years, cooperation among institutions will be imperative. As the coronavirus crisis has reminded us all, divisions make us weaker. Only by overcoming them will we be able to proactively shape our future.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, last time I had the opportunity to address this House on the Conference on the Future of Europe was on 15 January, a few short months ago. Since then, our world has changed significantly. We are not yet out of the crisis, so we cannot be certain of the impact that this will have on our work for the moment. My key message to you today is that the Conference on the Future of Europe is now more important than ever before. It is an exercise in democratic participation, which showcases the European way. Our common rights and values are central to the resilience of our societies and will be the basis on which we build our recovery from the corona crisis. I am convinced that we must continue to move forward together with ambition and vision. I see my job as reaching out to each and every European citizen. The COVID—19 pandemic shows us the importance of solidarity. It has also shown how together we can recover, repair and come out stronger from this crisis, as President von der Leyen recently said here in this very Chamber. I agree and would add that only together can we build the present and the future that citizens deserve. And please note this: the present and the future. The Commission has proposed a clear, structured plan that aims to lead us out of crisis and into sustainable and long-term economic growth, based on a green transition and a digital transformation, as requested by the European Council. The recently-announced comprehensive package for European recovery, with its overall budget of EUR 1.85 trillion, will help Europe recover from the crisis and support multiple European sectors as we emerge from this period of constraint. This includes major initiatives like Next Generation EU, which will boost the European budget in the first crucial years of the recovery and contribute, together with the reinforced budget for 2021—2027, to making it sustainable, inclusive and fair for everyone, including those in disadvantaged areas and those who were hit hard by the crisis. Together we will come out of the crisis. The Conference on the Future of Europe is an excellent tool to engage and involve all Europeans. I look forward to the joint declaration by the Parliament, the Council and the Commission and later – as soon as possible – to launching the Conference on the Future of Europe. Let’s be honest. Politics is no longer business as usual. We must be brave, have the courage of our convictions and deliver for the citizens. They demand it of us and we have a mandate to respond. We need to strengthen our representative democracy even more by offering an opportunity for enhanced participative democracy. I rely on your support for making this joint declaration a reality as soon as possible. We need to agree on the structure, scope and main principles of the Conference and establish principles for those who want to become our partners in this exercise. Yesterday, at the COSAC meeting, the national parliaments made it clear that they want to be partners in this joint endeavour, and we need to consolidate this partnership approach. We are not competing for influence here. We need to work together to be able to reach out to as many citizens as possible. They count upon the Council of Ministers to reach an agreement on a mandate to enable us to start as soon as possible the negotiations on the joint declaration so that the Conference can be launched as soon as possible. This is the Commission standpoint. In this context, I would like to say a few words on democracy and the Conference on the Future of Europe. During these times, people feel left behind. They blame democracy itself sometimes. While unfortunate, this also shows the importance of democracy and its relevance in our daily lives. Who present here today could have imagined the way in which COVID—19 has infected our European Union in so many different ways at so many different levels? Surely this current crisis shows now more than ever that democracy and democratic institutions have a key role to play. We understand that citizens’ trust in democracy cannot and should not ever be taken for granted. Citizens have been asking for greater participation in policy-making, and we need to listen to this call. By involving citizens and civil society even more, we will help to reinforce democracy in the European Union. Let us have the courage to put innovative tools to work for democracy and citizens, starting with the Conference on the Future of Europe. To conclude, I will end by reminding you why we are having the Conference on the Future of Europe. It is for the current and the next generations of Europeans. Together we – citizens and institutions – will find ways to give Europeans a greater say on what the Union does and how it works for them. Let us have the courage to make a success of the Conference on the Future of Europe.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, the Council and in particular the Vice-President of the Commission would also like to thank the President for the words. Firstly, which I think is essential to say here, is that it is very good to understand that the groups, I would say pro-Europeans of this house, were able to find to give a new impetus to the Conference on the Future of Europe and therefore this was the first point i wanted to underline. It is that we are clearly united and have a vision that is a shared vision of what should be the conference. Secondly, I would also like to say that today, as the Council seems to have discovered more recently now, the Conference on the Future of Europe is more important than it was six months ago and six months ago it was already much needed, but it is now more important. Why?  Because the pandemic is not that it has created new problems, it has made much more patent the problems that already existed and therefore it is necessary now.  There is an awareness on the part of the people, of the citizens, of the problems that Europe is experiencing, in particular the problems that have to do, on the one hand, with what should be the great objectives of the European project, what are the new major objectives and, on the other hand, also the problems of democracy, the problems of the rule of law, the problems of citizen participation and , therefore, these which were, shall we say, the great objectives and principles of the conference are clearly more necessary today than before. Secondly, it is very important: it is essential to realise that, in these circumstances, we must involve the citizens in it and we must follow-up and draw consequences from this conference.  There are two points which are also in the resolution, but the most important point, and here I have to go to the Council and accompany the Commission: ask the Council to take a decision, to ask the Council to finally take a position on this, because, my dear friends, only beautiful words are not enough. We have always heard very beautiful words from the Presidency, but we have seen no progress, no action and we continue to see great hesitation in the Council.  This is also a signal to European citizens. The Council cannot complain about the lack of democracy and then be delaying the Conference on the Future of Europe more and more. Present generations and future generations deserve further treatment, so the Council must quickly take its position and we take this democratic process, as unprecedented, ahead.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the vast majority of today's challenges know no borders. Inequalities, pandemics, climate change, digitization are challenges we face regardless of where we live. We also need to accelerate the change in the Union's decision-making system, moving from unanimity to the majority system in some crucial respects. Before the COVID-19 crisis, we were raising it: a European conference that reflects and defines its future.  This conference is now more necessary than ever. COVID-19 has highlighted some serious shortcomings in the Union, which must be addressed, including lack of competition in health matters, chaotic border closures and also lack of solidarity. If we add to this the risk that there will be no agreement between the Member States to approve the recovery plan, then we will face an unprecedented economic and social crisis.  Unfortunately, the Council continues to give lengths. While Parliament and the Commission have been ready since January to launch this conference, the Council has not yet been able to launch an agreement. Ladies and gentlemen, we need to have a stronger European Union in the future, and we cannot do this alone in the European bubble. We need to open a great debate, and in this the Council has a great responsibility. They can count on a Parliament aware of the responsibility we have to address changes, challenges and to build a stronger Europe with citizenship.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the reason for this resolution is very simple: it is not a resolution to the Commission, it is not a resolution to the colleagues in the Parliament, it is a resolution that is in fact made for the Council. I hope that the Council this time can reach an agreement so that we can launch this conference, because let’s be honest, it becomes more and more like the monster of Loch Ness. From time to time it appears, then it disappears, it is more like an illusion, like a fantasy and we must avoid that. This is serious business, this conference is not one or other little instrument for the European Parliament. This conference is vital, it is crucial for the future of our European Union, because let’s face it, this Covid crisis is another illustration of it. This Covid crisis will change the world. It is a world that will be completely different, a world that will no longer be dominated, I think, by the United States of America who is withdrawing from the international scene for the moment. It may well be dominated by China who wants to become, and who already is, a world power and who wants to dominate the world and international scene.   Between America and China there will be Europe stuck between them and if we don’t want to be stuck between the US at the one hand and China on the other hand, and if we want really the instruments to defend the interests of our citizens, we need another European Union. This European Union is not fit for purpose. Not fit for the future and we all know it. The Council knows it, the Commission knows it and certainly our citizens know it.  So it’s time now to start really this exercise because we have not a lot of time, maybe we can tell that to your colleagues in the Council. There is the Covid crisis, there are precedent crises, tomorrow there could be another challenge.  So my hope is that we can take a decision to make this common declaration between the three institutions and we can start this conference as early as possible in September.

name: Hélène Laporte
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission has launched a reflection on the future of Europe, which it sees as a direct dialogue between itself and the citizens. It is true that the Treaty of Rome and its signatory countries were hopeful about the European project, but it all seems so far away. What if the crises we are experiencing mark the swansong of this federalist and technocratic Europe? The European Union falls from Charybde to Scylla: health failure in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, failure on border issues and deconfinement, and a failure to date also of consensus on the recovery plan. But make no mistake, the failures are not, alas, new. So what future for Europe? To decide where you are going, you have to know where you are coming from. The roots of Europe, its culture, its wounds and its greatness are not a negotiable legacy, globalization has made our continent a land of passage and repentance. The people are attached to their land, their country, their great men. Ultraliberal dogma has lived, federalism must be reviewed in the light of the lessons of the past. The Europe of nations, which we call our wishes, will be a path of hope for peoples who wish to finally regain their sovereignty.

name: Daniel Freund
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I have 90 seconds of speaking time today. That’s the same amount that the European Council took to discuss the outcome of the last major exercise of citizen consultation. We talked to hundreds of thousands of Europeans in over 1 600 citizens’ dialogues. When I read now the draft Council mandate, I have to say that I am shocked the outcome of the two-year debate on the conference should simply be another discussion of the Council behind closed doors. How do you explain to citizens that we are having a debate on the future of Europe, but that you don't really want them to change anything, that we’re excluding the possibility of treaty change, of real change, before the debate has even started? I think that’s absurd.  So we are in a situation where, for the second time in a decade, we are slipping into the worst economic crisis. Millions of Europeans are losing their jobs, particularly young people. Many of them had just gotten out of the last crisis. The question now is: can we or do we want to afford losing another decade, or are we finally going to address the structural shortcomings of this Union, and make sure that we get out of this crisis faster than the last one. I hear in the Council that the conference has become a bit of a running joke, a running gag. I think this House has made it very clear that citizen participation is not a joke, that meaningful reform of the Union is not a joke, and that coming out of this crisis stronger and more united is not a joke. So the Council really needs to stop joking around now. Let’s start working on the future of Europe, I think it is about time.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab My political group also believes that a profound reform of the Union is necessary, especially – and here we agree – in the light of recent experience with the pandemic, which has shown how unsuitable we are, unprepared for existential threats. He also supported the idea of organising a conference on the future of the European Union if this conference were indeed open and also allowed those who do not pay homage to federalist orthodoxy to speak out. Unfortunately, after the statements made by colleagues, it is difficult to hope and to consider it justified. We believe that we must strive to restore the Union as a European community of sovereign nations based on a Euro-realistic vision of a confederal Europe that respects the rights and legitimacy of the democratic Member States. We must strengthen its spiritual foundations. If we should learn something from the history of the 20th century, it is how dangerous attempts are to completely rebuild society.  President von der Leyen recalled in her speech today the principle of 'unity in diversity' as the basis for European integration. In reality, however, there has long been a progressive uniformity of cultures, opinions and collectiveity in Europe. Nations feel that they are slowly being deprived of the right to make up for themselves. Thus, the European Union is becoming increasingly AEuropean, turning away from its philosophical and religious traditions from its past. We must make it European again in the right sense of the word.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I agree with the previous speakers who all say: yes, we need the Council to take up this conference together with Parliament and the Commission. Eight months have passed since the President of the Commission promised this conference to the people of Europe. The European Parliament immediately began to work very how we can move this conference. Many questions about the future organisational and institutional structure and constitutional mandate of this conference still need to be clarified, so time is simply pressing and we have to move, or we, as EU institutions, are not only making ourselves look ridiculous, but are further shaking up confidence in the democracy and capacity of the European Union to participate. The EU's system of government suffers from a number of serious shortcomings – as we all know – that have become apparent over the last decade: the euro crisis, the migration crisis, the rule of law deficits. Moreover, the EU is facing further crises with Brexit. Certainly, we also have differences of opinion: on enlargement, on the new Multiannual Financial Framework, on the ECB or on how to deal with the COVID-19 pandemic. Both the old and the new crises are only exacerbated by the institutional weaknesses of the EU's current constitutional architecture. And this urgently requires that citizens test the EU's ability to act and make effective and legitimate changes in a transparent manner. That is why I believe that we need this process of self-reflection. That is why we need consultation with citizens in this conference, so that we do not just set up a consultation mechanism and a dialogue again, but that we can come up with real changes to deal with these issues of the future.  So, dear advice, let us now start organising the conference! Because we need this conference more urgently than ever.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the socio-economic crisis caused by Covid-19 has made the need to bring citizens closer to the European institutions even clearer and clearer. A recent survey commissioned by our Own Parliament showed that 57 % of our fellow citizens are dissatisfied with the solidarity shown by the Member States during this emergency.  Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to act and turn a difficulty into opportunities. We must overcome once and for all those obstacles and legal paradoxes, such as unanimity in order to overcome the unanimity of the bridging clauses, to strengthen the Union's legal basis and concrete action for social affairs, for health, to reduce growing inequalities and to defend all those rights and solidarity that the citizens are clamously demanding of us. We must do it from the bottom up, we must also do so by amending the Treaties, if necessary, without precluding any instrument.  The world has changed, the Union must change. Parliament is ready to play this global game to defend our values and our project and we say to the Council: with this resolution, wake up and waste no more time, because that capital is the most precious that we cannot afford to debase in any way.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would agree with all of you that we have been involved in debating the Conference on the Future of Europe for so long that I believe the time has come to make it happen. We are Members of the European Parliament, whose obligation, actually, is political courage and political bravery, and we have been elected by citizens. But we are also citizens of the European Union and we can see, as citizens in our daily life across Europe, citizens’ attachment to a Europe that cares about her own citizens and a Europe that is open to the world. The pandemic has also shown disparities between what we as citizens expect from Europe and what it can do for us today. There are empty spaces in Europe’s capacity to act which can be captured again by anti-European populists. That is why this conference and the direct engagement of citizens is so important. The conference is potentially a ground-breaking opportunity to achieve a more democratic and legitimate union, but it can also help us make Europe more effective.  Let me finish by saying that it would be a shame if this conference did not open up the path towards making our Treaties future—proof, adjusting the Treaties to citizens’ expectations, with a view to boosting their chances in an entirely changed global world. As citizens said to me, ‘the boat of history has just arrived on our shores and we cannot miss it’. I wanted to share this with you.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we have the opportunity, we have an obligation, ladies and gentlemen, to make Europe more democratic, more transparent, more efficient and closer to citizens. Twenty years ago — and Mr Verhofstadt will remember this very well - with the Laeken Declaration, we started the last official debate on the future of Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, you have listed the various challenges we face; the pandemic is only the last. Madam Representative of the Council, you have seen the Commission's position ⸻very clear⸻ and Parliament's position, supported by 80% of the House ⸻up to Mr Castaldo, of the unenrolled, supports us⸻. What are you gentlemen and ladies of the Council waiting for? What are you waiting for? We have a position since January. It's been six months. We know that the Council takes its time, which is slower, but to that point it seems excessive. I'm really asking you. We need the Council to have a position and that in September we can start this Conference on the Future of Europe, and that we do so , as Mrs Erner said, without exclusions, also addressing, if necessary, the debate on the reform of the Treaties.

name: Gunnar Beck (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In Strasbourg, I spoke of Sigmund Freud and neurotic flight into the disease: illness frees from the hardship of recovery and promises relief and holidays from reality. Prophetic words! The Corona crisis is the latest in countless EU and euro crises: politicians are wringing their hands, as always do not know what to do. Only one thing everyone here knows: more EU now! The stage for this – the Conference on the Future of Europe: the EU should become effective, democratic and close to its citizens. However, it is not citizens' decisions that are planned, but structured citizens' dialogues, orchestrated by the EU and pro-EU NGOs. And effectively this means: paternalism, redistribution and over-indebtedness. As a result: not recovery, but the descent. Because the EU's problem is that at some point it runs out of German money. Germany and the EU belong on the Freudian couch.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, can I just say to Mr Beck that you must not have read the memo, because these are not orchestrated dialogues with citizens; these are citizens’ dialogues, we don’t orchestrate and we will not orchestrate.  In fact, this Parliament is saying very clearly to the Council, and is frustrated by the Council’s lack of ability to come to a decision. We want to engage with our citizens and it’s not for today or tomorrow, it’s for the future.  None of us has predicted the pandemic and yet look how it has changed how we work. Look at the impact on citizens, on families and societies. Why can’t we discuss this openly? Can I just say the words ‘as soon as possible’ were used by the Council — asap. When I hear that, to me it means now, not in a year’s time, today.   So please, you are hearing the frustrated voices of this Parliament collectively, except for one or two, who want you to move forward and to sit down with the Parliament to engage with national parliaments, with citizens, with the Commission and create a better Europe. It is not about more, it is about better.

name: Gabriele Bischoff (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her You will hear this here: we have a Parliament here that wonders why a single institution of the European Union does not take the first step towards the future of Europe. Because we are not deciding on treaty changes at the moment, it is not a complex mandate, it is an agreement on a mandate to enter into negotiations, to organise this conference in the first place. That is why this resolution is here to make a clear appeal and say: how can this be? For six months – January, February, March, April, May, June – it has not been possible to agree on a simple mandate. Instead, you stay in the trenches, you have dug in, the blockades continue, and you can't get to take the first step. If we do not manage to take this first step, and if the Council does not manage to do so, then we will all be involved and then we will not be able to stabilise Europe. That is why we are saying again: we have heard it, it is also for us here, that we say: how can this be that we do not take this first step? The appeal also to the German Presidency: if this is done, get it moving, we must finally start now!

name: Peter Kofod (ID).
text: Madam President! The Conference on the Future of Europe will be ruled out with one major tribute to the European Union. The conclusion will end up being more EU and more money for the EU. Now it is now a year since I was elected to the European Parliament. At the time I was an EU sceptic, now I am an OPPONENT of the EUROPEAN Union. I get Denmark out of the EU. We should not be forced to hand out child benefit, unemployment benefits or all sorts of other benefits. I do not want to pay any more for bureaucracy, the moving circus, the gigantic EU budget or keep handing out billions of dollars. I do not want the EU's open borders and mass immigration, and I will not let the EUROPEAN Union undermine our labour market or give the right to our social policy, health or immigration policy. I want back control, freedom back - I want Denmark back. You have convinced me that this system cannot be corrected or saved. This system is doomed to the virginity of history, and I am sure that one day in the future, Denmark will leave the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, many thanks for this opportunity to engage with you on the Conference on the Future of Europe. I think that your feedback is very important to our work and I really do appreciate what I heard today. I appreciate your contributions and your will to make the Conference happen, so thank you once again. Let me remind ourselves that when the Commission communication shaping the Conference was adopted on 22 January earlier this year, the Union was in the seventh consecutive year of growth and forecasts pointed to an expansion in 2020-2021. Today, with millions of citizens slowly coming out of confinement and the global recession unfolding, the perspective has radically changed. However, our determination to engage with citizens and ensure their voice is heard has not changed from that moment.  A key message from me today is that the Conference on the Future of Europe remains crucial. In fact, I would go so far as to say that because of the pandemic, it is now more important than ever before. European citizens should have greater say on what the Union does and how it works for them. Answering the difficult questions helps to save lives. Let me stress that we want the Conference to be an open, inclusive and transparent and structured debate.  I referred earlier to the Commission communication on the Conference. The principles stated in it are still valid. The Conference should allow citizens to focus on what they consider to be important. The Commission’s political priorities and the European Council Strategic Agenda provide a broad framework. Having already held many dialogues with citizens, I am convinced that issues such as healthcare and the European Union’s response to the public health crisis will now have a more prominent role in the dialogues among citizens.  Despite challenging circumstances, we aim to launch the Conference on the Future of Europe as soon as possible. Or, as Ms McGuinness said just now, once the Council has adopted its mandate, we can agree on a joint declaration. We are committed to follow up on what is agreed by the Conference. This will be the measure of our success and I commit to it fully. Prior to the Coronavirus outbreak, I was on a listening tour of the European Union. I had planned to visit all 27 Member States but I did only 10. In the first six months of my mandate, in my mission, I was focusing on national and regional examples of where citizens are structurally involved in decision-making processes because getting the feedback mechanism will be key for the Conference on the Future of Europe this time. A feedback mechanism is one of the most important things in this Conference and this is different from previous consultations.  We need to make sure that ideas found in local discussions can be meaningfully discussed at European level. Just like the honourable Members today said, I insist that the Conference on the Future of Europe must be representative of geography, gender, age, socioeconomic background and level of education of citizens. It must also be inclusive of minority populations. All are part of our Europe’s diversity.  It is important to keep an open mind. As I have said to you before, I believe that we should not predetermine the outcome. This is what we agreed many, many months ago, so we should not predetermine outcome or restrict the issues for discussion.  This is an important moment for us. We have the potential to lay the ground for a new type of politics, for a new dynamic to complement representative democracy together. Only together can we do this. Together, we can reinforce the link between European Union policymaking and the citizens’ increased trust. Increased trust, increased legitimacy. Let us make the Conference on the Future of Europe a real success for our citizens.  Thank you once again for your contributions and I’m looking forward to the Council agreeing on a joint declaration and then we can start; I think September would be the best timing to start this. Thank you once again.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude I wish to thank you once again for the useful debate we have had today. I have listened carefully to your views on this important subject and I have taken good note of them.  The Presidency is completely dedicated to finding common ground in the Council. The conference is very important to all of us, but personally I regret very much that we were not able to launch it in Dubrovnik during our Presidency. Before the outbreak of the pandemic, the Croatian Presidency sparred no effort when it came to the facilitating an agreement towards the Council mandates on this issue. Let me reassure you that we will continue to work with vigour and ambition in this direction.  The conference is a new project and some of the stakeholders have far-reaching ambitions for this exercise. It is expected that Member States approach it with different ideas, views, experiences and priorities. In any case, we are seeking consensus.  As this is a very important and emotional debate for the Presidency, and my last plenary as minister-delegate, allow me a few words in my native Croatian. Dear Chairman, in the first Croatian Presidency of the Council we faced a challenge not seen since the founding of the European Union. I am proud of our joint swift response, of the commitment of all colleagues, I am proud that we have ensured the continuity of decision-making in the Council, but also the constant communication of ministers in all Council formations.  Today I would especially like to thank all MEPs and MEPs who continued to work together with their colleagues in the Council and the Commission, at the height of the crisis, in order to adopt the first packages of measures to deal with European health, the economy and society as a whole with the COVID-19 pandemic. I hope that together we will work equally successfully on a recovery plan for the European Union. Thank you for enthusiastically supporting the Croatian programme and the priorities of the presidency. Your cooperation has been invaluable to us over the past six months.  Let me finally express my firm belief that by the end of the month we will find consensus on the Council's position on the Conference on the Future of Europe.  A healthy, resilient, responsible, strong and secure Europe, tailor-made for our citizens, must be our first priority. I wish you all a lot of success in further work for the benefit of European citizens and see you again. It was an extraordinary honour to represent the first Croatian Presidency of the Council in the European Parliament.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you very much, Madam President, for the work of the last six months, which have certainly been both exciting and exhausting for you, and for the good cooperation. In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, two motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, 17 June 2020, and the final vote will take place on Thursday, 18 June 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR)
text: in writing. – In order to avoid the dangers of an overly centralised Europe or a fully fragmented Europe, the ECR Group believes it is essential that the fundamental cohesion factor be based on responding to the real needs of harmony and prosperity of the Member States. Needs to follow a humanist and transcendent pragmatism where principles and values—pillars of our laws—are based on human rights such as the defense of life, freedom and dignity.  These, in turn, cannot flourish without fostering policies aimed at strengthening the institution of the family. A family as a measure and criterion of a healthy society focused on the real needs of all its members, because it is where men and women, young people and children are best educated and protected, in a permanent creative exercise to free their skills and abilities.  In this perspective of strengthening this basic and primary unity we will achieve real coherence in our proposal for a community of sovereign nations, where the principles of subsidiarity, proportionality and transfer govern and can be fully and consistently respected.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The Conference on the Future of Europe is organised by Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and was expected to start in May 2020 and last for 2 years. Fact, the Conference is extremely necessary, especially in a world fundamentally changed by the crisis in which Europe will seek its place between the US and China. In this situation, the EU will need clear objectives, as the Conference on the Future of Europe can draw up. It is undeniable that the holding of the Conference is a chance to carry out much-needed reforms in the EU so that it can be closer to citizens. To end the practices of division of Eastern and Western Europe. To put an end to the hypocrisy and practice of Europe at two speeds. To this end, it is imperative to hear all points of view. For now, the extreme-federalist downsies that have proven to have failed during the pandemic and the hysteria associated with it are given priority. It seems that Parliament stands fully and firmly behind the organisation and conduct of the Conference, while the Commission and in particular the Council are not at the same level of readiness. I call for the organisation and conduct of the Conference to take place in compliance with the principle of subsidiarity and respecting the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The 'Conference on the Future of Europe' aims to give a democratic appearance to a process of integration that has scorned and confronted the will of the peoples, whenever it has proved contrary to the intentions of those who have determined and determine the direction of the EU.  We would like to resose the process of the 'Convention on the Future of Europe', which would lay the foundations for a 'European constitution', in a mystification operation then dynamicised and which is now generally intended to be repeated.  As with the 'Convention', the Conference on the Future of Europe seeks to re-impose a roadmap and pre-determined policy objectives, hiding the EU's responsibilities in the current economic and social situation and aiming at deepening its policies, which are at the root of the deepening of social inequalities, increased development asymmetries and increased relations of dominance versus dependency between countries. Once again, they seek to create or deepen mechanisms for monitoring and conditioning the budgetary and economic policies of States – such as "Economic and Monetary Union", the "Fiscal Treaty", "Economic Governance", the "European Semester" or the "Banking Union" – which represent an unacceptable and serious obstacle to the full exercise of sovereign powers of countries such as Portugal, which are fundamental to their economic and social development.

name: Εμμανουήλ Φράγκος (ECR)
text: Writing. – This debate is taking place at a critical time for the EU. Since the covid-19, Member States have been fighting for their economic recovery and the EU must play a leading role. The Conference on the Future of Europe, now more than ever, must be an open process involving as many Community and national bodies as possible, in order to express the will of the citizens more easily and to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the Union. For the same reason, we believe that the national parliaments must play a more important role, because of the stronger democratic mandate, as well as the European Parliament and the institution of civil society. The objectives of the Conference should be, in particular, to involve citizens more actively in the administration, to strengthen the role of the European Parliament and the directly elected institutions of the Union, to provide for more instruments and institutions of direct democracy, to strengthen the role of national parliaments, to spread and decentralise powers. We also believe that full control of migration flows and a fair distribution of the burden of the problem, respect for the sovereignty of the Member States, and effective protection of European borders should be a priority.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE)
text: Written. – It is time to think about the European Union in its current form. The Treaty of Lisbon came into force 10 years ago, and the Schuman Declaration celebrated its 70th anniversary this year. The question of the future of Europe became more pertinent because of the corona crisis. Corona has clearly exposed certain pain points in the construction of our Union. Despite the strong catch-up afterwards, the EU was unable to get a grip on the various measures taken by the Member States at the beginning of the crisis. We must not be blind to this and we must dare to learn lessons. In order to overcome the socio-economic consequences , which are the biggest since World War II, we also need a great deal of resilience and a strong Union that can act decisively. Today I call for a thorough debate on the role of the European Union in cross-border health crises, so that we are better prepared in the future. The European Union's toolbox has proved too limited in this respect for the major works expected of the Union. We need to use this momentum to reflect on how we can make the EU more efficient and, above all, more decisive.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the last few years, the European Union has been put to the test like never before. Mainly due to Brexit and other successive crises related to euro area debt, uncontrolled influx of migrants, violations of the rule of law or, finally, the outbreak of a corona virus pandemic. They revealed numerous shortcomings both in the management system of the Union and in the areas of competence it has. I am therefore convinced that we are in a situation that requires a strong response, and I hope that the outcome of the forth coming future conference in Europe will be the recommendation of fundamental constitutional changes. They should, in my view, provide for a greater delegation of competences and institutional conversions m.in to the Union, including the abolition of unanimity in the Council, entrusting the European Commission with the role of a genuine EU government by limiting the role of the European Council, reducing the composition of the Commission and making it dependent on the results of the EP elections. It is also important to strengthen the position of the European Parliament, to give it greater powers of control, budgetary powers on an equal footing with the Council or an effective right of legislative initiative (independent of commission decisions). I also believe that if not all Member States are interested in deep reforms and further strengthening cooperation (unanimity), deepening integration could be achieved through the conclusion of a new treaty between the Member States concerned, based on the existing INSTITUTIONAL SYSTEM of the EU.

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europe is going through difficulties, we are still fighting the COVID-19 pandemic, which will result in economic problems. I support the work on the Conference on the Future of Europe. This may be a forum for reflection on the EU's response to the pandemic, but precisely because of this crisis, the conference should not be a priority. It is important that all EU institutions, while respecting their Treaty competences and, equally, the Member States, look at the future of Europe. We must not forget the national parliaments, their participation will strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the conference. The future of Europe is a community of nations, where individual traditions are appreciated, aware of their history and roots. The objectives that we have on the horizon are the economic crisis after COVID-19, demographics, a return to values.  Europe cannot deny universal and absolute values. We need a Europe that protects and defends the most vulnerable, whose voice is inible. It is not enough for Europe to have only Christian roots, it must have a future. To paraphrase the words of Pope Francis, it must be said that the time has come to build together a Europe that revolves around the economy as much as it does around the sanctity of the human person, inalienable values. "A Europe boldly embracing its past and looking with confidence to its future in order to live its present fully and with hope. The time has come to (...) promote a participatory Europe that brings knowledge, art, music, humanities values and the values of faith."

name: László Trócsányi (PPE)
text: Writing. – I agree with my fellow Members that the launch of the Conference on the Future of Europe is timely. Since the 2008 economic crisis, the long 2010s have been a series of virtually different crises – economic, financial, migration crises, the proliferation of terrorist attacks and the current epidemic situation. Europe, the European states, must become more resilient and effective in dealing with crises. Work needs to be made to solve problems that benefit European nations and European citizens. The principle of an ideological 'ever closer union' should not be allowed to tie up thinking about the future of Europe. European states are currently facing a number of challenges. They must become competitive on the world market and provide security for their citizens. Find answers to the demographic challenge of their society's ageing. They must say no to mass migration, which denies the values of European culture. They need to restart their economies, in which they are doomed to cooperate. We therefore need a Union that helps European nations in this. The Conference provides a good framework for the conduct of debates, but it can only be effective if no one owns it. The free conflict of opinions requires that national parliaments be able to participate in this thinking. National parliaments are, on the one hand, carriers of popular sovereignty and, on the other hand, masters of the European Treaties, so without them it is not possible to hope for a successful European vision.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. "We live in historical times that encourage historical change for all of us. The global coronavirus epidemic must also clearly and unequivocally re shape our thinking and attitudes to dogmas thought to be sacred cows, such as the competence of the Member States. The epidemic has shown that it knows no boundaries or time zones, and that effective action against it can only be deeply integrated and coordinated. When we talk about the future of Europe, one of the first and most important questions that we need to put on the table is this: how long are we going to allow such a deep gap between member states' public health systems? What kind of European community is one of its citizens three times more likely to get a hospital infection than its European citizen, who lives just a few hundred kilometres away?  When we think about the future of Europe, we need to be able to answer whether it is right that in an Eastern European Member State, due to the protocols and quality of care in force, a European citizen's cancer is less likely to be diagnosed in time than to the west. I don't think it's right. I believe that an enlightened European community of solidarity cannot tolerate these profound differences. I find it untenable that, leaving the organisation of health care within the competence of the Member States, the European Union can only shrug and shrug its shoulders because of such conditions. It is therefore necessary to review the competences of the Member States and, firstly, to set minimum quality standards in the field of public health. That's what I'm working on. I'll do that.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I have a brief message to make: I would like to inform you that the results of the first round of voting will be announced at 8 p.m. instead of 8.15 p.m.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission declarations on the protection of strategic European sectors from foreign takeovers in the post-COVID period (2020/2663(RSP)). There are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards on this debate either.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the members of the European Council, in their joint statement on 26 March, underlined that the COVID—19 pandemic constitutes an unprecedented challenge for Europe and the whole world, requiring urgent, decisive and comprehensive action at EU, national, regional and local levels. They pledged to do everything that is necessary to protect our citizens and overcome the crisis by preserving our European ways and way of life.  Members of the European Council also welcomed the Commission guidelines on the screening of foreign direct investment and called on the Member States to take all the necessary measures to protect strategic assets and technology from foreign investments that could threaten legitimate public policy objectives. In the words of the leaders, this will contribute to the EU’s strategic autonomy during the crisis and afterwards.  It is clear that the European Union will not get out of this crisis by closing its doors to international trade and investment. Many European companies are fully integrated in the global supply chain and a significant share of our employment is made possible thanks to international trade and investment. Global trade and investment will therefore remain fundamental for Europe’s recovery and growth. The European Union needs to diversify and solidify its global supply chains to ensure the continuous flow of goods and services and to be better prepared for future crises. However, at this time the European Union also needs to be particularly vigilant to ensure that we preserve those assets that are crucial to our security and that are part of the backbone of our economy. This will directly affect our capability to recover fast.  The economic crisis resulting from COVID—19 has weakened many European companies who have seen their stock prices fall. The danger of predatory takeovers by foreign companies, in particular those in state hands or with strong state support, is very real. The EU’s openness to foreign direct investment therefore has to be balanced with adequate tools and protection. EU rules already provide a framework to guarantee the protection of legitimate public objectives and Ministers for the internal market and industry regularly discuss the competitiveness of the EU economy and in particular its industry.  The discussion focused on strengthening the European strategic economic sectors and value chains and, in this context, also the protection from foreign takeovers. Ministers have welcomed the new industrial strategy for Europe that was presented by the Commission in March. They support the action announced by the Commission to reinforce the EU’s strategic digital infrastructures, to develop synergies between civil, defence and space industries, to secure the supply of pharmaceuticals and their ingredients, and to broaden EU access to raw materials, to give just a few examples.  At the informal video conference last Friday, 12 June, Ministers from the internal market and industry also discussed the Commission’s communication on the recovery plan package adopted on 27 May. They welcomed the measures proposed by the Commission to strengthen EU resilience and strategic autonomy across key technologies and value chains, while preserving the benefits of an open economy.  Ministers also welcomed a new European Strategic Investment Facility under InvestEU to support European resilience and investment in strategic industrial chains, notably those linked to the green and the digital transition. The Ministers took note of the Commission’s intention to propose a reinforced foreign direct investment screening mechanism, which would help the EU to protect its strategic assets, infrastructure and technologies from foreign direct investments that could threaten the security of the public order. The existing FDI screening regulation was already a priority file for the three institutions during the past legislature. This regulation was agreed very swiftly and in a very consensual manner by the co—legislators. Our collective engagement in this dossier has made the EU better able today to face the challenge in front of us. As you know, a significant and increasing number of Member States already have a screening mechanism in place and many others are accelerating the creation of their national contact points.
