The cooperation and exchange of information among Member States and with the Commission about potential foreign takeovers affecting our security or public order has increased sharply.  The Commission is regularly analysing and reporting on investment trends in an expert group, as foreseen in the regulation. Moreover, the upcoming Commission White Paper on an instrument on foreign subsidies will be a good opportunity to address the issue of state subsidies from third countries that have the potential of further disrupting the level playing field in the EU single market. The examples I have just mentioned show how institutional cooperation has improved the situation on the ground for our companies.  Finally, allow me to reiterate that the Council and the Member States will take all the necessary measures to protect strategic assets and technology from foreign investments that could threaten legitimate public policy objectives.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, Honourable Members, this debate today in the European Parliament is extremely timely, protecting Europe’s strategic sectors from foreign takeovers in a post-Covid world.  And I think we all realise that the current geopolitical context, the global economic environment, is probably the most difficult in recent history. Openness to trade and investments and to a rule-based multilateral order, they are all being challenged.  So today, the European Commission has adopted a White Paper, which launches a public consultation on ideas for future rules to make sure that foreign subsidies won’t undermine the level playing field in Europe’s single market.  Right now, as we start to rebuild from the damage that the coronavirus is doing, we need the single market more than ever.  Foreign investment is an important source of jobs and growth and very much welcome in Europe, but when foreign governments give subsidies to support investment and operations in the single market, that can affect our level playing field in several ways. To give you a couple of examples: if businesses are being subsidised that are already in Europe; if businesses are being helped by foreign subsidies to buy European businesses; subsidies can help foreign companies to outbid rivals in public tenders and some subsidised companies can even get access to money from the European budget. In this White Paper, we produce three different modules with three different ways to deal with these situations.  Module 1 is a general market scrutiny instrument to capture all market situations where foreign subsidies would distort the single market. The competence would be shared between Member States and the Commission and if a subsidy is found to distort the single market then redressive measures could be imposed. Or if the subsidy investment or economic activity has a positive impact that outweighs the distortion, the Commission could decide not to pursue it further. And this is what we call the EU interest test. Module 2 specifically addresses distortions caused by foreign subsidies facilitating acquisitions of EU companies.  The Commission would be the competent supervisory authority and a transaction could not be closed whilst the Commission’s review is still pending. Here, commitments might be accepted to allow for the acquisition and also here an EU interest test could be applied. Module 3 addresses the issues that might arise in public procurement and sets out a mechanism where bidders would have to notify any financial contribution received from third countries.  The competent authorities would then assess whether there is a foreign subsidy and whether that has made the procurement procedure unfair. The bidder would be excluded from the procurement process on this basis.  Finally, we also propose to look at access to EU funding in the context of foreign subsidies, both when EU funds are implemented by the Member States and when they’re implemented by the European Commission directly. Obviously, these are complex matters.  So, we are launching a public consultation. It will be open for 14 weeks until 23 September. And we hope to get a wide range of views and suggestions and this obviously is the best possible way of starting this consultation by getting the views of the European Parliament.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as my colleague, Executive Vice-President Commissioner Vestager, has said, the debate in the European Parliament this evening is very timely, for the reasons that she has just outlined, but also, we are living in a global public health challenge that is having profound consequences on our economies and on our daily lives. The COVID-19 emergency has exposed our vulnerability in many respects, and one of them is the resilience of our strategic industries in their capacity to respond to the vital needs of the European people.  We all agree that investment, including foreign direct investment (FDI), will play a central role in our economic recovery in each Member State, but foreign direct investment will also contribute to bridging the gap of domestic financing for the EU’s economic recovery and future ambitions, including greening our economy and making it fit for the digital age. In addition, foreign direct investment turbocharges research and innovation. Foreign—owned firms account for a quarter of business in terms of R&D in France, Germany and Spain, between 30% and 50% in Portugal and Sweden, and more than 50% in Austria, Belgium and Ireland. But foreign investments should not happen at the expense of our own internal security. This is where our FDI Screening Regulation plays a very important role in addressing the concerns when foreign investment may put European security or public order at risk. The Commission is closely following developments in the European Union, and at the end of March, we issued, as the Council President has said, special guidance to Member States on the protection of Europe’s strategic assets, ahead of the full application of the FDI Screening Regulation in October 2020. It reminds Member States of the interdependencies that exist in the European single market. It calls on all of them to seek advice and coordination in cases where foreign investments could, actually or potentially, now or in the future, have an effect on public order or security. Those Member States that have screening mechanisms should take full advantage of that and use them, and those that do not should certainly put them in place as soon as possible.  Europe has a strict and unique system of state aid control and transparency in place, but there is increasing concern that some third countries do not shy away from intervening in our markets with massive amounts of subsidies, and such third—country subsidies will then distort the European Union’s internal market. So investors receiving such subsidies could aim to acquire EU companies and could, thanks to their state financing, outbid other companies, including European companies. As Executive Vice-President Vestager said, the Commission has today adopted a white paper, which launches a very important public consultation on the ideas for future roles to make sure that foreign subsidies don’t undermine the level playing field in Europe’s single market. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are now continuing our debate on the Council and Commission declarations on the protection of strategic European sectors from foreign takeovers in the post-COVID period (2020/2663(RSP)).

name: Christophe Hansen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, China is not the only state on a shopping spree for companies weakened by the impact of the pandemic. Yet, it is definitely the proverbial elephant in the room in this debate. It leaves no doubt that our China policy could do with a healthy dose of realism. We should not adopt the approach of President Trump, who acts more like the proverbial elephant in the china shop.  The white paper on foreign subsidies gives good options, but actions speak louder than words. Actions such as the pioneering countervailing duties levied on imports of fibreglass stemming from Chinese state-subsidised companies producing abroad in Egypt. But more can be done: a China taskforce, to speak with China with one single voice on all different levels; secondly, we can beef up our FDI screening instrument; thirdly, we can move forward on the instrument for public procurement.  If we are to keep up public support for our trade policy, we must equip it with the tools to enforce fair competition.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, the economic effects of the corona crisis should not be used to make a profit on the backs of weakened companies. Millions of jobs in Europe already depend on the whims of foreign investors. The employees of Apollo Vredestein and Tata Steel can talk about this. They are fighting against decision-making on board tables, far away. There needs to be a review of the rules on foreign investment, which provide a clear definition of what strategic sectors are. Are these only the factories that make medical devices, for example, or are we prepared to secure other strategic sectors for our continent? We must not stand by and watch companies use unfair subsidies to seize the crisis to go bargain hunting. It's up to all of us to protect jobs and businesses.

name: Stéphanie Yon-Courtin
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Executive Vice-President, Commissioner, dear representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, in December 2019, President Ursula von der Leyen announced that the Commission she will chair will play a strong geopolitical role. The white paper you are presenting today on foreign subsidies is really a step in that direction, and I would like to welcome it, especially in the current context where the European Commission is working intensively to manage the crisis, particularly through the temporary framework of state aid. In the annual report on competition policy, of which I am rapporteur and which will be voted on tomorrow, we call on the European Commission, together with colleagues, to strengthen competition policy in globalisation and to ensure reciprocity with third countries in terms of public procurement and state aid. Our observation is clear: we must adapt our rules to the current situation to remedy two legal loopholes. Firstly, our state aid rules do not apply to non-European operators who have full access to our single market, and finally, neither antitrust rules nor the control of EU mergers take into account foreign subsidies. Imagine, ladies and gentlemen, a football match where the rules of the foreign team welcomed would be much more lenient than those of the team that plays at home. You don't have to watch the game, because without being flashy, you already know in advance who will win it, but in a totally unfair way! The COVID-19 crisis has alerted us to the need to preserve our key sectors in order to achieve a resilient Europe. The hostile takeovers of companies weakened by this crisis cannot be commonplace, on the pretext that we have not been able to prevent them, and I welcome the avenues put forward today by the Commission, which will enable this type of predatory behaviour to be investigated and prevented. However, there is still a long way to go, and I hope that the public consultation will answer these questions, in particular: what distribution of powers between the Commission and the Member States, what freedom for Member States which, from now on, willingly accept foreign investment or the buy-backs of their national flagships by largely subsidised foreign companies? One thing is for sure, if we want this to work, we must remain united, otherwise our trading partners will play more on our diversity than our unity.

name: Kim Van Sparrentak
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, President Trump’s alleged interest in buying the German biotech company CureVac was an eye—opener. I welcome the initiatives taken by the Spanish and German Governments to better screen foreign direct investment and create the possibility to veto hostile foreign takeover bids on health care companies. The further steps taken by the Commission are also a good step in the right direction. The health and pharmaceutical sector is crucial for the public health of Europeans. We must put public health before shareholder profits and that’s why we need an increase in public funding with clear guidelines. We need a change in the research and development model for pharmaceuticals, based on open science and cost transparency. Changing the pharmaceutical sector for the benefit of everyone will be a lot harder if European pharmaceutical companies fall into foreign hands. That’s why this sector in particular needs to be protected from hostile foreign takeovers, especially the ones that come from a very nationalistic interest.

name: Johan Van Overtveldt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, any initiative to protect our companies from takeovers, not least by Chinese groups that enjoy state subsidies, deserves all the praise and support. China does not play it according to international rules. The internal market is constantly protected. The legal arbitrariness towards foreign investors is pervasive and that country plays a rather dominant role in the increasingly widespread cybercrime. Protection is good, protection is fine, but not enough to give back our entrepreneurial fabric, which is badly battered by this crisis. I believe that two measures or two measures are absolutely structurally necessary in this area. One: strengthening the internal market. Without this internal market, it is impossible for companies to compete on the international market. And two, the realisation of the internal capital market, which is necessary to generate the necessary funds for companies and also to ensure that those funds are used efficiently.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. "Mr. President, what a waste of time! It was not until 2020 and a crisis of unprecedented magnitude that the Commission and the Council were moved by the aggressive practices of certain powers and their multinationals in public procurement trade on foreign acquisitions in strategic sectors. It was not until 2020 that some discovered that in the WTO, for example, China or the United States were not really fanatics of reciprocity. I saw that Ms. Vestager and Mr. Breton said they had been naïve. It is good to recognize that, but now we have to stop being so and we have to react. I have read your White Paper carefully. First of all, I find it complicated: you have three levels of investigation, countless forms, etc. I think we have to get to the bottom of it, we have to be clear, simple, pragmatic. We must stop, as you do all too often, from wanting to restore the pure and perfect market at all costs. It never existed and it does not exist. Let's get to the bottom of it: we need to protect our businesses, our jobs, our know-how; you need a Buy European Act. When it comes to acquisitions of foreign companies, that is not the rule, but the exception. We must defend European companies and employees.

name: Mislav Kolakušić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, the right to truth and the right to true facts is one of humanity's fundamental rights. In order to make the right decisions, we need to find out the facts. On 10 March 2020, I asked that we do not close the doors of the European Parliament, that we stay here and learn the truth about the virus, about one of the countless mutations of the Corona family virus and COVID-19. Instead, we closed the doors of Parliament and thereby gave the right for others to close the doors of their parliaments, furthermore, to trade, to abolish transport, to abolish the entire economy.  What happened? There's been an unprecedented economic disaster. We now have a second wave coming up, we need to find out the facts, we need to invite the most famous epidemiologists and virusologists to this home, ask them questions to know how we're going to react in the 10th month.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr! May I make it clear, however, that the European Parliament has never closed its doors, but that we are the only international, multinational organisation that has continued its work in a multilingual and remote way and has demonstrated its ability to act as a European civic chamber?

name: Lídia Pereira (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Covid-19 pandemic is causing devastating consequences for the European economy with The Union's exports falling by close to EUR 470 billion by the end of this year. Market volatility leaves European companies susceptible to foreign offensives. It is therefore urgent to take concrete measures to protect them and, above all, when owned by companies owned or owned by States. The old maxim that capital has no nationality is valid only and until the moment when this capital ceases to be motivated by its remuneration and becomes a political, cultural and civilizational weapon. This type of threat is even greater when it comes to strategic sectors, infrastructure or technologies.  We need a pragmatic Union, an attractive economy and a regulatory framework to monitor the origin of foreign capital in any merger and acquisition process.

name: Raphaël Glucksmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Piraeus port, Toulouse airport, Alstom. So far, everything about us has been for sale. The Commission is finally reacting with this White Paper. Filtering foreign investment is indeed vital, but it is not enough. I will tell you the story of a French factory, that of Gerzat, the last factory capable of producing oxygen bottles in Europe for our hospitals and our firefighters. A year ago, the Anglo-American management of Luxfer decided to close this plant, despite a 55% increase in profits, and we are now totally dependent, to produce this, from the United States or Turkey. Luxfer is the name of an abandonment of solidarity and an abandonment of sovereignty. So, ladies and gentlemen, we have an armed arm of EUR 2 trillion: the public order. We need a Buy European Act today. We cannot stay like this, unable to produce bits of tissue or basic drugs. The european citizens would not forgive us, and they would be right.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, in protecting Europe’s strategic sectors there is no single silver bullet – we need the whole toolbox. That’s why I welcome the White Paper that looks at ways of reining in foreign subsidies, but we also will need to strengthen our investment screening approach vis-à-vis predatory takeovers. Even though the volume of capital invested has decreased recently, the number of investments has grown, which means that investment from China is going after smaller companies that still might have a strategic role. So I think we should try to start amending our investment screening mechanism once it comes into force in October and we could learn a lesson from this. In addition, I think in order to protect our strategic sectors we must also protect their supply chains, and there it would be interesting to learn from Japan where they’re investing into relocating in order to protect supply chains, and they do that together with ASEAN countries. We could think of doing that with Western Balkan countries and other partners too.

name: Tom Berendsen (PPE).
text: Mr President, the next few years will determine how we as Europe will go into the future. And we're not turning our backs on the rest of the world. An outstretched hand remains important, but we must set clear rules to serve our own interests. No more being naïve! Those who want to be active in our market must abide by the rules and they must serve European interests. A U.S. government looking for a coronary drug only for Americans does not serve our interest. Chinese state-owned companies looking for strategic bargains here, whether it be ports, high-quality technology companies or orders for electric buses, do not serve our interests. In order to serve our interests, we must ensure that our market also applies our rules, our standards and values. In this way, we protect our place in the world and ensure that the jobs of the future are preserved here in Europe. I therefore call on the Commission to act quickly!

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all can I thank all of the contributors to this important issue. I want to make some concluding remarks by insisting on the fact that the European Union has an open market. It welcomes foreign investments. But foreign investments certainly need to be screened, and I agree with the speakers Glucksmann, Bütikofer and Hansen who have advocated that we need to be looking at an even stronger measure than we have in place for foreign direct investment, but this was the will of the co-legislators to have a light-touch, data-driven data-collection mechanism, and therefore we in the Commission would certainly advocate a stronger measure here, if this is possible.  So in that respect the foreign direct investment screening mechanism that will come into effect in October needs to be strengthened. Also I think if there were two issues that we need your assistance on, then it would first of all be to respond in a very clear way and in a very strong way to the White Paper that has been issued by my colleague Commissioner Vestager today, in terms of getting a good response about how we need to do more in dealing with the issue of farm subsidies and that they are competing on an uneven playing field with the European companies.  And secondly your strong political support would be very welcome for moving on the international procurement instrument, which has been left a little bit in abeyance by a certain institution, so I call on the Council and Parliament and the Commission to work more closely together in order to ensure that we get this particular piece of legislation enacted as quickly as possible.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me just echo what my colleague just said – and what Mr Bütikofer suggested – we need a toolbox. There’s no such thing as a silver bullet when it comes to these matters. They are complicated matters. But there are solutions to be found. And what we’re doing here is to express the fact that we will not – at the cost of businesses in Europe and consumers in Europe – sacrifice fair competition. Because it serves us well. It gives us choice, it gives us affordable prices, it gives us innovation. But in the same vein, of course we will not let go of fair competition. We will stand up for European businesses when they are being unfairly challenged by businesses who get foreign subsidies for acquisitions, maybe even for their operating costs – the most harmful subsidy of all is to have someone pick up your bills in doing that.  I hope that we can continue a strong cooperation on this. I really hope that you will encourage the co-legislator on the international procurement instruments, because here we need reciprocity and we need tools for that. I also hope that you will insist that we get better procurement rules, because procurement is a competition, and those who are the most efficient, with the highest quality, they should win: not those who come with a subsidy in their luggage. Right now, European governments are doing the best they can to help businesses come through the damage that the coronavirus is doing, but they do that in a controlled way, they do that in a transparent way, they do that in a way that preserves the single market that will help us recover and create the jobs that have been lost. The reason why we’re dealing with foreign subsidies is that we have no control, no transparency, and that is why we stand up against this today. So thank you very much for the very broad support. I very much look forward to our future cooperation, also on these files.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this has been a very useful debate for all of us and I would like to thank you for Parliament’s continuous engagement and interest in this topic. I have taken good note of all your comments and interventions, and I will convey them to my colleagues in the Council. As I mentioned earlier, the economic crisis resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic has made many European companies vulnerable to hostile takeovers by foreign companies. For this reason, the EU has to ensure that we preserve those assets that are crucial to our society and to our economy, and those that assist the post-crisis recovery.  The new EU legislation to create the first EU-wide framework for the screening of foreign direct investment was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council in March 2019 has now entered into force and can be fully applied from 11 October 2020.  Finally, allow me to reiterate that the Council and the Member States will take all the necessary measures to protect strategic assets and technology from foreign investments that could threaten legitimate public-policy objectives.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Beata Mazurek (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The negative effects of the COVID19 crisis will continue to be felt in Europe and worldwide for a long time to time. While we are trying to return to normality in small steps, we must not forget the challenges that await us in the new "pokoronaviral reality". We must do everything we can to protect our economy from external factors that may affect its weakening. We must support our companies by creating appropriate mechanisms to prevent them from being taken over by third-country entities. Strategic industries, such m.in defence, IT and medical industries, should remain the domain of the Member States. We need to strengthen the internal market, strengthen our competitiveness policy so that we are better prepared for future crises.  We must act sensibly. We must not close our doors to foreign investment, which will contribute to a faster economic recovery. However, they must not endanger our security. They need constant monitoring, cooperation between Member States and ongoing exchange of information are needed. We cannot act hermetically. Through good cooperation, we will better safeguard our interests. Our actions must be decisive. Let us remember that by protecting our economy, we are protecting the internal market and consumers and, above all, the citizens of the European Union.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The COVID-19 crisis is a threat of third-country investors taking over strategic companies. The EP and RE Regulation on the monitoring of foreign direct investment in the EU will not take effect until October 2020. Poland as one of the 14 countries has regulations at national level and applies the Act of 24 July 2015 on the control of certain investments. The Polish, in support of Polish entrepreneurs, introduced a package of solutions "Anti-crisis shield" for more than PLN 312 billion, which is intended to protect the Polish state and citizens from the crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The entry of investors from third countries into Europe is already taking place. In the crosshairs are strategic companies from the point of view of public safety (e.g. energy), health care, new technologies and companies from key industries, in Poland m.in. furniture sector. It must be remembered that not only liquidity is the reason for easy acquisitions. The flow of know-how data, the raising of EU R&D funds by companies from Member States are a bad feeling, and their loss can have very negative consequences. We must be particularly vigilant and protect strategic sectors. Checking the origin of the capital of companies wishing to invest in the EU and links with third-country governments are essential. Europe must not become a tool in a global 'trade war'.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: Writing. – After the coronavirus epidemic, the market value of many European companies has decreased and may need investors due to their weakened liquidity situation. Unfortunately, European technology companies have long been attractive investment destinations for companies from non-EU countries, for example. Interest in the Far East has now intensified again. These companies also appear to be making use of the situation caused by the coronavirus epidemic, in particular as they can obtain advanced technology. I believe that, in order to ensure effective protection, it is necessary to provide a coordinated European answer to this question, and that member states should consider taking anti-takeover measures as an element of measures in response to the coronavirus epidemic, in line with local specificities. I am convinced that the actions of the Hungarian and Polish Governments have set the right path and set a good example. One of the objectives of the crisis management package of the two Visegrad Countries was to prevent the acquisition of strategic companies abroad. Eastern European decision-makers are therefore increasingly concerned that state-backed companies from non-EU countries may gain too much influence over key companies on the continent and thus sensitive infrastructure, while those countries continue to protect their own economies from similar foreign investment. I urge the Commission to pay due care to ambitious takeover plans and to take immediate action and to develop the necessary EU toolbox to eliminate the distortive effects of the internal market.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on tourism and transport in 2020 and beyond (2020/2649(RSP)). Like the last chairmen, I repeat that there are no spontaneous speeches and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for inviting the Commission for this debate to discuss what is of course on the mind of everyone nowadays. The vision of the Commission for the recovery of tourism and transport, as we gradually emerge on the other side of the Coronavirus pandemic. I am sincerely happy to be back with you. As the summer holidays approach, it is clear that we need to consider transport and tourism together. How would we physically go on holiday if no trains, boats, planes or cars were moving, or indeed moving across borders?  However, getting the economy moving requires people moving too, and that requires trust and coordination. What we need to offer citizens is clarity, non-discrimination and seamless connectivity.  We all know too well that the transport and tourism sectors have been the hardest hit by the pandemic, and particularly passenger transport. Traffic across modes has been down by at least 80% compared to the previous year. Transport is a vital enabler for many sectors, including tourism, and ensures the transport of goods that we all depend upon. It is in fact the backbone of the single market and economic activity as such. So restoring transport in the EU and beyond must be accelerated, while keeping health requirements in mind.  Our guidelines of 13 May set out a common framework for the progressive and safe restoration of transport services and connectivity. They provide general principles applicable to all transport services and specific recommendations for each transport mode. We have also proposed guidelines on the safe resumption of tourism services across the entire ecosystem, such as in hotels and restaurants, or for tour operators.  Additional guidelines were presented for restoring free movement and for making vouchers more attractive. With these guidelines we have all the necessary tools at hand to restart with this important part of our economy, as of now, well ahead of the economically so important summer of 2020. No endeavour can ever be risk free. However, our guidelines and the protocols developed by our agencies take all precautionary measures and provide the best available practices for reducing risks, all while making the resumption of passenger transport possible. These guidelines should be complemented by widespread information about the measures taken, so that each European can make responsible and well-informed decisions about how to limit health risks while travelling.  Any measures imposed in the transport sector have to be proportionate and risk-based. It is very important that Member States are, as of this week, leaving the general transport bans or internal borders restrictions behind and favour instead more targeted measures. This means increasing cleaning, using protective equipment, prioritising electronic ticketing or avoiding crowding in hubs. Cumulatively, these targeted measures can provide the much needed trust for people to restart travelling. Because of the unique nature of aviation, the EU Aviation Safety Agency and the European Centre for Disease Control have published additional operational recommendations based on the Commission’s general guidelines. It clarifies that a number of appropriate measures should be taken. This can, in conjunction with inbuilt features in aircraft, such as hospital grade filters, permit the reduction of risks to acceptable levels. Acting together is key, since transport is by nature a cross-regional and cross-border activity. It goes without saying that restoring links must always be coordinated, in particular we need to ensure that any measures applied at points of arrival and departure are mutually acceptable, otherwise travel will become prohibitively burdensome, expensive and in some cases impossible.  In this regard, we will also continue our good cooperation with Member States through our network of transport contact points established at the beginning of the COVID-19 crisis in the context of the Green Lanes guidelines. Safety is not the only thing needed to inspire trust. Trust is also built on precedent and the precedent we wanted to defend is that consumers should be protected in the EU at all times. The Commission has been clear throughout this crisis that the rights of passengers to reimbursement shall not be restricted. Consumers, especially those who have been hit economically by the crisis, will only get back to travelling for leisure and tourism if they can rest assured that their travel packages and flights are to be reimbursed if cancelled. In addition to all that, resuming passenger transport and tourism requires business continuity for all the sectors. Securing working capital, funding of operations, public support for businesses to maintain investment pipelines are all vital economic prerequisites for regaining connectivity and building a transport system that is fit for the future.  The Commission has therefore proposed a robust and comprehensive package for the recovery of the EU economy. Although specific economic sectors do not have ring-fenced funding in the recovery package, it is clear that those economic ecosystems, such as transport and tourism, will be able to benefit from several funding opportunities. I therefore seek your support in adopting this package swiftly. It provides a unique window of opportunity for funding in transport, tourism, automotive, aeronautics, and ship manufacturing, as well as all other industries needed to ensure sustainable, resilient and affordable connectivity for 2020 and beyond.  I will devote all my efforts in convincing Member States and private stakeholders in using the EU instruments available, to increase liquidity and to get firmly on a recovery path. The Commission’s proposed recovery package to kick-start the European economy contains an array of opportunities for transport under the EUR 1.1 thousand billion MFF and the EUR 750 billion in the Next Generation EU programme. The recovery package includes a reinforced budget for the Connecting Europe facility, with an additional EUR 1.5 billion for the general envelope to stimulate further infrastructure investment. It will accelerate the completion of the Core TEN-T network due by 2030. It will stimulate the Digital and Green Transition with clear priority given to the most decarbonised modes, rail and inland navigation, and it will accelerate the deployment of clean technologies such as alternative fuel infrastructure, in line with our Green Deal agenda.  We are also proposing an enhanced InvestEU with an increased budget of EUR 31.6 billion. This will include a new Strategic Investment Facility, the InvestEU’s fifth window to support critical infrastructure and the development of resilient value chains, including for new clean technologies that are essential for the transport sector.  In addition, the sustainable infrastructure window has almost doubled in size in our proposal and now has a EUR 20 billion guarantee which can stimulate private investment in sustainable transport infrastructure and fleet renewal.  With a total budget of EUR 560 billion the recovery and resilience facility can benefit all sectors of the economy, including transport. Member States will submit their plans — recovery and resilience plans — by April next year in order to receive grants or loans. I am sure that investment in sustainable transport systems will be high on the recovery agenda of Member States, as this is mentioned in almost all country reports of the EU Semester on which the national plans will have to be based.  Of course there is also the solvency support instrument under the European Fund for Strategic Investment with EUR 26 billion which can mobilise additional private capital to support eligible companies in the sectors most impacted by the Coronavirus. All these instruments will continue to support our priorities of sustainability and digitalisation — the focus of our upcoming Strategy in Transport communication. The Coronavirus changed a lot, but not the need for smarter sustainable mobility. 80% of the CEF budget for transport is already contributing to climate action. For the entire MFF and the Next Generation EU we propose an overall target of 25% climate mainstreaming. For transport it could be even higher.  I would like to conclude by commending you for the European Parliament resolution highlighting many of the challenges and solutions taken. As we look forward, we are of course learning lessons from our experiences over the last few months. The situation was unprecedented, and I would dare to say that we are now wiser and better prepared. I am looking forward to your questions and comments. Thank you very much.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the tourism sector has undoubtedly been the most punishable sectors by the pandemic: one third of humanity in confinement, air traffic below 90%, tourism activity is virtually zero. The tourism sector is the mainstay of our economic growth. In fact, it has been the most powerful ally of the European economy. Europe is the world's first tourist destination. Talking about tourism is much more than talking about leisure; is to talk about cohesion, solidarity, culture, vertebration, the future. A European response is therefore urgent.  The European People's Group, and Spanish, in particular, wanted to be a locomotive in the response. And that is why we are asking, first of all, to be a priority in the recovery plan and, secondly, a clear roadmap. We need certainties, we need coordination and we need security.  We need security in health protocols and in protocols, too, security ÷ they are common; European measures to be recognized by each other÷; we need help from SMEs, because the productive fabric of tourism is made up of more than 90% of SMEs; we need ÷ and relaull connectivity for the Balearic Islands or the Canary Islands, for the outermost regions, is key.  And we also need a strategy for the future of European tourism. We call for action. We cannot waste a minute, because the future of Europe is at stake. There is no solidarity. Europe does not exist without solidarity, but neither would Europe exist without tourism.

name: István Ujhelyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European As a Social Democrat MEMBER, I am speaking to you now on behalf of and on behalf of 27 million Hungarian workers, including more than 500 000 Hungarian workers. Yes, the waiter of the Balaton winery, the receptionist of the Budapest hotel, the Maltese tour operator, but also the stewardesse of the German airline asks what you are doing specifically for us. Because until now, national governments have mostly viewed tourism as a tree that bears fruit forever. They didn't want to feed him. Now we can all figure out how not that is. Therefore, the Social Democratic Group demands immediate assistance and concrete means from the reconstruction plan. We need a crisis management mechanism that we can pull out at any time in the long run if we find ourselves in a similar situation. We need a European passenger guarantee system and, importantly, a long-term sustainable and smart new European tourism strategy. That is what we have proposed, now we need to put the profession and employers, workers, on a ventilator, and then we need a sustainable smart plan so that European tourism always comes to fruition.

name: José Ramón Bauzá Díaz
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, we have been hearing about data and abstract commitments for months: that tourism accounts for 10% of the European Union's GDP, which is a strategic sector for the Union, that the Commission is fully committed to the countries that depend most on it... But the European Union cannot simply settle for that. We cannot simply receive recommendations knowing that they are not being followed by the rest of the member countries. Why is the European Commission calling on 13 May to end compulsory quarantines when other countries, such as Spain, impose their own quarantine? Why has border opening occurred in an uncoordinated way, so that countries with similar epidemiological characteristics have differentiated and spaced openness over the period of one month? Why are countries being vetted on each other within the European Union itself? Why does a sector employing twenty-two million people, accounting for 12% of the total Union workers, not receive a single euro cent as a budget item devoted to tourism? That tourism is an absolutely relegated and secondary sector for the Commission we have heard in this House too many times, and unfortunately I am afraid we will continue to hear it. Already with the crisis of the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook we said that it was necessary, more than ever, to develop a common strategy that would allow us to anticipate misfortunes and not improvise. And unfortunately, another misfortune has come and re-improvised. Madam Commissioner, as spokesperson for Renew Europe, as a Citizens MEP and as a former president of the Government of the Balearic Islands, a region absolutely linked to tourism, I have proposed to you our concept of a Europe brand, based on three pillars: the opening of borders, common quality and safety standards and also the promotion of the European Union as a tourist destination. Commissioner, you have our full and absolute support to exercise the political leadership that the European Union needs. We will always be at your side. For tourism and, above all, for Europe and also for Europeans.

name: Roman Haider
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, tourism is the industry most affected by the crisis, and that is why it is very regrettable that The President of the Commission, Mr von der Leyen, did not mention tourism in a single word in her speech today.  What is needed now to help the enormously important tourism sector in particular, but also the transport and transport sector in general, which is vital for Europe, is, on the one hand, unbureaucratic financial aid, which really appeals to businesses. On the other hand, it is also fatal right now for the Commission to insist on particularly strict compliance with climate targets in this area.  The Green Deal will prove to be a massive obstacle in the area of transport – especially there – and also for tourism, unless major changes are made here. Instead of continuing to lash out at tourism and transport companies, the Commission should start with financial aid and building an efficient high-performance network that is also environmentally sound.

name: Tilly Metz
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Following the COVID-19 blocking measures, we must ensure a safe, sustainable and coordinated reopening of the tourism and transport sector. In this sense, I welcome the Commission's guidelines and recommendations. Let us also look ahead to prepare for the transport and tourism we want in the future. The climate crisis will not disappear even with the end of the pandemic, and the transport and tourism sector must contribute to reducing our environmental footprint. The crisis has taught us that societies and people can drastically change their habits. We stayed at home, stopped flying and started cycling more and walking more. We now have a unique opportunity to redesign the concept of tourism and invest in sustainable modes of transport such as the train – especially night trains – and the bicycle and its infrastructure. It is also an opportunity to promote agroecology and the development of rural areas in the interests of tourism. I call for a plan for sustainable tourism in Europe and thus a win-win situation: good working conditions, full cash registers for suppliers, a healthy environment – and thus a safe travel experience for travellers.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Few industries have suffered as much damage as transport and tourism as a result of this crisis. Overnight, companies operating in these sectors simply had to suspend their operation altogether. It will take them years to rebuild their capacity and will require a great deal of organisational and financial effort, which today rests primarily on the shoulders of the Member States. Therefore, the guidelines published by the Commission alone are not enough. Real support is needed, which will not be subject to unsusvable climate targets. The implementation of new rules, such as the extremely costly and harmful mobility package, should be suspended. The Commission should also review the provisions which may, under these exceptional conditions, constitute an additional burden. Fifteen Member States have taken the right direction when calling for vouchers in air transport. It is a pity that the Commission ignored the reasonable arguments in this regard.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, tourism is a powerful growth accelerator and it is the economic sector most hit by the health crisis. Millions of jobs are at risk with a deterioration in labour rights and with horizontal reductions in wages and incomes. Tourism is the people of hospitality and cannot exist without them. We must support small and medium-sized enterprises that are suffocated by a lack of liquidity in order to survive this critical period. We must prevent bankruptcies and their acquisitions from being strong, as well as serious price distortions that will affect healthy competition, the market and consumers themselves. Today, therefore, we are calling for the safe ness of travel, with massive tests, without the financial burden on citizens, direct support for work and businesses to remain competitive the next day, as well as essential tools for the future, a tourism budget, a European crisis management mechanism including protection and compensation for travellers in the event of bankruptcies, as well as an integrated European strategy for sustainable tourism.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: – We are in the midst of the COVID crisis and transport has problems, but transport is the solution as well.  Why should we go for an HSPRN – a high-speed passenger rail network – connecting all major cities in the European Union amidst a COVID-19 crisis? Because public spending makes sense to combat the economic crisis. It is logical, because to invest in a green project for a sustainable future that is beneficial for all makes sense; because infrastructure investment is needed for economic growth; because future generations would like to know where the money we are spending today went. That is why we need an ambitious, tangible programme with a budget that makes it possible. That is why we should go for an HSPRN – a high-speed passenger rail network.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for this debate. It is a debate which gives us the opportunity to work on a resolution which touches on a point, as my fellow Members have said and repeated on several occasions, which is crucial. The impact of the crisis has fully weakened the tourism sector. The tourism sector has an impressive feature: it intercepts many other sectors, as is often the case. Tourism intercepts transport, culture and economic development. There is one particular issue – I will not repeat myself – an issue that strikes me and which I believe must be the subject of specific funding in the Recovery Fund, it would be a mistake not to foresee them: the protection of the professionalism of the human capital of the myriad small businesses, which in the tourism sector, have struggled over the years, have built up very capable staff and who could lose today. A small business educates for years in the hotel sector, in the catering sector, a staff that today is in danger of losing. The social impact on this could be very serious, and we would all pay for it, including culturally. Let us act on this promptly.

name: Johan Danielsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is fitting that it is precisely this week that we in the European Parliament are adopting our resolution on tourism, a week that began with the reopening of many of our national borders. Now is also the start of summer holidays and holidays. It is important, of course, that we are able to open up to tourism and travel in Europe, on the one hand, to tourists who have the opportunity to see new things, to experience things, but above all to the 22 million Europeans who depend on tourism in their work and for their income.  As so many have said, "If this is to work, it requires that those who travel, those who are going to travel are safe. On the flight, on the trains, on the bus, at hotel facilities and so on. But it also requires that those who work in hotels, those who work in restaurants or shops, those who clean, are safe when they go to work.  So we must ensure that, as we gradually open up our economies, we also guarantee the health and safety of all the millions of people working in these sectors. Because the economy is important, but it is also important that we guarantee people's health at work.

name: Marco Campomenosi (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Commissioner Vălean for being here, the opportunities for discussion with you and your colleague Mr Breton are different and we have already had the opportunity to talk about what the impact is on tourism and transport of this crisis and how wide it is. I shall speak this evening mainly on the subject of tourism precisely because, as my fellow Members have said, it is a very important sector. In my own country, Italy alone, it accounts for 13 % of gross domestic product. There has been a lot of talk about how to intervene economically. In truth, it could also be done at no cost, simplifying legislation through the legislative power that the Commission has in Brussels. I am thinking, for example, of the Services Directive, and we have also discussed it with Commissioner Breton. Action can be taken on the scope. For years, investments in the bathing sector in Italy have been blocked precisely because of the risk and problems that may arise from the application of a directive that dates from 2006 and today we are in 2020. Action can be taken to exclude this sector.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I believe that tourism is not something that europe should really interfere in. Tourism is often a national, regional and very often local issue. I think we have to realise that this summer, above all, will not be a year of tourism as it usually looks. In Sweden, for example, we have a government that has handled the pandemic so terribly badly that we are not welcome to some countries simply. Swedes are not allowed in.  I therefore believe that we must realise that it will take time before we come back again, when tourism will be as it used to be. We won't see the end of this pandemic for quite some time to come, I'm afraid. But tourism needs to be kept under its arms, helped, and it is best done by the governments of the various Member States, not from the EU, which have the eagerness to put their fingers in just about everything that a nation state does better.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think that the Corona crisis has clearly shown us our limitations. It has shown us that, unfortunately, this European Union is not the Union we want. But that means that we must work to make this European Union better. We have 27 million people in the European Union who work in the tourism industry and, as you know, Commissioner, generate 10.3% of European GDP. Package tourism alone generated EUR 130 billion in sales in 2017. We must therefore solve the problems of the present, because small businesses, travel agencies and service providers have liquidity problems, and we need to address these liquidity problems. We in the Socialist Group are proposing a European Travel Guarantee Fund, which would cost around EUR 5 to 7 billion. This is a meaging amount compared to the EUR 32.9 billion that Member States are currently spending to bail out the airlines alone. Hence our call, and then the call on members of Parliament to vote in favour of this fund.

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, well, thank you all very much for your comments. I think we are all on the same page here. We all recognise the importance of the sector of tourism and the sector of transport for all our economies. We are all worrying about how this is going to unfold in the future and how we are going to emerge from this crisis.  I said in the beginning, I gave some hints, well, you know, I’m thinking, and I’m sure many of you are doing the same thing, that we need to develop a sort of an emergency plan so that next time if, God forbid such a thing will come again, we will be prepared, for the second one.  And then we have to debate the lessons learned and I think this is also something very important that needs to be done very soon. We have to learn from the lessons that this crisis taught us in order to become better, and as has been said, it showed us our limits.  But on the other hand, now we are talking about tourism because it’s been hit so hard. It’s true that it’s a long debate on subsidiarities and what each of the Member States of the European Union should deal with and what is the degree of implication.  Of course, usually, when problems occur, everyone is looking towards Brussels and I would really have wished that we would have had the money to step in, but we didn’t have the money, at European level, to step in for the liquidity crisis. So we had to ask the Member States. We put forward this flexible framework for State aid, to step in and help with liquidity. We had to protect the consumers while we were helping the companies with liquidity.  I heard several of you - and this is a floating idea going around - because it is a lesson learned, that what you do with the liquidity issue - if a huge amount of reimbursement or compensation would be asked for in case of cancellation. And I know there is this idea of a European fund. But it has to be in a budget and of course if the Member States would like to put money together for such a fund that’s one thing, on the other hand, with all the complicated discussions we have with the budget, with the MFF and everything, I haven’t seen any true appetite for creating new things at the European level.  We have to admit the fact that there are several - at national level - several schemes of guaranteeing these kind of packages and I think that here, this can be shared, and lessons learned by Member States should include also the fact that we cannot live without having a fund to guarantee all of this, or else it won’t work and the liquidity problem will be very difficult to solve.  There are, and probably you are right, we are thinking about this, that by using State aid, it might create disparities or imbalances in the competition in the market because of some Member States having a larger fiscal capacity to step in and help companies, others less. Then we feared creating an unbalanced situation for the future.  But that’s why, for example, we imagine that we proposed the solvency instrument, which would be aimed through the European Investment Fund, especially to step in and help, including by buying equity, those companies which were less helped and they would be in need of better help at the European level because they didn’t receive it at the national level.  So, we are advanced and we are engaged with the European financial institutions, with the EIB, to map and see how all the instruments we have put in place, which is quite an exhaustive list, can be used for various situations.  But anyway, our aim is to support those who are not helped and there are viable companies to be helped through this financial instrument at European level.  Transport workers are critical and I think from the very beginning, from the very first guidelines we put forward, we stressed the importance of them being treated as critical workers. So that’s why we didn’t have them put in quarantine when they’re crossing the border or one or the other. We, in all the guidelines we had for each mode, we insisted on the protective measures to be taken, especially for workers in transport. And I think this is the same for tourism and for the hospitality industry, because if the workers are getting sick or if they are not protected, it makes it a no-brainer.  So, I think everyone started that. We have to have them safe in order to have them providing services. So this is something I’m totally supporting. For small and medium-sized enterprises, we had put very quickly in place some instruments - by my colleagues, of course, in the Commission. For example, we have the SURE programme, which is an instrument to support, especially jobs. We put in EUR 100 billion in loans for SURE, especially to support short-time work schemes and to help the Member States to protect the jobs, the employees and the self-employed against the risk of dismissal and loss of income. Is it enough? I don’t know. We are of course in a continuous process of evaluating how all these proposals we have had are actually working.  And also, the idea behind the creation of the Next Generation EU fund is especially for the recovery, it is foreseen for recovery. We have been thinking of front-loading a lot of money at the beginning of next year or so from the MFF. So this will be an injection of capital and funds, which would translate ultimately into jobs and profitability for the companies in economic sectors.  I think this would cover more or less some of the issues you have raised. Of course, we would love to see simplified procedures.  There are also messages from you, which I will take to my colleagues in the college, so that we can further reflect on the situation.  While we are talking about the future, you will receive our strategy; you will see that we are aiming at putting it to consultation. By the end of the year, you will receive our strategy for sustainable and smart transport. I would add also resilient.  So that will be a great opportunity for us to look to the future. But the future cannot be but sustainable and smart. So also when we are talking about tourism, I think, for tourism itself, the future has to be sustainable, and this is a debate we will have to have, because I don’t want to forget about that.  There are also lots of schemes at regional level for tourism - because we saw, in relation to the situation with the crisis, it has a footprint, which is regional and the necessities and challenges are different from one region to another. So, through the regional funds, I know that financing was made available. Finally, let’s not forget that this is a health crisis. This is a health crisis. And the situation with the virus and the epidemiological situation is so different from one place to another. We need to trust. We need to make people understand that as long as we don’t have a vaccine or a viable treatment, there is a risk. And we have to continue to live with the virus.  So this is the situation and a most unfortunate one. But we need to adapt and try to be safe and restart the connectivity and the services in tourism and in transport.  Thank you very much for having me this evening and I’m looking forward to our next encounter.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, seven motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Thursday, 18 June 2020, and the final vote on Friday 19 June 2020. As we have already mentioned, the result of the second round of voting will be announced on Thursday at 9 a.m. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Magdalena Adamowicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The spread of COVID-19 virus in the European Union has led to the almost collapse of the tourism industry in Europe. Support is therefore urgently needed for entrepreneurs, in particular the self-employed and small and medium-sized enterprises, to help them manage their liquidity, maintain jobs and reduce unnecessary administrative burdens. Thousands of companies, especially smaller ones, are fighting for survival today, many of them struggling with insolvency. Help is needed immediately. In this context, it is important to draw attention once again to the current lack of a specific Financial Instrument of the European Union to help rebuild the tourism industry after the pandemic. Moreover, the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 also lacked a dedicated budget line for tourism. I believe that, given the experience of recent months, there should be a broad discussion on the European Union's comprehensive tourism policy, which is an extremely important sector of the European economy.

name: Pablo Arias Echeverría (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Joint Resolution adopted by the European Parliament proposes concrete measures to the European Commission to deal with the recovery of the tourism and transport sectors and to emerge from the crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. These two sectors are among the most affected and an agile and coordinated response by the European institutions is essential. Health and economic confidence and legal certainty are what gives certainty to the tourism and transport sector to reactivate its activity.  In this line, the Joint Resolution includes several proposals by the Spanish Delegation of the People's Party in the European Parliament, such as the development of a European certification seal to ensure the highest hygiene protocols in infrastructure and means of transport, in order to build trust among tourists, the implementation of measures for the recovery of tourism in the island regions and in the outermost regions (RUP) , or the need for a budget line dedicated to sustainable tourism within the next Multiannual Financial Framework (2021-2027). It also includes, at our request, the need to develop a long-term strategy for tourism that lays the groundwork for the sector to be prepared for potential future crises.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the tourism and travel sectors. Travel restrictions have already distressed the entire tourism value chain and affected approximately 27 million employees. To counter the devastating impact of COVID-19, we need to use the crisis as an opportunity to develop a comprehensive and future-proof European strategy that stabilises and rebuilds the sector and incorporates the European Green Deal. We must re—establish our citizens’ trust by ensuring consumer and passenger rights and protection. The European Commission has already clarified the voluntary nature of travel vouchers, but enforcement and widespread communication of this rule is lacking. A European Travel Guarantee Fund would address this issue by securing the financial liquidity of the tourism and travel sector while also guaranteeing consumer rights. Further, the establishment of uniform EU health guidelines along with Member State specific guidelines is vital for passenger protection. We must also develop a roadmap for sustainable tourism and travel by focusing on the creation of a non—toxic circular economy, urgently pushing the aviation and maritime industries to cut emissions, investing in digitalisation, and investing in sustainable tourism schemes for businesses – particularly SMEs, which must be guaranteed immediate access to liquidity and support.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. – Tourism is extremely important and Member States are doing their best to help their companies, and small and family businesses. The EU must help and supplement these efforts, through the Recovery programme. But true recovery can only happen if we rebuild the trust of travellers. To achieve this, coordination between the Member States is key. The Commission should facilitate this process, but it must remain within the remits of the national authorities to decide on lifting or introducing travel restrictions in view of their own assessment of the situation. There cannot be a one—size—fits—all solution, because it can backfire through an increasing number of infections. In the light of social distancing and lower capacities I am convinced that we must broaden the variety of European travel destinations. Therefore, in the coming weeks we must promote a much wider range of cities and regions. I am counting on the Commission to support such efforts. That would not only broaden the number of destinations and help the local hospitality sector, but it would make European tourism more sustainable and balanced, stopping over—tourism at certain locations.

name: Tomasz Frankowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic has taken a toll on all of us. The restrictions caused by quarantine, the movement ban and the dramatic slowdown in the economy have contributed to the decline of many transport and tourism companies. I would like to thank the European Commission for a number of recommendations enabling the gradual and coordinated provision of travel services and services and transport services. It is important that, when reactivating the European economy, it should be a priority to protect businesses and to promote jobs as actively as possible. Small and medium-sized enterprises make up 99% of all companies in Europe, creating two-thirds of all jobs. In this respect, more flexible administrative requirements and better access to financial assistance are needed, as it is these companies that are able to revitalise European tourism. I would also like to call on the European Commission to increase its support for the cultural and sport sectors, which play an important role in the development of tourism. Sport tourism is particularly popular, especially in the form of participation in major sporting events, which attracts fans and athletes even to the most remote regions.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The travel and tourism sector generates 3.9% of EU GDP and employs 5.1% of the total workforce, or around 11.9 million jobs. In conjunction with other sectors of the economy, these figures rise to 10.3% of GDP and 11.7% of total employment, which means 27.3 million workers. In Poland, the transport industry yates about 15% of GDP. The transport and tourism sectors are the sectors most affected by the coronavirus crisis. Restrictions on movement and travel following the pandemic have resulted in a 60%-80% decrease in international arrivals. It is estimated that the decline in hotel and restaurant revenues could be 50%, tourism operators and travel agencies 70%, and shipping lines and airlines 90%. As a result of the pandemic, 6.4 million jobs in the EU are at risk. Businesses are fighting for survival. That is why it is so important to guarantee them rapid specific support by providing credit lines to maintain liquidity, as well as revolving loans that finance the payment of remuneration. In the long term, however, measures are needed to ensure that tourists can travel to and within Europe again. It is also necessary to maintain strategic transport infrastructure, such as ports and railways, in order to protect it from foreign takeovers. The revision of the mobility package, the provisions of which will further plunge businesses, should also be rejected.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: in writing. – There are many factors which influence the choice of a holiday destination. Among them, very importantly, cultural heritage. Sixty-eight percent of Europeans point to this factor. Cultural tourism accounts for forty percent of European tourism. European projects, such as the European Capital of Culture, provide a great drive for cultural tourism. The 2020 Capitals - Rijeka and Galway - have sadly missed out in a special predicament, because of the pandemic. They need to rapidly adjust their programmes prepared for years in advance. A second wave or future virus could follow. We do not know if coronavirus will not come back with a second wave. Or some other new virus. However, being prepared is crucial. We must have preparedness, action plans, contingency all in place in advance for projects such as the European Capital of Culture for the future. Only in this way will we encourage future applicants for the title, among them the Silesian city of Katowice with the surrounding Metropolis of Zagłębie Dąbrowskie and Upper Silesia. Thank you very much!

name: Ondřej Kovařík (Renew)
text: Writing. – Tourism is not only one of the key sectors of the European economy, but also one of the most affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Although it currently faces a number of different problems, it also has the opportunity to create or seize new opportunities. It is now necessary to make efforts by all Member States to jointly restore tourism. Safety, public health and expert recommendations should be key factors. Citizens should also be sufficiently informed about the conditions and hygiene measures that have been put in place and are in force in individual destinations.

name: Julie Lechanteux (ID)
text: In writing. In the face of the COVID-19 crisis, the Commission presents a series of totally inadequate measures. On the other hand, the Members of the National Gathering propose concrete measures: an immediate 50 billion euro Sun Plan and a major campaign to raise awareness of local tourism; the cancellation of tax and social charges for 2020 for companies in the tourism sector that have achieved less than 70% of their usual turnover; The abolition of the CFE for 6 months; the acceleration of the procedure for repaying partial unemployment; The obligation for banks to provide government-guaranteed loans; The use of insurance in the operating loss of businesses; Helping and advising on the sanitary standards of facilities and activities; Helping staff train on new health protocols; Helping businesses adapt to the new situation: local customers, local products; The extension of terraces on public roads in conjunction with mayors, at no additional cost; automatic renewal of all concession contracts in 2021.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – Tourism is an important sector in number of workers and as gross domestic product, in some countries exceeding 15%, but also as a social bridge. Unfortunately, policies that target the largest number of citizens, education, health, tourism are not within the competence of the Union. The European Commission has already drawn up recommendations for tourism to help the sector emerge from the Covid-19 crisis. In order to withstand other crises, in order to have a common approach, to attract as many tourists as possible from outside Europe, it is necessary to have a common tourism policy, with harmonised rules, with the categories of tourist entities enjoying the same standards on operation and infrastructure. At the moment we do not have a similar approach to the protection of tourists or industry personnel, because all these things are at the discretion of each Member State. In this case, a solution must be found that does not involve a treaty change, but rather indirect ways. In tourism we have at our disposal the provisions related to consumer protection, which is a sector of shared competence. Starting from ensuring the protection of the tourist, we could even reach some rights of the tourist, as in the case of passengers.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE)
text: Writing. – The negative effects of the pandemic on the tourism sector continue at pan-European level and have now been reflected in the quantitative figures for the first quarter of 2020. In Greece, which is one of the most popular tourist destinations, there has already been a decrease in inbound tourism of 5.6% while in the corresponding receipts the drop reaches 17.1% compared to the same period of 2019. The Greek government has proved that it is making a championship in the control of the pandemic, which is an optimistic for the resumption of the tourist season, an important factor in the economy of Greece and the EU. However, at this very critical point in time, one step ahead of the global opening of the tourist season, liquidity is still needed. Greece has supported the European Recovery Programme from the outset but the tourism sector needs direct funding, with subsidies that will allow all tourism businesses to reopen normally and hundreds of thousands of people to return to their jobs. It is our duty to reverse the liquidity crisis, which has seriously compromised the viability of the industry the next day. The EU must lead this effort with the necessary funds in the form of pre-financing, which will lead to the maintenance of the competitiveness of Greek and European tourism.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU is now taking the first step towards developing a European tourism strategy. This should ensure a coordinated approach across the Union and all Member States in an area that is essential for our economy. The EP called for immediate action in the april debates and more, as tourism, together with transport, is the hardest hit economic sectors by the coronavirus pandemic. A tourism strategy must also have financial resources, so the call made in the EP resolution on a budget line dedicated to sustainable tourism in MFF 2021-2027 is crucial.  I welcome the Commission communication on tourism and transport, as well as the package of measures aimed at overcoming the crisis caused by coronavirus in these areas. I am convinced that, in addition to emergency intervention, we need a long-term approach. Now 6.5 million tourism jobs are at risk, with tens of thousands of SMEs at risk of stopping operations. The most critical moments are still ahead of us, and the immediate measures proposed by the Commission, implemented in close cooperation with the Member States, could ensure the return to the tourism sector and the rescue of many businesses and jobs.
